PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —For some time now, the Speaker and I have been considering the future administrative arrangements for the parliament in the context of increasing demands for services at a time of budgetary restraint. After reviewing comments from the heads of the five parliamentary departments, we have decided to implement a management structure based on the two chamber departments.

SPEECH.PARA: The functions of the present three joint departments—the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, the Department of the Parliamentary Library and the Joint House Department—will be merged into the Department of the House of Representatives and the Department of the Senate.

This two chamber department structure is the best way of achieving a dynamic and responsive organisation which will allow the parliament to make significant savings while improving the services provided to senators, members and committees.
The Speaker and I know that we will have the full and professional support of all staff in meeting the objectives of greater efficiency and effectiveness in the parliament's operations.

We have asked the departmental heads to provide us by Tuesday, 18 March with an implementation plan for the transition to the new structure. I will advise the Senate as soon as practicable after that, and as required by the rules of the Senate I will be consulting the Appropriations and Staffing Committee as the matter progresses.

DEBATE.TITLE:
BANKRUPTCY AMENDMENT BILL 1996 BANKRUPTCY (ESTATE CHARGES) BILL 1996
BANKRUPTCY (REGISTRATION CHARGES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 December 1996, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996 and cognate bills form part of measures designed to increase cost recovery from the Insolvency and Trustee Service, which administers bankruptcy matters. In total, the measures proposed by the government are designed to raise some $22.3 million over four years, being $3.6 million in 1996-97 and $6¼ million in each of the out years.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth looking at how the bills seek to do this. They do so by increasing the flag fall on the estates administered by the official trustee; by replacing the existing fees payable in respect of all bankruptcies by a flat levy on all realisations in bankruptcies; and by requiring registered trustees to hold trust funds in interest bearing accounts and to pay the interest earned to consolidated revenue. This is similar to the existing arrangements for interest earned on the common investment fund managed by the official trustee.

The genesis for these proposals came in our government's Meeting our commitments proposal before the election. In that document, the coalition committed itself to raising some $15 million over three years in the area of personal insolvency. It is worth looking at that document, which states:

There is some capacity for increased cost recovery in ITSA. ITSA has total revenue of approximately $27 million of which $22 million originates from Parliamentary appropriations. Better cost recovery will result in further savings of $15 million over three years.

The proposed greater cost recovery in this area may seem attractive, but it is simply bad policy. The persons who are ultimately likely to bear the cost of these increased fees will not be those people who either through their own financial mismanagement or through circumstances beyond their control have gone bankrupt. The people who will be slugged will be the creditors. The innocent parties in insolvency cases will be the ones who will be left to carry the burden of these increased fees.

Most of these creditors are small business owners—the people that this government has pretended to want to protect. These measures will punish those businesses not because they have done anything wrong but because they have had the misfortune of doing business with someone who has ultimately gone bankrupt. Why have the government led people to believe that they are acting in the interests of small business when this measure is ripping money from the small business sector? Why have they got it so wrong?

For a start, one has to look at what has to be called the sloppy job that was done in putting this commitment together. The estimates of expenditure on and revenue raised by ITSA in our pre-election document Meeting our commitments were based on the 1993-94 annual report—outdated. They could have got the most recent figures. Had they done that, they would have recognised that in 1995-96 a total of $28.7 million was appropriated to ITSA and approximately $7 million was raised by way of revenue. Even in 1994-95 the most up‐to‐date financial data would have shown that ITSA received $27½ million in appropriations and raised $8 million in revenue.

Let me turn to the individual fee increases to see what the government is doing. There will be a flag fall fee on the estates administered by ITSA, and that will rise from $2,000 to $4,000. This measure is expected to raise some $1.62 million in a full year. During estimates the Attorney-General's Department admitted that ITSA had estimated that the increase in the flag fall fee alone—and this is worth listening to, especially by those on the other side—would reduce the number of estates producing a dividend from 45 per cent to 30 per cent. So creditors in one out of every six bankruptcies will, because of this flag fall measure, now not receive a dividend.

Secondly, the proposal to increase revenue from the realisation charges will be achieved through an increase in the flat fee payable from three per cent to eight per cent. This measure is expected to raise some $4.2 million in a full year. In the last financial year, the total dividend paid was only $12.4 million. So one-third of last year's financial dividends will now be appropriated by government.

Finally, the payment of interest earned on realisation by registered trustees to consolidated revenue is expected to raise $430,000 in a full year. This interest is currently paid to creditors. So, once again, it is going to be those innocent small business people and individuals who will be ripped off by the operation of this particular measure. This revenue has been calculated on an assumed four per cent interest rate on such accounts, although no such minimum rate is required by the legislation. This is a senseless slug that will only harm ordinary Australians and, principally, small business owners.

The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996 does have some redeeming features. The bill also makes a number of minor amendments to the Bankruptcy Act 1966, which Labor does not seek to oppose. On that basis, I will shortly be moving an amendment to the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill which will delete those provisions of the bill which seek to facilitate the implementation of the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996. For the reasons I have already mentioned, Labor will be opposing the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill in full.

I will now turn to the Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill 1996 and focus on some of the provisions of that legislation. Clause 4 of the bill imposes a fee of $1,500 on applications to become a registered trustee. Clause 5 imposes a $1,000 registration fee. As a result, first time applicants to become registered trustees will now have to pay $2,500. Clause 6 of the bill also imposes a $1,000 fee for extension of registration. Clause 7 imposes a $500 fee for variation of the condition attaching to a person's registration as a trustee. I note that the introduction of fees for registration as a trustee, similar in magnitude to the above, were foreshadowed in the previous government's Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill. Accordingly, we will support this particular legislation.

With the election of the Howard government, we were promised a sudden boom in confidence in the business community. Quite simply, that has not materialised in the way we were promised. As a result, the number of bankruptcies rose to over 4,800 in the June quarter last year and to a staggering 5,400 in the September quarter—the highest, I believe, on record. The number of bankruptcies dropped only slightly in the December quarter but still remained unnecessarily high at some 5,100. Far from the post election bounce that was promised by the government, the figures on bankruptcy indicate that we are not on a smooth path to that sort of recovery.

As the September quarter figures show, the total number of bankruptcies and part X arrangements, assignments and compositions have risen in Queensland by over 45 per cent on the previous year. In the Northern Territory, Tasmania and Western Australia, the rises are 50 per cent, 54 per cent and 55 per cent respectively. In the ACT, the part of Australia most immediately impacted upon by this government, the rate of bankruptcies has risen by a staggering 63 per cent on the previous year. Some sort of boom! One of the few states to buck this trend is New South Wales which has had the lowest rate of increase in bankruptcies at only 19.6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the only Labor government.

—I say only 19, but that is small in relation to other states—and, as Senator Neal says, it is the only state with a Labor government. I also want to turn this morning to the appalling way this government has handled the pursuit of one of our most infamous and notorious bankrupts, Christopher Skase. We were all glad to hear late last year that the chase for Skase had been resumed. But that was only after this government and, in particular, the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) let the Australian people down by failing to seize the first available opportunity to continue to pursue Mr Skase.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me relate some of those facts, because I think they are important. On 26 August 1996, the trustee of Mr Skase's bankrupt estate, Mr Donnelly, made an application under section 305 of the Bankruptcy Act for financial assistance to further pursue the assets of Mr Skase. Section 305 of the act vests the power to grant such assistance in the Attorney-General. However, as most of these decisions are primarily bureaucratic in nature, the power has been delegated to the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy and the assistant secretary of the secretariat branch of the Insolvency and Trustee Service, Australia.

That was on 26 August. On 27 September 1996, the assistant secretary, pursuant to that delegation, determined that the application should not be granted. Without knowing more about the detail of that application, I do not think it would be appropriate for me to criticise the officer involved in that decision.

However, the decision failed to understand, I believe, the importance of Mr Skase as a symbol of the excesses of the 1980s corporate Australia. It failed to recognise the deep and continuing hurt and offence felt by many ordinary Australians who lost money to this deceptive man. It failed to recognise the importance of taking all reasonable steps to pursue this man as far as possible, to not allow him to forget that, while he, through his dishonesty and deception, is living in luxury, he did a lot of damage to the reputation of Australian businesses, to the financial structure of Australian businesses, to the esteem in which our laws were held, and, most importantly, to the livelihoods of many good, honest, hardworking Australians.

That a bureaucrat, strictly applying that section in accordance with the issued guidelines, should too narrowly construe his duty is perhaps capable of comprehension. But, mindful of the real anger Australians still feel towards Skase, mindful of the damage he has done to our reputation, mindful of the way that he continues to snub his nose at Australia and the rule of law here from faraway Majorca, the Attorney should not have condoned such a decision. For him to have done so, for him to have let it go through to the keeper at the time, is simply deplorable.

As was revealed in Senate estimates, the Attorney's office was briefed to the effect that the Skase decision was pending and that it was likely to be made on 24 September 1996. But Mr Williams failed, once again, to act. His office was formally notified of the deci sion on 2 October 1996. Again, he failed to act.

The Attorney, despite having the power to overturn this decision, failed to act prior to the decision becoming public on 9 October 1996. Even then—despite his office having been told during the afternoon of that day that the story was about to break on A Current Affair that night, despite knowing that even at that particular time he could have overturned that decision—he failed to act. Even when he did act, it took this Attorney some six weeks to make a decision that he could have made in six seconds.

The fact that he and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) then had the audacity to blame the bureaucrats for a decision which they knew that the Attorney had known about for some time and which, through the Attorney's own inaction, Mr Williams had condoned, is not only one of the most appalling acts of self-denial this place has seen but also one of the most stupendous failings of ministerial responsibility of recent times.

I think the Attorney owes a lot of apologies to a lot of people, including the Prime Minister, for not being alive at the wheel when this decision was conveyed to his office. He also needs to apologise for letting the department run in auto mode since the time he was alerted the decision had been pending. I think he also should apologise, Senator Harradine, to the bureaucrats whom he has let the carry the can as a result of his own ineptitude.

I have seen, even in recent days, both Mr Williams and Mr Howard lamely maintaining their defence by briefing journalists that it was all the department's fault. It was not. The minister is responsible. The minister always, as was recognised in the estimates process, had a legal capacity to intervene and to ensure another decision was taken. The minister was on notice, and the minister did not act. For that, he should be condemned.

But even today, Senator Harradine, there are still some very basic questions left hanging in respect of this matter. As of last week in the estimates process, the government is still refusing to tell the Australian public how much money the Attorney has set aside for the funding of the continued pursuit of Skase. All the Attorney has said is that the amount is comparatively small when compared with the $800,000 spent to date.

There is no legitimate reason why—with Mr Donnelly's report just about in the hands of the Attorney—the Australian public cannot be told how much resource this government is putting into the continued chase for Skase. The reason why the Attorney will not reveal the sum is that the amount is embarrassingly small. It is so small that he is afraid that it will show the government's decision to be nothing more than a very cheap political stunt.

Financial accountability means that this parliament will find out at some particular stage how much money has been allocated by the Attorney in this matter. We will have to find out, and I put the parliamentary secretary on notice that during the committee stage of this bill I will be asking more questions about why we do not know and why the Attorney will not tell the Australian public how much more money he is putting into it. If he is putting enough resource into the chase for Skase to be proud of, then he should be telling us. Our fear is that he has basically embarked upon a token effort here to save his political skin. That is not the motivation that should be involved in a matter like this.

So we believe there is no reason why the amount approved should not be released and the Attorney-General should come clean with it now. The opposition does, however, recognise that the chase for Skase has been continued. It is a pity, though, we cannot appreciate how dinkum the government is in respect of this.

In conclusion, as I have indicated earlier, I will be moving some amendments in relation to this legislation during the committee stage. I also indicate that the opposition will be supporting some parts of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the opportunity in the second reading debate to include some general remarks on bankruptcy matters in discussing these bills. The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996, the Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill 1996 and the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 create machinery and administrative mechanisms and raise charges to facilitate the substantial changes which were ushered into bankruptcy law last year. Those substantial changes were brought about by the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Act 1996 and will operate as measures which will further constrain dishonest and deceitful persons from ripping off ordinary Australians who, in good faith, provide finance, goods and services in the ordinary course of trade and commerce.

SPEECH.PARA: Some bankrupts are, of course, ordinary Australians fallen on hard times, but the people whom I refer to are economic and social vandals and should be given little quarter and little leeway. The Australian public, Senator Bolkus, has been rightly incensed by the way that the likes of Christopher Skase have been wrongly able to evade lawful civil and, in some cases, criminal prosecution. At least Alan Bond, who is now in gaol, had the courage to stay in Australia.

I was particularly pleased to see the inclusion of section 121 of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Act 1996 which, if our reading is correct, will address many of the issues which allow these scoundrels to fleece financial institutions, small creditors, the mums and dads of this nation and the revenue of the Taxation Office.

Section 121, on our reading, will have the effect of voiding transactions ab initio where the transferor's main purpose in making that transfer was to prevent the transferred property from becoming divisible among the bankrupt's creditors or to hinder or delay the process of making property available for division amongst the bankrupt's creditors. If this law had been in place during the 1980s and early 1990s, many small businesses and investors would have been spared the financial ruin caused by cheats and crooks whose sole purpose was to satisfy their own greed and the greed of their families.

It has been a disgrace that the pursuit of big‐time white collar crooks has been so difficult. If it were not for the tenacity of social and political commentators—and I name just one—such as Paul Barry, who is the author of the Rise and Fall of Alan Bond, as well as others of his ilk, then ordinary Australians would have been denied the rightful prosecution of bad bankrupts.

The history of bankruptcy law in this country has been testimony to the legal and political reality that individuals, family farmers and small businesses, who occupy the less lucrative end of the scale, have had applied to them a form of class discrimination and class policing. People in small businesses have never had the slack cut to them that the failed entrepreneurs of the 1980s did, simply because they did not have the same sorts of political connections. We know from our analysis of criminal statistics that some people in this country have the law applied to them in a more rigorous manner than others.

I want to turn to the role of foreign and other trustees or advisers. All big time white‐collar criminals have big lawyers, big accountants and big advisers in tow and not much that is ethical about them. Most of them go blithely along in their business today untouched by the scandal of the bankrupts. As one example, let us look at Bond and how his advisers are being dealt with.

For instance, his Swiss banker, Mr Bollag, is considered to be central to Mr Bond's financial affairs and is being currently questioned, I understand, as to whether he had any part in the deception that has seen Alan Bond's bankrupt estate realise very little of its true worth. It is proper that all connected persons are questioned. I believe that section 121 will go a long way to prevent the hiding of assets in the future so that we do not find a person such as Alan Bond, who now earns $40 a week in prison, being able to miraculously produce a $750,000 payment which was not acknowledged in the information given to his bankruptcy trustees. Are we all mugs to accept that state of affairs and to let it continue?

It is lamentable that the law we are about to enact today will not apply to existing or past petitioners for bankruptcy. But this chamber, as the whole parliament does, respects the rule of retrospectivity. The previous government was far too slow in responding to the excesses of the 1980s. I and many others believe that was the result of being far too close in political and financial terms to many of those failed entrepreneurs. The money that has been poured into political parties then and now will involve a tainting of the political and legislative process. Some of the arrangements with mates in the last decade were profoundly unethical and immoral. In my own state the legacy of those days is the imprisonment of two past premiers and one deputy premier from both sides of the political spectrum.

However, the greater problem that the Bond and Skase matters exemplified are the weaknesses in our system of corporate governance. Shareholders are still required to challenge board members and directors but have failed to do so with any of the authority and the vigour that they should have. That may be because we operate in a system where our shareholders do not have democratic rights, and the institutions and the large shareholders dominate the process and they are very much tied up in an elite manner.

The regulatory authority, now the Australian Securities Commission, should be as hard hitting as the very best of such agencies internationally. A major publicity campaign on the shortcomings of auditors needs to be implemented. Finally, the banks of this country now with their finances recovered on the backs of small business must frequently be reminded of their part in allowing entrepreneurs to survive with creative balance sheets. It is only when people such as Tiny Rowland did the work on Alan Bond that the whole pack of cards came down. The so-called banking people who were supposed to be able to regulate these matters were incapable of doing that analysis themselves.

The government has, by the bills before us, sought to implement greater cost recovery. Our concern with the charges in the estate charges bill that will be implemented is that less of a pie will be left over for equitable distribution of the bankrupt's estate. That is a political decision the government will have to wear and, on my part, I find it difficult to see how such a scenario is beneficial to small business in this country.

To the extent that these various amending bills will allow dishonest persons to be pinned down, then the law will finally be coming to terms with the legacy of the greed of the 1980s. I must say that it is with some concern that I see the drive towards simplification of the various corporate laws resulting in less oversight in many respects. If anything is to be gained from those experiences it is the knowledge that unrestrained individualism to the detriment of the community has little value in the long-term prosperity of our nation.

It will only be when the mechanisms of ethics, accountability and transparency are universally applied that the Australian public will become more relaxed that the Alan Bonds and Christopher Skases of our land will never get another strong toehold in our community or our economy. The Australian community has lived long enough with the consequences of the actions of these people and still does so.

The Australian Democrats will not be proposing amendments to these bills unless amendments which substantially improve these bills are offered in the committee stage. We will be supporting the bills as they are put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the speeches of Senator Bolkus and Senator Murray. The matters they put forward I think are matters that should be taken into account. But there is another side to bankruptcy laws in addition to pursuing those people who, as it were, rorted the system. The other side of it is that these laws are there to help those people who legitimately—people without any fault—go bankrupt. That is the other side of the law that is being introduced this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is proper that we make it clear that this parliament understands that it is not only crooks who go bankrupt and bring devastation upon the society but also people who, despite all the good efforts and honesty they put into any sort of enterprise, nevertheless go bankrupt. These measures introduced this morning will help them as well.

I am glad to see that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General, Senator Ellison, is handling this matter on behalf of the government because he was part of a committee that looked at this issue so very well. He did a lot of good work on that committee. On this broadcast day, I acknowledge the work that he has done, not only on this report but on many others in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, may I thank senators for their contribution to this debate, and particularly Senator Cooney for his kind comments. It is true that we both sat on that committee, Senator Cooney. I think you chaired it in 1995 in relation to the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill. It was as a result of one of the submissions to that committee that we have implemented a provision that deals with the keeping of a trust account by trustees—that is, they keep one single trust account relating to all the estates that they administer. I will come to that shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: The level of increased cost recovery from ITSA, the Insolvency and Trustee Service of Australia, was announced in the government's pre‐election policy statement, Meeting our commitments. These measures give effect to that policy. The bills before the Senate provide for separate legislation imposing charges that are, with the exception of the interest charge, currently imposed by regulation under the Bankruptcy Act 1966.

The proposed fees and charges are not altogether new. They involve an increase in existing fees already collected. In the case of interest from trust fund moneys in the administrations of registered trustees, they merely apply the requirements that have existed in respect of ITSA bankruptcies since 1980. This will partly offset the cost borne by taxpayers in maintaining the bankruptcy system. At the same time, the measure contained in the bill significantly reduces the paperwork burden on trustees in complying with the Bankruptcy Act, which should reduce cost to the administrations which are borne by creditors.

At this point, I refer to some of the matters that Senator Bolkus raised. At the outset, Senator Bolkus mentioned the flagfall for the official trustee, which is raised from $2,000 to $4,000. That was done by way of regula tion in December last year to achieve parity between ITSA's fees and those in the private sector. If there is any submission on the part of the opposition that this is contained in this legislation, that is not so. I make that point for the benefit of those who have any doubt, and it really is quite misleading to say that this legislation does that. The flagfall increase was done by regulation in December last year. I also remind the Senate that, in relation to the question of this increased flagfall, one still has the choice between a registered trustee and the services of ITSA. So it is not as if this has been imposed willy‐nilly on creditors.

There are other aspects of the opposition's position on which I will comment. Firstly, the opposition, by opposing the measures mentioned, is denying the government the opportunity to impose the realisations charge—even at the current rate. The current rate of three per cent has been at that level since 1988. The proposal to require the payment to consolidated revenue of interest earned on funds held in trust by registered trustees supports the change in arrangements that will allow registered trustees to hold a single trust account for all estates if they wish to do so. I mentioned at the outset that this was a matter which was raised before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee in 1995. It also removes an existing anomaly whereby interest on funds held in trust by the official trustee has for some time been paid to consolidated revenue.

The new interest charge on interest on trust fund moneys in administrations of registered trustees merely applies the requirements that have existed in respect of ITSA bankruptcies since 1980. What you have here is the treatment of both on the same level—levelling the playing field—and making the situation apply equally to estates administered by registered trustees or by ITSA. There is no reason why there should be any difference in approach between the two sectors. I point out to the Senate that the amount of interest is payable as the amount derived less bank fees. While it is true that the increase in charges may have an impact on creditors, the creditors are also among the principal beneficiaries of the system.

BREAK.PARA: It is not true to say that the government will achieve full cost recovery for ITSA. These proposals will go a long way to making ITSA more viable in that respect and towards achieving greater cost recovery. But it is not true that there will be 100 per cent cost recovery, as maintained by the opposition.

I submit, with respect, that the opposition fails to recognise that the measures contained in these bills will significantly reduce the paperwork burden on trustees in complying with the Bankruptcy Act which, in turn, should reduce the cost of administrations which are borne by creditors. So we are looking at a streamlining of the system to reduce the paperwork, to treat registered trustees the same as ITSA, and to lessen the cost which will be borne by the creditors in the long run.

It is worthwhile to dwell on the point that Senator Bolkus made that the flagfall raised by regulation last year would limit the amount of funds available to creditors. Of course, in only 20 per cent of bankruptcies are there any assets to speak of which are divided. Eighty per cent of bankruptcies have little or no assets for division among creditors. So you are looking at a small rump of bankruptcies numbering 20 per cent. You then look at the flagfall itself—it is an increase in fee of $2,000. That, in the scheme of things, will not prejudice creditors but, in the long run—with its assistance in cost recovery—it will make ITSA more viable.

That is where we have to look at the functions that ITSA performs. ITSA delivers a number of public interest services and I think it is important that the Senate remembers this. Some of those are the development of policy advice, information to debtors, education to debtors and creditors and generally the education of the commercial community, and particularly in providing financial counsellors and practitioners. It also exercises the role of regulation and it provides the official receiver with powers in relation to bankruptcy and trustees, and also there are law enforcement responsibilities that ensure that a credible system is maintained.

As well as this, the official trustee, through ITSA, administers roughly 92 per cent of all bankrupt estates. ITSA performs the function of administering non‐fee paying estates on behalf of creditors, and as well there is the new debt agreement system, which Senator Cooney would recall from the legislation going before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee, which involves small estates of $52,000 and under. That avoids the formality and the complexity of bankruptcy and, of course, ITSA has to administer that as well. ITSA has wide ranging roles and you can see the importance of having cost recovery in that sector.

Senator Murray raised some very interesting points about the 1980s, and I might just touch on the Skase matter. The opposition really has a cheek raising the Skase matter today. Where was the opposition when it was in government in the 1980s in relation to the rorts and the entrepreneurs that were making hay while the sun shone under the Keating and Hawke governments? What were they doing about that?

I am glad Senator Murray reminded me of what actually went on during those days, because we have a situation where the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) is determined to do everything possible to bring to justice Christopher Skase, and additional resources have been provided to Mr Donnelly in relation to the Skase matter. If I were to put on record in the Senate the detailing of that resource—the details of what the Attorney‐General wanted to do and the detail of the strategy of the Attorney‐General—no doubt the people who would be rubbing their hands with glee would be Mr Skase and his lawyers. I am not about to put on record the Commonwealth's position in relation to the Skase matter. Suffice to say, the Attorney‐General has provided additional resources and is pursuing this matter with vigour.

If Senator Bolkus wants to raise these points and shoot the Attorney‐General's position down in flames and give Mr Skase and his solicitors some advantage, well, be it on his head, but the government will not be a party to that. It would be irresponsible for the Attorney‐General to divulge any detail of what really is an operational matter. It has been a longstanding convention in the Senate and its committees that details of operational matters are not made public, for very good reasons.
I foreshadow to Senator Bolkus that, for those reasons, any questions which go into the detail of the Attorney‐General's conduct of the Skase matter will be met with the answer I have just given.

I am pleased to see that the Democrats will not be opposing any of these bills, and I thank Senator Murray in that regard. I also note that the opposition will not be opposing the Bankruptcy (Registration Charges) Bill 1996. As I say, the measures before the Senate today consolidate existing charges within a single package that will have the effect of simplifying the imposition and collection of charges. It also provided the Inspector‐General with the authority and responsibility for auditing accounts of administrations of both registered trustees and the official trustee. The combined effect of these measures already enacted in the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Act 1996 and the powers proposed in the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill will allow for enhanced supervision of trustees. By opposing these measures, the opposition will be denying the government the opportunity to make important reforms in this area.

The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question to ask of the parliamentary secretary. It does relate to the Skase matter. When does the government expect to receive Mr Donnelly's report? The information we got last week was that it will be very soon, and the department was on notice that we would probably be seeking further information as to what `very soon' meant.
—We do not have any further advice to that which was offered to you at Senate estimates.

—Parliamentary Secretary, you mentioned earlier that this is an operational matter and, as such, the parliament is not entitled to know how much the government has put into the operation chasing Skase. In the past have there been circumstances where the government has made available to the parliament information on resources put into the investigation? Whether it is bankruptcy or other matters, I would put to you, parliamentary secretary, that quite often we get an idea of how much has been put into it. For instance, ballpark figures were mentioned as to what resources the government anticipated spending on the inquiry into the Australian Federal Police.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not accept the contention you are putting up that we would impinge on the operational aspects of this investigation if you were to tell us at this stage how much the government has allocated to Mr Donnelly to pursue what we know is the next stage of the chase for Skase. There are precedents. Why will you not tell us at this time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that there are precedents. Quite frankly, this is a matter which is pending. It has not been brought to a conclu sion. I dare say that Mr Skase and his lawyers would love to know how much money the Commonwealth is going to spend on this, because it is always an advantage to know what resources your other side has. I can tell you from experience that if you know that the other side has limited funds to fight a matter, you know that you can run them to the wire and exhaust their case accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter is pending. It is a delicate matter. It is one where strategy could well win the day. One of those is not letting the other side know what resources you are putting into it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very convenient argument, but we know already, for instance, that $800,000 has been allocated to this matter. We also know that because a government may put $30,000, $50,000 or $100,000 into the next phase of an operation, that does not preclude the government from putting in extra resources after the next phase. We have also been told by the Attorney that the next phase is a limited one.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to you that revealing the amount of money that has been allocated at this stage does not in any way indicate to Mr Skase or anyone else what resources the government can put into the chase. It only indicates what resources we are putting in at this particular moment.

I also refer you to quite a number of occasions during the term of the previous government when spokespeople on your side sought and demanded as a right information of a similar nature, even in respect of the Skase matter.

I think this argument of `we won't tell you because we do not want to tell Mr Skase how serious we are' is a disingenuous one. You do not have to indicate all the cards in your pack at this particular stage. The Australian public deserves to know how serious this government is and what resources you are putting in at the moment. That is something they do not know.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I really cannot take this any further, suffice to say that the Attorney-General is pursuing this with vigour. Mr Donnelly has been provided with extra resources. I do not think there is any precedent during the time that this government has been in office where it has divulged details which can prejudice any ongoing litigation. That is as far as I can take it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not asking for details of any investigation. I am not asking for details of whether the AFP has been brought back into the action. I am not asking for details of what further action is proposed by Mr Donnelly or by the Commonwealth. I am asking: as a reflection of how dinkum you are about chasing Skase, what money are you putting in now?

SPEECH.PARA: How can you say that this Attorney-General is very actively pursuing Mr Skase when we are talking about from the end of August, start of September, to about 9 October to actually appraise himself of the fact that his department was taking no action in this matter? That is not a sign of activity; it is a sign of inactivity, which ranks with the inactivity of former Attorney-General Durack before the Costigan royal commission blew up, when he kept files in his bottom drawer for some four, five or six years. You cannot say that this Attorney-General has been actively pursuing Christopher Skase when he went to sleep for two months at the wheel.

That is one reason why the opposition is concerned about how much money you are putting into it. We are not asking for operational details. We are not asking whether people are chasing Skase internationally. We just want to know how serious you are. The best way of appreciating that and the best way of appraising how serious this government is about chasing Skase is to get an idea of how much money you are putting into it now. We recognise, for instance, that this is one part of the investigation and there could be further parts following.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —This has nothing to do with the debate. We are talking about streamlining provisions in bankruptcy law and implementing measures which would make ITSA more efficient in cost recovery. That has nothing to do with the Skase matter. If the good senator is going to persist with this line, I simply have nothing further to say. I believe we should get on with the amendments you are proposing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —This Skase matter goes to the heart of bankruptcy administration. This is the highest profile matter affecting bankruptcy in this country. We are dealing here with bankruptcy laws. You may duck, you may weave and you may not want to give us the facts. The Attorney-General is hiding behind this code of secrecy. Do you not feel as if there should be some degree of accountability of the executive of the parliament when you are spending money? You are actually spending taxpayers' money, no matter how little the government is putting into the chase for Skase.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought, apart from direct operational details and security matters—this is neither of those two—that there is a responsibility on the government to tell the parliament how much money has been allocated here. Do not duck and weave and say that this has no relevance to the bankruptcy law. This goes to the heart of the administration of bankruptcy law. I ask the parliamentary secretary: do you anticipate a time when you will be able to tell us how much money has been allocated to chasing Skase?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The time at which the expenditure will be available to the opposition and the public will be at the conclusion of this matter and not before.

—The matter is not concluded as yet, but we do know that some $800,000 was spent by the previous government in pursuing Skase. That information was made available before the matter was concluded. Are you telling us now that there will not even be an interim revelation of how much resource has been put into this next stage? Is that what we are being asked to cop at this particular stage?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I did not know better, Senator Bolkus, I would swear you were in the employ of Christopher Skases's solicitors. Quite frankly, that is an—

—On a point of order: I think that inference is not only unparliamentary but also undignified for Senator Ellison to make. I take offence at it. He knows very well that I am not in the employ of Skase. He also knows that we are not just serious about trying to pursue Mr Skase, but that we are also trying to keep the government honest in terms of chasing Skase. I take offence at the imputation and the direct allegation made by Senator Ellison.

—I do not think Senator Ellison actually used those words, but if you took offence, Senator Bolkus, the normal course of events in the Senate is to ask the honourable senator to withdraw the remark. I will ask the parliamentary secretary if he will do that.

—I think this is the first time in my time in this chamber I have been asked to withdraw a remark, and I will do that, because I did not infer that you were in the employ. But I must say, Senator Bolkus, that what you are seeking to do could only advantage the case for Christopher Skase and his legal advisers.
—Do you deny, Senator Ellison, that the public already does know, although the matter has not been completed, that some $800,000 has been spent by the government in chasing Skase? Do you deny that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —That figure has been made public; we are looking at the conduct of this case in the future. That related to a different stage of proceedings entirely. It was a discrete matter in the running of this matter, and that is what it relates to. I do not deny that that was made public—it was. But we are talking about where we are at and where this case is going. We are not going to divulge any details.

—Will you also acknowledge that I am not asking you to give a commitment as to how much money will or will not be spent in the future on the chase of Skase; that I am not asking for an indication of what the government might do in pursuing Skase in the future?
—I can't take it any further, Mr Chairman.

—I find this totally unacceptable. I understand the difficult situation in which Senator Ellison has been put by the Attorney‐General's stubbornness and desire that what he is doing in relation to this matter not be seen. It is something that we have grown used to in respect of this Attorney‐General. I do say, Senator Ellison, that I know you are in a difficult position. But I also indicate that the public does have a right to know how serious the government is. We will keep pursuing this at a later stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary Secretary, I advise you that the Australian Democrats will support every effort the government makes to continue to pursue this matter. I think possibly we should look for some assistance in the matter of charges and moneys to be expended in this area. Although Senator Bolkus may be considered to be drawing a long bow in his particular line of questioning, my view is he hits such a fundamentally important public interest area that it is appropriate for those issues to be raised here.

SPEECH.PARA: I think one of the things that we need in terms of public information and accountability is better and more frequent information on the progress of these matters. I think that would help considerably. Being forced to wait for debates like these or for estimates committees or having to put questions up, it is probably very useful for regular updates and briefings to substitute for information from the Attorney‐General.

I would like to ask you, Parliamentary Secretary, what government policy is in this regard. There has to be, in my view, some penalty for all those who make these things possible. As you know, during my speech at the second reading stage I mentioned that auditors, bankers, accountants and lawyers have either been dilatory in their supervision of the affairs of high profile bankrupts or are accomplices. Although sometimes they can evade the law, the question is whether they should be exposed. The other question is whether governments—your government—will continue to do business with lawyers, auditors, bankers and accountants who have been party to the shenanigans of the Skases and Bonds of this world. I would like a response on that.
The second thing I would indicate is that an article on the front page of the West Australian on Friday, 28 February, said:

Mr Bollag will be examined under oath for a week in the Swiss district of Zug, near Zurich, in April as part of Operation Oxide—an Australian Federal Police investigation into whether Bond hid assets from his creditors and perjured himself while he was bankrupt between 1992 and 1995.

I think that sort of activity by the AFP, with the support of the government, is something to be proud of. I would commend your government in announcing as soon as you can the consequences of that inquiry in April. I would appreciate your confirmation that you will keep us briefed on that.

The third point I want to make—I will wrap all my points up in this sense—is that I am very conscious of the remarks made by both Senator Ellison and Senator Cooney that we must be at pains to ensure that bankruptcy law continues to look after those who have merely fallen honourably into hard times. The government's cognisance of that is noted, and I respect that response.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murray for his support in relation to the matters he mentions. I take it that what he is getting at with respect to dealing with accomplices and people who have been guilty of offences is whether the Commonwealth would brief those sorts of people and provide them with work; is that right?

—Just to make sure you understand: my view is that, although those people may not have been convicted in any court or found guilty, it is unwise and inappropriate for government to continue to provide them with work if they can avoid it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government always approaches the provision of work to the private sector with caution, particularly where professionals are involved. But, then again, the government has to be careful not to pre-judge matters because it might be an unfair judgment. But I take the point Senator Murray makes and I will raise it with the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) and bring Senator Murray's concerns to his attention.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the last point Senator Murray made, the debt agreements which I mentioned earlier cover the situation that Senator Cooney mentioned in relation to those smaller estates which usually do involve small businessmen and people who have fallen on hard times not necessarily through their own fault. In those sorts of situations they can avoid the burden of bankruptcy as such but, nonetheless, there is still security offered to creditors. So the debt agreement situation, I think, takes care of that.
With respect to the other matter that was raised relating to the Federal Police, I will undertake to take that up with the Attorney and get back to the senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have amendments that have been circulated in my name. They read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 1 (line 15), omit "Subject to subsections (2), (3) and (4), this", substitute "This".
(2) Clause 2, page 1 (line 17) to page 2 (line 10), omit subclauses (2), (3) and (4).
(3) Schedule 1, item 13, page 4 (line 18) to page 5 (line 11), TO BE OPPOSED .
(4) Schedule 1, item 20, page 6 (line 6) to page 11 (line 17), TO BE OPPOSED .

I explained earlier the objective of these amendments. I do not need to rehash that debate but I do indicate at this stage that we do have concerns with provisions in the charges and that, although we will put these amendments, in recognition of the fact that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting these amendments we will not be forcing this to a vote. But we will be expressing our opposition to particular clauses as embodied in the amendments I have circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me by looking at the amendments that it might be worthwhile to take amendments 1 and 2 together because 3, 4 and 5 are opposing clauses. Would that be satisfactory to you?
—You can take them all together if you like.
—If I may assist you, we will oppose all five, so they may as well be taken together.
—With respect, I think Senator Murray makes a useful suggestion. Perhaps it could save time if all five are taken together.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —If you will assist the chair, I would like to put 1 and 2 together.

(2) Clause 2, page 1 (line 17) to page 2 (line 10), omit subclauses (2), (3) and (4).

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I put the question that the bills be reported, I want to make a statement that I understand that the parliamentary secretary was a little taken aback earlier when I asked that certain comments be withdrawn. I checked with the clerk and it is the convention in the Senate that, if an honourable senator objects to a remark, the person who made that remark is asked to withdraw it. In doing that I was following the convention. I was not making any judgment on whether the remark was unparliamentary or otherwise.

That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senator BOB COLLINS

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition have no objections at all to the central provisions of the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill; indeed, we have never had. But one could fairly ask, with all of the huffing and puffing that has been going on over the last six months by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) over the issue of the alleged lack of proper experience and qualifications of the CASA board, why this legislation has been hanging around for as long as it has been. It was introduced into the House of Representatives in June last year and it was entirely open to the government, in terms of managing its program, to have this legislation brought on far before this.

SPEECH.PARA: One really does have to pose the questions: with all of the high profile that has been given to this, why has this piece of legislation, for no good reason that we can see, been lying around for months and why has it not been given some priority up the pecking order in terms of legislation in this house and been dealt with before now? Mr Sharp could have had his opportunity, as far as the opposition are concerned, to have made these additional appointments a long time ago. The reason one has to pose those questions is to question the bona fides of the government on this issue and in particular to question the bona fides of the minister in this over-the-top campaign that he has been running against the board members of CASA and in particular the strident and indeed reckless criticisms that the minister has engaged upon recently of that board.

One criticism in particular deserves mention. I was extremely angry when, driving along, I first heard it on the car radio. I thought, `The minister really has lost his marbles completely in terms of his pursuit of the CASA board on this one.' He said very specifically that the board had not discharged its proper responsibilities and therefore deserved the sack in respect of the DC3 incident, which of course I personally recall only too well. The federal minister for transport said that the board of CASA deserved the sack because the board had failed to prosecute the people involved in that DC3 incident.

It was with utter disbelief that I heard that statement. That was a reckless statement by the minister and the minister in fact should have had his backside firmly kicked afterwards by his colleagues for overreaching himself and for going over the top. The board of CASA does not prosecute anyone; neither did the CAA. Indeed I have no doubt that Senator Ellison, who is in the chamber at the moment, would be perfectly well aware of the point that I am making. The CAA has never been responsible for prosecutions. The statutory responsibility for that job rests with the Director of Public Prosecutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —And rightly so.

—And rightly so, and always has. The fact, which the minister did not even bother to regard in his reckless attacks on this board, was that CASA discharged all of its statutory responsibilities in respect of this incident as it happened. It did forward all of the necessary briefs to the appropriate authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Director of Public Prosecutions, no doubt in an entirely proper way, determined that it was not in the public interest to prosecute. There was a Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report published on this incident. The DPP reviewed that decision after the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation completed its report and on that review determined again that there would be no prosecution in the public interest. That was a decision, entirely properly, of the Director of Public Prosecutions. Any complaints or concerns about the failure to prosecute on the matter should therefore be directed to the federal Attorney-General (Mr Williams) by his colleague the minister for transport.

But that was a glaring and transparent demonstration publicly of how utterly irrational and how utterly insupportable this minister's campaign against the current board has been. He really exposed himself profoundly with that ignorant and improper attack on the board. It was then—in terms of the tit for tat that has been going on with respect to the utterly destabilising nature of this paper and public war with the minister—that the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority responded, as he had to, to point out the facts in the matter and that the minister was utterly wrong in respect of his criticism of the board in failing to prosecute the people involved in the DC3 incident.

Having said that, one then only has to make a reference to the minister's own public explanation last year as to why he wanted the original board to quit. It is worth while revisiting that extraordinary statement, which I think the minister himself conceded afterwards—to paraphrase what he said—was not his best performance. When he was originally suggesting that the board should go, that was at a time when, so far as he was concerned as minister, the board had not had an opportunity to demonstrate whether or not it was competent at all. Indeed, the Monarch incident and all the rest of it that the minister and the rest of us were so concerned about all predated this board. What explanation did the minister give publicly for why he wanted the board to go originally? Let me remind the Senate. The reason the minister wanted the board to go was: `I have obligations to other people.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?
—Precisely. That is what the minister said last year.
—But who's he got the obligations to?
—That is a matter I guess that is open to speculation. But what an extraordinarily stupid statement for the minister to make.
—He meant the Australian people.

—Oh, lawyers. There is no doubt about lawyers. I certainly want to respond to have that slippery interjection incorporated in the Hansard . `He was referring to the Australian people'—it takes a lawyer to come up with an explanation like that.

SPEECH.PARA: The reference to `other people' was meant in the ordinary sense, not the lawyer sense—in the sense of ordinary people like me—that is, the obligations he had to other people whom he wanted to put on the board. That is what he meant and that is what he said.

All of this over-the-top breast beating, allegedly in pursuit of better safety, has been a sham from then until now. The minister started this campaign by admitting publicly that the reason he wanted to get rid of the board was to put other people on the board. He topped it off just recently with that over-the-top nonsensical attack on the board for failing to prosecute the DC3 people when he should have known as federal transport minister that that board and no other board has ever had the responsibility for prosecuting and that on this occasion the management of the CAA did everything that was required of them under the act and forwarded those briefs to the DPP, which then determined twice that there would be no prosecution.

BREAK.PARA: That raises the important question of what is the function of a board of a statutory authority. The function of the board—and I want to disabuse the sort of atmosphere that has been created in the community on this—is not to go out and inspect aircraft. The board does not go out and test pilots. The board does not do ramp checks on aircraft. What the board does is ensure that the organisation that does do all these things does it effectively and efficiently and does it in accordance with the statutory obligations that the organisation has under the act. That is the test of the board.

I might add in respect of that issue, they have on the board in an ex officio capacity the chief executive of the organisation, Leroy Keith. One would forgive him at the moment, while all of this nonsense is being thrown about by the minister and the government, for keeping his head down and not expressing a personal view about any member of the board or the management.

I do not hesitate to say that I have high regard for Leroy Keith. I am familiar with his background and his expertise. I am familiar with the job he is currently doing at CASA. I am familiar with the professionalism that he has brought to the Senate committees that he has an obligation to respond to in respect of questions asked. I think Leroy Keith is an effective and competent chief executive of CASA. He is particularly in charge of the ramp checks, the aircraft checks and all the other things that the organisation has to do. He is on the board of CASA and that advice is immediately available to the board when they want it.

In respect of the intemperate and insupportable criticisms that have been made of this board, I want to refer to one other issue that needs to be canvassed—that is, Dr Clare Pollock. I do that I guess to appeal to the people who are reporting this entire affair. Dr Pollock has been lumped in with a general description of people who have no particular expertise in aviation.

Anyone who knows anything about aircraft accidents knows that one of the major causes, if not the major cause, of aircraft accidents is the human failure—generically referred to as pilot error—and the systems failures. We have so few aircraft accidents relatively speaking and flying is still far and away the safest mode of transport in the world because one of the things that marks out aviation disasters is that they are rarely caused by one or two things going wrong; they are usually caused by a whole sequence of events going wrong and then the odds shorten and shorten. It is when seven, eight, 10 or 15 things go wrong at the wrong time and at the wrong place that you have an accident.

One of the principal skills required by the investigators at the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation are professional skills in systems failure. That is exactly what Dr Clare Pollock is an internationally recognised expert in. She is a systems failure expert. She has absolutely critical qualifications that are absolutely relevant to the job of being on that board.

On a personal level, I think it is about time somebody laid out fairly and clearly that she is one of the more highly qualified aviation experts on that board. I am sick and tired of the constant criticisms of her that she has no qualifications—something, I regret to say, that has simply been picked up and run unquestioningly by a number of journalists. I want to lay that down now. If you want to make that criticism of members of the board, please do not make it continually of Dr Clare Pollock.

Should the board be comprised entirely of aviation experts? Of course it should not. That board, like any other board, needs a mix—the proper mix—of generalists and specialists on the board. Is it more important, for example, to have as the chair of the board an expert in aviation safety who may be a lousy administrator, or a professional administrator who is intelligent enough to be able to hear what is being said to him by the experts on the board, in particular by Leroy Keith, about those technical matters?

I make absolutely no bones about my view on the issue. It is far better in my view to have an expert administrator in that position rather than somebody who has a degree in aviation engineering and may, therefore, only be an expert in that particular part of the aviation industry in which they are qualified.

If you can have the best of all worlds—which is what you look for when you are appointing people—and find somebody who has a degree in law, a degree in aviation engineering, a commercial pilot's licence and everything else, that is fine. But you find a person like that. I could not when I was minister for transport. They are as scarce as hen's teeth.

There is another difficult and proper problem that needs to be considered in terms of conflict of interests. That is, in drawing people from the aviation industry, you need to be very careful that the particular part of the aviation industry they come from is not then unfairly represented by them on the board. Who is as concerned about this as anyone else? The minister, of course, because the minister has gone on the public record attacking the Civil Aviation Authority for his concerns that their employees may have a conflict of interest in respect of companies they may have previously worked for.

That is a proper concern too, but where else does the safety regulator get the test pilots and the check and training captains it needs, if not from the industry? Of course, that is where they must come from. It is simply then a question of ensuring that there is proper process and proper regard given so they do not get an opportunity to be in a conflict of interest—as much for their sake as for the safety of air regulation, I might add. If, for example, a particular person is drawn from a particular company and goes to work for the CAA, it is a sensible prohibition to ensure that that person is not directly involved in any decisions that involve the company they worked for or, if they are, that they are only in such a position as part of a group of people who are engaged in the same exercise and scrutinising that overview.

We have the minister on the public record expressing his concern about that conflict of interest. That same problem applies to board appointments. You have to be careful that you do not take people from companies in which they may exercise some improper role afterwards. That is one of the reasons why you often look for people who are retired from direct involvement with companies. That is why when I was transport minister, by extraordinary coincidence, I did appoint on one occasion two brothers to the board, one who had been a senior check and training captain with Ansett and the other who had followed an almost exactly parallel career path with TAA—not something you would find every day of the week.
It is difficult to find people who have all of the necessary skills, do not have the conflicts of interest, will properly discharge the functions and so on. It is not altogether an easy task.

In expressing again the same support we expressed for this legislation in June last year—and wondering why it has not been brought on before now if the minister wanted to appoint these two people—I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate is of the view that:

(a) given the statutory responsibility of the Board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) in setting the overall strategic direction for CASA and ensuring that the Authority functions in a proper, efficient and effective manner, it is appropriate that the Board should include members with backgrounds such as the law, regulation, general safety and consumer advocacy, as well as members with specific expertise in aviation;

(b) since members of the CASA Board are appointed as independent directors of a statutory authority, they are entitled to perform their functions and complete their terms of office in accordance with the Civil Aviation Act 1988 , unless incompetence or impropriety can be proved against them; and

(c) to maximise public confidence in aviation safety in Australia, the Minister should ensure that there are no potential conflicts of interest created by new appointments, by not appointing to the Board any person who has recently engaged in political lobbying or public advocacy on aviation issues on behalf of any company or interest group involved in the aviation industry;

and notes that the protestations of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) about the urgency of reconstituting the CASA Board are at odds with the fact that this bill has languished on the Notice Paper since its introduction to the Senate on 28 June 1996.

The amendment is self‐explanatory. I would simply draw the attention of the Senate to paragraphs (b) and (c) from that amendment, which are critical to it. Paragraph (b) is to ensure that the kind of political shenanigans that the minister is engaged in—and they have nothing to do with aviation safety, and we know it—do not occur.

The final paragraph (c) takes a commonsense position. Given the government's assertions on the public record, there is absolutely no logical reason why the government cannot support all of this second reading amendment. There is nothing in it which, firstly, is exceptional or, secondly, is in conflict with anything the government has said publicly on this matter. Indeed, every single paragraph supports the minister's assertions on the question of aviation safety and commonsense approaches to the appointment of board members. I look forward to getting the support of the Senate, including the government members of the Senate, for this second reading amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was listening to Senator Bob Collins's contribution, I was thinking of parallel examples of boards. If you had a board whose role was to look at health or safety issues of nicotine and smoking, would it be sensible to suggest that that should only be made up of smokers? If you had a board looking at the impacts of alcohol abuse, would you suggest that it is appropriate that it should only be made up of drinkers? If you had a superannuation board, is there any suggestion that it is right or proper that it should only be made up of pensioners or superannuants?

SPEECH.PARA: The question follows: is it proper or are you likely to get a reasonable result if those who are to be regulated end up being the only ones who are directed towards being on the board? The answer quite clearly is no. If you do such a thing you are likely to get a skewed result right from the beginning.

Aviation safety is not just about pilots. Air safety is about the public—the public who fly, the public who are underneath air paths and the relatives of people in many different circumstances—and about the confidence people can have in an industry which is so vital to a country like Australia.

This bill unfortunately is yet another sad episode of the tragic tale of civil aviation in this country. The continuing tragedy has been played out in a political forum that seems to have little concern for the safety of the public who travel by air in this country, despite the rhetoric to the contrary.

There is also another example of the problems we will continue to face in Australia as we push for further deregulation and cost recovery, and lose further control of regulatory bodies. The message from the government and, to that extent, the opposition is clear: that we do not need enforceable regulation or regulation as we may have had it in the past; that competitive forces will force companies to maintain proper standards in areas such as safety. To my mind, this approach is naive in the extreme. It leaves the consumer open to massive risk in relation to safety and environmental standards, and so on.

The reality is that, in areas such as aviation, we do need to regulate to ensure that the highest levels of safety are maintained. This is where we need to have properly established and accountable regulatory bodies, such as the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The farcical situation that has arisen with CASA over recent months is a direct result of the politicisation of that body and the failure to have proper procedures and qualifications in place in relation to its board.

In that regard, I am pleased to see that Senator Murray has proposed some amendments that address some aspects of my concerns. I believe that his proposal in relation to such issues as the qualifications of the board, merit as a basis for appointment, a limit to the number of terms that a board member can serve and the independence of the board is laudable. The Greens will be supporting his amendment to that effect during the committee stage of the bill.

The CASA board should not have been placed in the position in which it has found itself in recent times. I believe that the reforms proposed by Senator Murray, which I believe are consistent with the Nolan commit tee report from the United Kingdom parliament, will go a long way towards avoiding this sort of debacle in the future.

It is extremely important that we deal with this issue without this level of politicisation. At the moment I have some concerns about the proposal for the second reading amendment, and those concerns relate to lobbying. Lobbying can be many different things. People can lobby for very good reasons in relation to civil aviation safety.

I do not know—perhaps Senator Collins could advise me—whether there is some precedent for this; I would be happy to hear about that when it comes up—whether the fact that someone has spoken up or tried to change things in the past in relation to aviation safety should immediately bar them from participation on the board. That perhaps might mean in the future that anyone who has kept their mouth shut becomes eligible for a board and that there will be some sort of witch‐hunt in relation to whether or not anyone who has ever expressed an opinion has been classified as a lobbyist.

That is my reservation. It might be a `this means you, Dick Smith' amendment. But before I commit to whether or not we would be able to support it as a second reading amendment, I would like to see some more rationalisation for it when we come to the committee stage. But I shall leave that for further into the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to take a few minutes to speak in support of the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 1996. The purpose of this bill is quite simple, and it is outlined in items 3 and 4 of the schedule of the bill. These items amend section 33 of the principal act to provide for a deputy chairman to be appointed to the board of CASA. In addition, the maximum number of members who may be appointed is increased from three to four.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, you would be aware that I have had a great interest, a long and abiding interest in aviation. I have spoken on it on many occasions. It comes from an association of over 30 years as an aircraft owner and pilot and someone considerably involved in the maintenance of those aircraft also. I think I have a broad view of the whole of the field. In my time here, as Senator Collins will aver, I have played no political favourites on this. I have been as critical of my own side of politics as I have been of the Labor Party of actions that have been taken that I think are contrary to the best interests of the nation and the aviation industry.

I rise to support this bill, not for any political reasons but because I believe the quality of the Civil Aviation Authority can be improved. We really do need the very best people we can get on the board of that authority because it is an enormously important field. It involves the lives of so many Australians and the commercial wellbeing of the country. All of us in the parliament are accountable to the community for aviation safety in so far as we have an influence on the legislation that goes through the parliament. And it is beholden on those of us who have an interest to speak in order to try to obtain the best results for the community that we can.

The catalyst for this body, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, was the disastrous accidents to two commuter airlines, Monarch and Seaview, in the immediate past. They led to the dissolution of the old Civil Aviation Authority—and it was not really an old authority as it had replaced the department of transport which, in turn, had overtaken the Department of Civil Aviation which had existed for many years. I think many of the changes administratively that the regulatory authority has suffered have contributed to the malaise within the industry because there has been very little stability and very little predictability in the careers of people. We have lost a lot of very capable professionals in the last 10 to 20 years from the regulatory authority that we simply could not afford to lose. I have a view that all those changes were rather precipitate—that they were the response to pressures of the time, both in relation to incidents within the industry and economic policies.

I have spoken on many occasions about the economic rationalism of the Labor Party and the way they applied, inappropriately, a user‐ pays doctrine to aviation and how, in that process, they completely overlooked the public interest in having a safe and effective regulatory authority to provide safe commerce for people and for freight within Australia, and the great contribution that makes to Australia's economic wellbeing.

I am not averse to the proposition, for example, that we disband the CASA, the Federal Airports Corporation and Airservices Australia and go back to an organisation which would be a department of state—such as the old Department of Civil Aviation. I would not want it to go back to the way the old DCA operated 10 or 20 years ago, but I think the public interest is so substantial in this area that there is a valid case to have a department of state where the parliament has direct responsibility for the actions of that department rather than the indirect pathways we have of setting up a series of government business enterprises at arms‐length from the government in the form of the CASA and the FAC. But that is a diversion for the moment.

I return to the point that the genesis of CASA was the tragic accidents that we experienced in the last few years with Monarch and Seaview. As a result of that, CASA was set up. When parliament approved the legislation to set up CASA, there was never any belief in the parliament that those who were appointed to the CASA board would not be people who had a great professional interest in and experience in aviation or cognate subjects.

There was some surprise when people who had no apparent connection at all with aviation were appointed to that board. I have a bit of a liberal view about this.
