I think boards do have to represent wider interests rather than very narrow technical ones, for the very good reason that boards of organisations do not involve themselves in day-to-day running matters. The board does not, of itself, dictate the minutiae of how an organisation operates. That is left for the managing director or, in the case of CASA, for the chief executive officer.

The board of any organisation should look to the future and should lay down broad principles and policies which the employees of that organisation should follow and work to. The actual composition of the board, in not having 100 per cent aviation experience on it, is not a great concern to me, but it is a concern when pretty well everyone on the board except for one member had no previous contact with aviation.

I have been a very strong critic of the actions of the Civil Aviation Authority and CASA in the past where they have not performed as well as they should have. But, having said that, in all fairness I have to say that, in the short life of CASA, they have made some improvements. They might not have moved as rapidly, as far or as fast as they should have, but I think the board of CASA have honestly tried to tackle the great problems that beset them in the regulatory field. I think that ought to be put on the public record.

This amendment will allow for additional members to the board of CASA. I would like to deal with the membership of the board of CASA, because it has been a matter of considerable public debate over the last few months. There is a need to have some members on that board who really have a handle on and a deep knowledge of aviation safety matters. This is not a field for well meaning amateurs to be involved in. You need people with a range of interests. You need people who have experience in the commercial world, because, at the end of the day, aviation is a commercial activity.

The overall economic value of aviation in Australia probably runs into billions, and the regulatory authority has to recognise that aviation operates in an economic environment. Therefore, you have to have people on the board who have sound business and commercial experience. You have to have people who represent the interests of the consumer—whether they are using the airlines to carry freight or the millions of people who fly on the airlines in Australia each year. Their interests have to be represented.

But at the heart of CASA is this business of aviation safety. As someone who has been involved in aviation for a very long time in a practical sense, I would not pretend to hold myself out as competent to sit on that board in a safety role. I think the sort of person you need for that is someone who has had a very extensive flying experience, probably someone who has been a qualified test pilot—that is the level of expertise that I think is appropriate—combined with experience of executive control of safety matters in a large organisation. There is a big difference between applying safety at a personal level and trying to enforce safety across an industry or across a nation. I believe we need somebody on the board with those qualifications.

I have never been too keen on service personnel—army and air force officers or pilots—getting into the Civil Aviation Authority, because often they have not had the requisite commercial experience and take a rather scholarly or unworldly view to operations of aviation in a commercial sense. Regrettably, some of the people who apply from the services and who have had employment in the Civil Aviation Authority, or its predecessors, in the past have not been the very best of service pilots.

In a case like this, I think you can only go to a former senior air force officer to provide that safety oversight. There is no opportunity in private or commercial aviation for people to go through things like the Naval Test Pilot School in the United States, the test pilots school at Edwards Air Force Base for the USAF or the Empire Test Pilot School in the United Kingdom. Those opportunities are just not available to civilian pilots.

While airlines such as Qantas and Ansett have an intensive safety program, they are always within the boundaries of that company themselves. It is really only in an organisation such as the air force that you have somebody who can get experience across the whole ambit of dealing with a large organisation and putting safety practices in place. I think someone with that experience is absolutely vital to have on the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.
With those few words, I wish this bill a speedy passage. The only point I would like to comment on is Senator Collins's amendments to the bill. In subsection (a), he says:
. . . the board should include members with backgrounds such as the law, regulation, general safety and consumer advocacy, as well as members with specific expertise in aviation.
I think that `general safety' ought to read `aviation safety'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak briefly on the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 1996. In doing so, I think the first thing that one needs to highlight is that in recent times we have heard a lot of trumpeting by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) and huge indignation about the activities of the CASA board. One would have thought, from reading and listening to the minister, that the CASA board was ignorant, illiterate and totally incompetent.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things the minister has recently been going on about has been the Falcon crash in Queensland. There have been lots of allegations about the incompetence of the CASA board and how they did not handle that correctly. We finally had the Wheelahan report tabled yesterday, which confirms that the CASA board had not done anything wrong. There were some things to answer, possibly on behalf of a CASA employee, but the CASA board had not done anything wrong. In relation to the employee, it stated that it was unclear whether any conflict of interest had arisen from the employment of that employee. The report concludes that there are some deficiencies in their new conflict of interest rules—and I understand that CASA is keen to correct that—but there is no criticism of the CASA board.

The report does, however, criticise the minister. The Wheelahan report is a report that the minister commissioned because he wanted to get the CASA board. His own report got him, because it criticises the minister for taking three months to reply to a letter in which queries about the safety of Falcon Airlines were raised. It also criticises the contents of the minister's reply. This is a minister who did not understand that the DPP is the one which takes the prosecutions; he was criticising other people for being slow and tardy.

It appears from the Wheelahan report that the minister is the one who has been doing that sort of activity. It is a witch-hunt by the minister. It is the only way to describe it. He thinks he doth protest too much, because it is now 5 March 1997—

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost the ides of March.
—Yes, it is almost the ides of March, and the minister may well rue the ides of March.
—That's nearly a fortnight off!

—Yes. He may well rue that, because he has been protesting about the CASA board almost since the day he became the minister. In fact, when he was the shadow minister, he was protesting. He has now had over 12 months—more than a third of their term of government—to do something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister acted fairly quickly. I think he got this bill into the House in late May last year. It has been in the Senate since 28 June. Since 28 June, what have we seen? We have seen the minister trailing around this countryside, belting the CASA board around the ears for all he is worth, indulging in every criticism that he could possibly dredge up. We have even had the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) in this place describe one of the CASA board members as a welcome adornment to one of his boards that he might put her on. The minister has obviously not read the full meaning of the word `adornment', because it does relate to ornaments and things that beautify.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody's ever accused me of that!

—No, Senator. I do not think anybody has, and nobody would accuse the parliamentary secretary of that either. That is the sort of criticism that it has gotten down to—denigrating people because it is assumed that they will just beautify a board. I think that is a fairly disgusting sort of comment for the minister to make.
—Did you read Ian Warden on that?

—Ian Warden also could not be described as beautifying much, could he? He is not actually Mr Universe—with all due respect, Ian. Again, I think Ian should go and read the full meaning of the word `adornment', not `ornament'. I think this is a much more serious issue than that, and I will stop digressing.

SPEECH.PARA: What these attacks have done and what this tardiness on the part of the minister has done have, I fear, at least the potential to erode the confidence of the flying public in the safety of airline travel, and I think it probably has. That is of great concern. We saw comments last week in the press by James Strong from Qantas expressing concern about any erosion in confidence in airline travel and in airline safety. Qantas and Ansett have a world reputation in airline safety, as do a lot of other airlines in this country. The smaller airlines have been the ones that have gotten into trouble. It is the CASA board and the CASA authority that have been involved in monitoring that and in rectifying it.

When I say that there have been some airlines in regional areas of Australia that have gotten into trouble, there are also a lot of other airlines out there who are running very competent, very good services but they are running them in smaller aircraft. They are running them in nine seaters or 18 or 19 seaters.

Qantas and Ansett can possibly withstand, without too much problem at all, the drop in passenger numbers of one or two passengers per flight but those smaller regional commuter airlines could not stand a drop of one or two passengers per flight because that goes immediately to their viability. These are good, reliable airlines. I fly them all the time. I fly with them more than I fly with the majors and so do a lot of other senators here. We know they are good, competent safe airlines, but I do not want to see the confidence in those services that those airlines provide eroded falsely due to the minister being out on a witch‐hunt after the CASA board because he wants to appoint his own people.

This bill will enable him to appoint two more people to the board. He has had this bill on the Senate Notice Paper since 28 June last year and for seven or eight months the government has done nothing about introduc ing it. It just highlights the action of the minister as being nothing more than a witch‐hunt, being nothing more than a vendetta against individual people. But while he is conducting that vendetta I want to know and I want assurance from him that he is not doing anything which is going to undermine confidence in the airline industry.

This is a very important industry to Australia. Many, many people in this country rely upon commuter and regional airlines for their transport methods. Yet the minister's actions have undermined confidence in the industry. We have heard that concern expressed publicly, as I say, by the chief executive of Qantas. This is something that is of grave concern to me. The minister has been tardy in ensuring the introduction of this legislation into the Senate. I think tardy is a fairly polite word to use here. But it has not stopped him from conducting this witch‐hunt, and this witch‐hunt is something he should be condemned most roundly for undertaking.

As I say, I do not want to see him, as a consequence of his deliberate act of conducting this witch‐hunt—and it is a deliberate act on his part to conduct this witch‐hunt—forcing or placing in jeopardy the viability of some of these smaller regional commuter airlines. As I say, if you are operating a five or six seater or even a nine seater or a 19 or 36 seater, the drop of one or two passengers has a huge impact upon your industry and your business. That then gets into consequential flow‐on effects of whether you are able to afford to fulfil your safety commitments.

Anybody who is going to fly will of course fulfil their safety commitments but it will place extra stress and pressure on that airline. Often the principal of the airline is still involved in active flying. As Senator Collins said, pressure is one of the things that does add to the stress and strains in this industry and can actually add to accident rates. If any of these things happen they can be traced back to the deliberate actions of the minister. I think he is to be condemned for this.

We have also seen the politicisation of this. We have seen one or two individuals, who have very close links to the coalition and who make significant donations to the coalition, take a very high public political stance on this. The amendment that the opposition is moving is designed to remove the possibility of people basically buying their way on to these sorts of boards. That is of grave concern.

I repeat: the minister is to stand condemned for his witch‐hunt of the CASA board when the Wheelahan report criticises him rather than the board. He is to be condemned for any erosion in confidence of airline safety in this country and the potential impacts and consequences that this may have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is a most important debate on the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 1996 because it does not just go to the heart of a very political issue; it goes to the heart of probity and accountability in government and the boards which government appoints generally. In the defence and attack on this board lies the very heart of how this government will approach the defence and attack of all the boards within their power. It is very important, I think, that the Senate gives this government a message as to how we want to pursue these issues of board appointments in general. It is not for nothing that it has been an issue which has provoked extreme public and media debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I must begin my speech by indicating that with regard to this issue I do have some experience, and it is experience I shall draw on. I have, unlike many members of the Senate, extensive experience in the operation of boards. I have sat on many boards as a senior executive, as a shareholder and as a community person. I bring to that a view I have as to the way in which boards shall operate. I think some of the remarks of Senator Bob Collins were apposite in this respect.

I also bring some experience of aviation. The first experience was unfortunate, because I had many years of war service and had much to do with aeroplanes as a result. On the other side—which is also unfortunate because it gets to be a pain after a while—I have had decades of extensive air travel in all sorts of airlines, some of which I do not want to repeat.

BREAK.PARA: The government should know that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the CAA bill with amendments that we will put up. The purpose of that bill is to allow the Minister for Transport and Regional Development to appoint additional members to the CASA board. We do not seek to interfere with that right. It is useful to enlarge the board. Five members is too small a number to cover all the ground this board and any board needs to cover. It is also appropriate that the increase is to an odd number. A board of seven is not too large and boards in my view should always be composed of odd numbers so that you do not have split votes and do not force the chair into a casting vote position.

We will be moving a number of important amendments which have been overlooked in the debate so far and I will discuss these shortly. The background to this legislation unfortunately rests in the government's and minister's desire to fire the existing Labor appointed members of the board and to appoint Liberal appointees in their place. I have come to that conclusion reluctantly and I base that conclusion on the very unbalanced, biased and intemperate way in which this minister has pursued this issue.

This is a problem and we should address it. The idea that any Labor appointment is bad or any Liberal appointment is good is nonsense. Some Labor appointments from the previous government were undoubtedly bad and some Liberal appointments from this government will undoubtedly be found wanting. We cannot attack people simply on the basis of by whom they were appointed.

The minister has done himself a disservice in the way in which he has pursued his objectives, because the objectives pursued by anyone else would have been appropriate, namely that the board does need to be enlarged, its skills and qualifications do need to be examined and the important way in which it operates does need to be opened up to further debate and improvement.

This bill gives us the opportunity to decide what relevant expertise is needed and two things need to be said about this. Firstly, the minister's notion of what constitutes relevant expertise is awfully vague and may be mistaken. Secondly, even if he is correct in assuming that the members of the board—and I have never mastered whether he means all the members, some members or just one member—lack appropriate skills, the approach that he has taken in dealing with the current board has not in my opinion been a model approach. Should the minister be able to force members of the board to resign? The problem with having appointments based purely on ministerial discretion which can be terminated when governments change, is that it opens the way for political patronage and continues a dreadful and unacceptable precedent. The Australian Democrats have opposed, will continue to oppose and will beg you to oppose this process of political patronage.

It also conflicts with the notion of having a statutory authority which is independent and at arms‐length from government. If this minister or any other minister is able to sack board members of statutory authorities at their own discretion, how can their independence be guaranteed? Of course he has not been able to sack them. He has therefore attacked them and has made every other board that the government controls and all their members nervous as a result—nervous of their independence, nervous of their tenure and nervous of their ability to be independent and to speak out.

In the USA, which does not have a democratic system I admire, with each change of administration everyone appointed to such public posts tenders their resignation. This paves the way for the new President and his ministers to appoint a long list of mates to such boards. Patronage is therefore effectively built into the United States system on the basis of, `If you can't beat them, let's join them.' I do not believe such a situation is appropriate for the USA or is acceptable for them. It is certainly not appropriate for Australia. It is not a path we should continue down.

To some extent—and we are grateful to our predecessors in these various chambers—legislation has attempted to avoid overt executive control, unfettered executive discretion or unacceptable executive power. It is for this reason that the CAA does not allow the minister to replace the board at his discretion. That does not mean that board members cannot be removed and this is why the minister himself has arrived in the situation where his own judgment and pursuit of this matter has been discredited. Because the act does quite properly enable the minister to sack the board if their performance has been unsatisfactory for a period of time or if they are identifiably incompetent. He has that power.

To date all we have got the minister to really focus his answers on is to accuse the board of inexperience and a lack of variation of skills. But the minister has not presented the details of specific decisions or instances where this inexperience has led the board into mistakes of judgment which have put air safety materially at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because he can't.

—Exactly, nor has he been remotely persuasive in supporting his argument that the current board is inexperienced and is guilty of worsening our air safety regime and, fortunately, the media and political commentators in this area have been sharp enough to pursue him on those grounds.

BREAK.PARA: If the minister can demonstrate that the board's performance has been unsatisfactory, the relevant board member should be removed. The minister has not been able to make such a case; he has therefore left himself open to the strong allegation that political patronage is a major motive. I do not suggest for a moment that it is the only motive, because this bill does evidence some useful advances.

If his intention is simply to create job vacancies so he can appoint mates—which is the motive that has been imputed—then he should back off the existing board and concentrate on the board he can legitimately change after June 1997, when most of this board's term is up. I have not understood the attack on these persons when their term expires in a few months: it really is not an issue of immediacy.

If the minister cannot demonstrate that the board's performance has been substandard—and we are yet to see any solid evidence—he must cease playing political football with the board and trying to score points that do nothing to further his legitimate concern for air safety in this country. I draw your attention to the Falcon Airlines inquiry report, which was tabled at my request in a parliamentary return to order yesterday. That is an instance where publication of a particular inquiry report was suppressed for far too long, and that has probably damaged some innocent people as well as rightly focusing on some people who did need to be focused on.

What qualifications should board members have? The minister has repeatedly announced that both new appointees are to have practical aviation experience. Our suggestion is that the board should be viewed as a whole and that the minister's appointments should be looked at with a view to how that board should look after June and not how it should look after the passage of this bill.

Two things need to be said about practical aviation expertise. This requirement is not spelled out anywhere in the bill. I happen to agree that the board should include practical aviation experience but, if it is not spelled out in the bill, what happens if the next minister from another government or from another political party disagrees and appoints inappropriate people to the board? What it means is not spelled out anywhere else by anybody.

Let us ask some silly questions. Does `practical aviation' mean the board members must be licensed pilots, have experience in aviation catering, be air stewards or aeronautical engineers, or merely have worked for an airline company for a number of years? Must they be enthusiastic amateur pilots? Mention has been made of a well‐known one. Can it be interpreted to mean that they can be highly experienced aviation passengers, such as the parliamentary secretary and I? The very fact that it can mean almost anything reinforces the fact that, unfortunately, it means almost nothing and gives each minister undue discretion. The Democrats have endeavoured to spell out those qualifications which we think are appropriate.

I can anticipate the arguments that it fetters the minister, that it will be too prescriptive and all those sorts of things. We throw the challenge to you: we are quite happy for you to put appropriate amendments in. We have listened carefully to the comments from the minister and from numerous experienced commentators in both the electronic media and the press media, and we have put together a check list of the appropriate qualifications.

We have also used my own experience on boards and my understanding of what boards are required to do—and we will make comments on this in the committee stage—by including the range of skills essential for a board to have to operate effectively in a very complex environment. It is extremely fortunate that we have Senator Collins, with his invaluable experience as a member of the former government and as a former minister for transport, participating in the debate, because it will give some substance and depth to our understanding of this issue. He has rightly made the point that board skills have to cover more than just aviation safety.

We agree totally with the minister that the board members should be appropriately qualified. It is a most important admission by the minister, and an important advance in the debate. We would like to see all other ministers, and shadow ministers for that matter, acknowledge that all board members should be appropriately qualified.

We need to look at the board's role and functions, and then determine the individual and collective skills that need to be reflected. We have given this much thought. We strongly believe a broad mix of skills is needed because the board is not only responsible for deciding safety objectives, strategies and policies to be pursued; it is also responsible for overseeing the running of CASA—and that means workers compensation, employee contracts, legal liability, fiduciary duties, financial accounting. It means all the normal things that go with board operation. Our proposed amendments will therefore seek to ensure the requirement to appoint appropriately qualified individuals on the board and to ensure that those qualifications are clearly spelt out.

We have also tried to tackle the issue of independence. While the minister deplores the cool relationship that is presently said to exist between the industry and the regulator—although I can see a mutual respect, quite frankly, between the two in many of the utterances that are made—I fear that a swing too far in the opposite direction could be far worse. We do not want too warm a relationship, and the minister should be cognisant of that when he is dealing with the matter.

Parliamentary Secretary, I will scrupulously keep away from personalities in this debate. I will not get involved with partisanship as to who I think should or should not be on the board. Frankly, I do not know the persons who have been put up as board nominees or who have been lobbying my own office for inclusion well enough, in terms of their qualifications or lack of them, to even begin to enter that debate. And I believe—

TALK.START.PARA: —There has only been one. Tell the truth.
—There are several actually. I believe that we should approach this in terms of principle as much as we can and withdraw from the political stuff that has been going on in advance of this bill.

BREAK.PARA: Maintaining independence of the regulator from industry is imperative. The relationship between the regulator, whose primary duty is to protect fee‐paying customers, and the industry needs to be kept at arms‐length. Failure to do this could result in capture of the regulator by any industry or sector of industry. That would not be good for safety. I do not think anyone genuinely concerned about safety would disagree.

Having listened to the minister on many occasions, I am quite sure that the one thing he would absolutely hate to do is to appoint a board which would then oversee any detrimental situation of air safety which would rebound to his discredit. He must ensure that he and the board are at arms‐length from each other. For this reason, the Democrats will be moving an amendment designed to minimise the possibility of capture by any particular person or organisation.

I think it is important to note that the Democrats welcome the current review into the role of CASA and the civil aviation safety regulations and the input that industry organisations are making. Some commentators are fond of dismissing some of those organisations as bully boys or as self‐interested or sectional groups, but in their competing claims they are contributing to much more exposure of the issues that need to be debated and which the minister himself has quite properly brought to the public's mind. That continued participation by the various constituent organisations in the industry is important if we are to achieve a more effective and efficient aviation safety regulatory regime.

I want to remark on Senator Collins's amendment. I indicate to the parliamentary secretary that we will support that amendment to the second reading debate but with the exclusion of the last three lines of paragraph (c) of that motion. We think that it is too broadly expressed. As Senator Margetts has said, we do not think that the definitions spelt out there are correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, are you moving that as an amendment?
—I would like to ask Senator Collins if he is prepared to accept that. If so, we will move that amendment. If not, we will oppose the entire amendment.
—So you will be moving an amendment?
—Yes. I move:

BREAK.PARA: Omit all words after "new appointments" in paragraph (c) of amendment.

This amendment seeks to exclude the last three lines of paragraph (c) of Senator Collins's second reading amendment. I do not think I have much more to say at this stage. I look forward to the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the notable things about the debate that has taken place so far in the Senate today on the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill is the contrast between the manner of that debate and the way in which this issue has been handled by the Minister for Trans port and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) and by some sections of the industry in the public arena over the past 12 months or so.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have heard today from all sides of the chamber—I pay particular tribute to the contribution of Senator MacGibbon from the government and the comments just made by Senator Murray from the Democrats, as well as from my own colleagues—has been a reasoned, logical and constructive discussion about the particular issues of air safety and the operation of the CASA board. I listened with particular interest to the remarks made by Senator MacGibbon. For instance, I think there is a lot of merit in the comments he made about the need for both independence as well as expertise on the CASA board and in the area of air navigation and air safety. I felt that his suggestion that such qualities can be found in persons with air force experience was a good one.

Equally, Senator MacGibbon quite properly acknowledged that the make‐up of boards, whether it be in the area of civil aviation safety or any area, should never be confined simply to expertise in the particular area for which that board is charged with responsibility. It has long been recognised that in making appointments to boards of government instrumentalities there is a need to have a mix. Firstly, you do need expertise in the particular area that is under the control of that board, but you also need, for instance, to have regard to the importance of consumer representation and a range of other areas that may well be impacted upon by decisions of the board and by the conduct of that industry. I welcome those comments.

As I said, the tenor of the debate here contrasts markedly with how this issue has been handled by the minister out there in the public arena. Other speakers have drawn attention to the fact that the minister has this obsession with removing a number of members of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. It is quite clear that that obsession has blinded him to his responsibilities as a minister. For a start, it has been noted that the minister has at all times had within his area of control the ability to expedite this legislation, which has lain on the table for some seven or eight months. He has known all along that the position of the opposition was that it would not oppose the legislation to expand the size of the board. He has had that opportunity but he has never taken it up until now, when we are debating the bill.

One would have thought that, if he was so concerned—if he had this genuine concern that there was an urgency about restructuring or adding people to the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority because of concerns about safety in the industry—he would have acted; he would have sought to get this legislation through the parliament as quickly as possible so that he could then make the necessary appointments. But he has not done so. He has gone on a public rampage attacking particular individuals. We all know who they are: the chair of the board at the present time, Justice Bill Fisher; Ms Gabi Hollows, who is the consumer advocate; Dr Claire Pollock and, of course, Mr Geoff Molloy. Justice Bill Fisher is a very experienced and highly regarded Chief Justice of the New South Wales Industrial Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he your mate?

—If you want to continue, Senator Macdonald, the disgraceful attack upon the judiciary in this country that other colleagues of yours in the National Party particularly want to engage in, go right ahead. You are clearly making idiots of yourselves out there in the public arena with the sort of attitude being adopted by the government that, if you do not like the message, then you get stuck into the messenger.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the issues before the chamber at the moment, as I have said and as other speakers have acknowledged, the minister has at all times had the opportunity to get this legislation through the parliament quickly, but he chose not to do so. As Senator Murray quite rightly pointed out, the attack upon the board members is totally unjustified. The attack is based upon an argument that these individuals do not have experience or expertise in air navigation or air safety issues or in the aviation industry generally, and therefore they are not entitled to be on the board. In the case of at least two of those persons on the board—Dr Pollock and Mr Geoff Molloy—they do have experience, substantial experience: in respect of safety issues in the case of Dr Pollock, and as a former pilot in the case of Mr Molloy. We all know that the ex officio member of the board is Mr Leroy Keith, a person of renowned expertise in this area. But the minister goes on and on and says he needed to get rid of these people. It was nothing more than a political vendetta which he commenced prior to the election of this government.

As Senator West quite rightly pointed out, the minister has been on this hobby horse, this obsession, since his time as shadow minister. I find it quite hypocritical that the minister is engaging in that sort of campaign. He is accusing members of the board of being incompetent on the basis that they do not have a particular level of experience or expertise in the aviation industry when, at the same time, he and many other ministers in the cabinet and in the ministry would never meet that same test. The fact is that hardly any of the ministers in the current government could claim to have any expertise or experience in the portfolio areas that they look after. At the end of the day, that is where the buck stops—it stops with the minister.

I do acknowledge that there are some ministers who could claim to have a particular expertise based upon their previous profession or training in the area of the ministry that they look after. But, in general, the sort of complaint that this minister wants to make about Justice Fisher, for instance, or Ms Gabi Hollows is one which more clearly applies to many of those in the ministry. I do not notice any of those ministers putting their hands up to resign their commissions as ministers of the Crown because of lack of experience or knowledge. It is a pity that some of them did not consider that option.

We know that a large part of this minister's campaign has been about getting rid of the particular individuals on the board that he does not like. He is also hoping to get the opportunity to appoint a few of his own mates. One person's name in particular has been out there in the public arena. I am quite prepared to name him: it is Dick Smith. Dick Smith himself has put his hand up. He said, `Look, I'm available. I want to be on the board.'

TALK.START.PARA: —He wants to be chairman.

—Yes, he would like to be chairman. If he can't get that, he probably wants to be deputy chair. I do not actually criticise Dick Smith for putting himself forward; he is entitled to lobby. But the real issue here is the fact that Mr Smith would come onto this board representing a specific vested interest in the aviation industry because of his undoubted membership of AOPA. Also, he is a person who has not been immune from criticism about his own previous role when he was on the board of the Civil Aviation Authority. We know that it was Mr Smith who pursued, quite vigorously, the policy of affordable safety—something that has been a matter of concern, particularly since the coroner's report on the Monarch disaster when that philosophy was criticised.

SPEECH.PARA: It was only just prior to the election that Mr Smith publicly endorsed the election of a Liberal government. He did that not only by way of public comment but also by spending many thousands of dollars in advertising on behalf of the Liberal Party. So one has to question the motivation in all of this, especially when we consider the hypocrisy of this government, which constantly attacked the Labor government for some of the appointments that it made to boards whilst it was in office. So don't give us any lectures about this high moral ground that the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the government wish to place themselves on.

I wish to make a few other points in the time remaining. As it has been acknowledged, the Civil Aviation Authority had a lot of problems. That has never been denied. Indeed, it was the Labor government minister who took steps to break up the old CAA. The responsibility for air safety was taken away from them and given to a specific board—namely, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The board of CASA was established in July 1995, and the area of air safety was separated from the other functions of the old CAA and given its own board because of the promi nence and importance that needed to be attached to it. We also saw the establishment of Airservices Australia at the same time.

Listening to the constant public attacks by this minister on these board members, one would think that they had been in their board positions prior to the establishment of CASA. I think there has been a quite deliberate campaign to make the public believe that the current board members of CASA somehow bear responsibility for the incidents, the accidents and the negligence that occurred under the previous arrangements, and of course that is totally untrue. These people have been in office since only July 1995 and, as Senator Murray quite rightly pointed out, their terms expire in June 1997.

At all times the minister has had the opportunity to await the termination of their appointments and then proceed to make different appointments if he so desired. But what has he done? He has allowed this legislation, which will expand the size of the board to give it additional expertise, which he believed was so urgent, to sit, lay dormant, for seven months while he engaged in a disgraceful attack upon current board members and tried to create—I think in some cases he succeeded—a false belief in the community that these people are responsible for all the accidents that had occurred prior to their own appointment.

Senator West quite rightly said and I think other senators have noted that we in this country have a proud record overall for air safety. We are fortunate to live in a country where flying conditions are fairly stable. We do not suffer the extremes of heat and cold that other parts of the world experience. Of course, that fortunate circumstance has contributed to the fact that, by and large, we have a fantastic record for safety. There have been problems in the past. That has been recognised, is being addressed and should continue to be addressed properly within the bodies established to look after this area. It should not be in the public arena as a slanging match between vested interests in the industry.

I suppose members of parliament more than most can attest to the fact that we have an excellent safety record, both domestically and when Qantas and Ansett fly overseas. I am sure many members of parliament could recount incidents of where they have flown on airlines in other countries and would attest to the fact that we have the highest of standards when it comes to comparisons with the rest of the world.

That, of course, is not in any way to suggest that we can be complacent. We cannot be. But the minister has certainly been complacent. He has been lacking in his responsibility to get this legislation through the parliament. It should have been done ages ago. Fortunately, it is now before the parliament. As I said, I think we are now getting a constructive debate on the issue rather than the public slanging match we have had in the past. I support the legislation in conjunction with the amendment that has been moved by my colleague Senator Bob Collins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in summing up. I do agree with Senator Forshaw that this is an important debate. I and certainly the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) are very happy that today we are debating the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to point out something by way of explanation because the motion moved by Senator Bob Collins, as amended by the Australian Democrats, refers to the minister having in some way been tardy in getting this legislation before the Senate. I think Senator Collins knows as well as I do that the minister has been very keen to get this legislation debated. When I took over the job of Manager of Government Business in the Senate, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development was one of the first people to knock on my door and ask, `When the hell are you going to get this CASA legislation dealt with?' He not only knocked on my door but also bailed me up at airport lounges and rang me regularly. Mr Wallis, who is in the advisers box today, rang me regularly. I even bailed up Senator Bob Collins behind the partition behind you, Madam Deputy President, and suggested to him that we get it dealt with quickly and negotiate to have it dealt with non‐controversially.

TALK.START.PARA: —You shouldn't be telling people what we do behind the partition.
—We were fully clothed.
—That's nobody's business but ours. That's why we go behind the partition.

—That is right. Unfortunately for the Deputy President, he had his picture taken standing near the partition, which I thought was very unfair of the ABC last night. Senator Collins and I did not have our photograph taken, but I am sure he will not mind my saying that the minister has hounded me to distraction to have this legislation dealt with. So he is very happy it is here. I have worked assiduously to make sure that it got here. I would hate to know when the legislation would have got dealt with if it had not been for the `oiling the squeaky wheel' syndrome that applies in most things in life, I suspect. That is a serious matter, because the minister has tried to get this dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reading amendment is the other matter I would like to deal with. The coalition clearly would prefer there not to be a second reading amendment, but Senator Murray's motion to delete all words after `new appointments' in paragraph (c) does take out most of the most objectionable parts of that other motion. As I said, we would prefer not to support the motion at all because we think that, effectively, it is a restatement of either the reality or the law, certainly in paragraph (b) and the bit of paragraph (c) that remains. Paragraph (a) is a sort of restatement of things that we find not disagreeable. We will not oppose the amendment by Senator Murray. In conclusion, I thank all honourable senators who have made contributions to this debate and look forward to the bill's speedy passage.
Amendment (Senator Murray's) agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Bob Collins's), as amended, agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no idea whether Senator Murray intends to press divisions at all. But, just in case he does, I indicate that the opposition intends to support Democrat amendments 1, 2 and 6 and oppose amendments 3, 4 and 5. I do that to simply indicate that if Senator Murray did want to press divisions he may not. If the amendments are moved in two blocks, it might save a bit of time.

—If the government is inclined to oppose any of these amendments, we will be moving to call a division. As you can see, I am alone in here. So, in the event of that happening and you push me to it, I will have to call a quorum. I am happy to take it in any blocks which accord with your remarks.

—If the committee is minded to do so, Senator Murray should move amendments 1, 2 and 6, deal with those now and divide on them, as he has indicated he wishes to do. He should then move remaining amendments 3, 4, 5 and 7 together as a second block.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 14), after item 4, insert:

PARA.TAB: Insert:
(1A) The members referred to in paragraphs (a), (aa) and (c) of subsection (1) must be persons who have qualifications relevant to, or experience in, one or more of the following fields:

TAB.TAB: (a) safety systems and practices, preferably in relation to aviation;
(b) aviation or aeronautical engineering;
(c) flying aircraft;
(d) consumer advocacy, preferably in relation to aviation;
(e) administration, preferably in relation to a regulatory body;
(f) financial management or accounting;
(g) law.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 14), after item 4, insert:

PARA.TAB: After "Minister" (first occurring), insert "on the basis of merit".

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 14), after item 4, insert:

PARA.TAB: Insert:

TAB.TAB: In making appointments, the Minister must ensure that the balance of interests on the Board is such that no one interest may dominate the Board or derogate from its independence.

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your assistance, Senator Collins. I will deal with amendment 1 first. It is important to note that there are precedents for this kind of spelling out, if you like, of qualifications required. I think the Wool Board, for instance, has the qualifications spelt out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aviation or aeronautical engineering?

—I will come to that. We have done that quite deliberately. We have done this spelling out of the various qualifications `relevant to or experience in'—and, Senator Collins, you must note the word `or'; it is not a prescriptive or restrictive amendment—deliberately because of the very strong case the minister has publicly made as to the qualifications and experience he wants on the board without really spelling it out.

SPEECH.PARA: If I can deal with paragraph (a) of the amendment first. We have indicated that it is important that there is a person on the board who understands safety systems and practices, preferably in relation to aviation. Boards, generally speaking, have to react to proposals put to them by senior executives of the organisation. Since safety is the raison d'etre of the CASA board, it is vital that they do have people on that board with experience in safety systems and practices able to judge the issue appropriately.

Shadow minister Tanner correctly made the point that companies such as BHP do not necessarily have welders on their boards. But you can be very sure that, given the nature of that company, they have engineers on their board so that, when their executives come to them with proposals, they have people with substance and ability able to rebut or to question in an informed, experienced and qualified manner. I cannot conceive the CASA board ever excluding the requirements in paragraph (a).

As the mover of the amendment, I should make clear to Senator Bob Collins that our intention is that paragraph (b) of the amendment not be read as `aviation, or aeronautical engineering'; it is aviation engineering or aeronautical engineering. I am told by those who are intelligent in these matters, which I am not, that that can mean a different kind of engineering background and qualification. That is the reason aviation engineering or aeronautical engineering is included there. Since so much of safety depends upon structural matters and an understanding of the structural nature of aircraft, you need people who have an engineering understanding. Once again this goes to the very heart of the case the minister has made, but has failed to specify.

Paragraph (c) of the amendment is expressed as `flying aircraft'. In other words, persons with experience in the matter of flying aircraft should be on the board. That can be a very broad field. Plainly, if you are going to be involved in matters of aircraft safety, it is quite helpful to have people who understand that matter.

You can have people advising you in life who have got no experience in matters whatsoever. I am reminded of Catholic priests who might advise you on matters of matrimony. I have always thought that was an extraordinary thing for them to do. So there are instances in life where people do advise you in areas in which they have no experience, but I think that is inappropriate in this board.

Paragraph (d) of the amendment is `consumer advocacy, preferably in relation to aviation'. This board is primarily but not exclusively concerned with the safety of fee paying passengers. The needs of those passengers, the needs of consumers, have to be taken into account. The previous government recognised that. We wish the current government to recognise that. It is a very important, appropriate and public recognition of a community need.

Paragraph (e) of the amendment is `administration, preferably in relation to a regulatory body'. The point was made I think in the second reading speech that it is vital that administration is understood, that a person who is on the board understands the mechanisms, the methods, the shortfalls and the pitfalls of operating in a regulatory body.

Paragraph (f) of the amendment is `financial management or accounting'. Any board which has to deal with the financial matters that are the province of the board has to have someone on it with a financial management or accounting background.

We have heard in previous debates and in the media the concept of affordable safety discussed. Somebody who is dealing with affordable safety needs to know what the balance sheets, cash flows and prospects look like of the airlines which are affected by safety decisions which have a financial outcome. Somebody who has to determine the resource needs of the organisation needs to understand the financial consequences of how all that works and to relate to and react to the proposals of what may sometimes be a self-serving executive or employee who puts a proposal to the board.

Paragraph (g) of the amendment is `law' and relates to the liabilities which attach to this very important field. No board is without legal advice, simply because of the fiduciary duties and the liabilities which pertain in operating any organisation. They are particularly important in matters of air safety, where the compensation claims and the legal claims can be extremely onerous and extremely difficult. It is very unwise to have a board which does not have someone on it with legal background and experience.

For paragraphs (a) to (g) of the amendment we have said that persons should have qualifications relevant to, or experience in, one or more of those fields. If you look at existing members of the board and take somebody like Mr Keith, who is the head of the executive, you can see that he could fit into a number of those categories and that is so for almost any appointment that has been publicly put or for appointments which have already been made.

We think this throws out all the politics and the claims that the members of the board are not experienced enough or not capable enough. This clearly spells out, but with wide enough discretions, to the minister the constituency of the board. I urge strongly that this amendment be supported. I am grateful to Labor for indicating their support.

The listing of the skills needed on a board is not a novelty. It is actually highly desirable. As I said, it is influenced for us by the Wool International Act, which has a comprehensive scheme governing selection and appointment of members. The amendment has a precedent and should be supported.

The inclusion of `on the basis of merit' in our amendment No. 2 should not be necessary but, regrettably, because of the patronage assertions, questions of bias and the inference of mateship in the appointments of persons to the board, we would urge that this amendment be accepted. It should not even have to be here but it needs to be here. Perhaps the minister himself does intend to make his appointments on the basis of merit. If he does intend that, I cannot possibly see how the government could oppose this amendment No. 2. To oppose it would be just the most extraordinary thing I have ever heard.
I move to amendment No. 6. Once again, I could not possibly see how the government could oppose this one because it simply says:
In making appointments, the Minister must ensure that the balance of interests on the Board is such that no one interest may dominate the Board or derogate from its independence.

Plainly, the government would not like to see any board captured by an organisation or persons, because that would rebound to the detriment of the ability of that board to act independently and of the minister to rely on its considerations. Whilst I might expect some debate from the government on amendment No. 1, in my opinion amendments Nos 2 and 6 are extremely supportive of the government having a board which is capable of doing its job.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to say the Greens are happy to support the three amendments moved. I have mentioned problems in terms of the board structure with resourcing and levels of regulation, but we do think this is moving in the right direction in relation to the operation of the board and the interaction between governments of any sort and the way boards are structured. If it is seen to be a well‐working model—and we all have the ability to watch carefully and review—I do not see that this kind of guideline will be a problem for air safety. We are all hoping that it will be a step towards improving air safety. It might be a way of depoliticising the CASA board and making sure that all governments have clear guidelines about how such boards should be constituted.
—The opposition will be supporting the three amendments moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be opposing all of the amendments that are currently before the Senate. I think Senator Murray quite adequately explained the reasons we would do so during his speech in the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that it is not appropriate to be so prescriptive, to effectively create a check list in the legislation as to the sorts of people and qualifications that are required to go on this board. The coalition, prior to the election and virtually every week since then, has said that we are committed to appointing people with relevant aviation experience to this board. This legislation proposes to do that. We do not think that it is necessary to say that the appointment needs to be made on the basis of merit. The alternative proposition to that is that you might prescribe in the legislation that the appointment be made only on the basis that the person being appointed was an utter dill.

We believe that, when someone has got to the position of a minister of the Crown in the federal government, there are enough checks and balances on that minister to ensure that he or she makes an appointment on the basis of merit without telling the minister in legislation that he or she has to do that. That is not to say that ministers in the past have not appointed to boards people who were inappropriate or even dills. That may from time to time happen. I am not aware of that, but it probably has happened. But we regard it as entirely unnecessary to say that the appointment needs to be made on the basis of merit.

Amendment No. 1 moved by Senator Murray is far too prescriptive. We believe that the minister should not be fettered in this way in making appointments, particularly when you read amendment No. 1 with amendment No. 3. I am very pleased to see the opposition will not be supporting amendment No. 3. If you took the two of those together, it would become extremely prescriptive and would tie the hands of the minister in making sensible judgments about the balance of the board—judgments on not only the experience of members of the board but also the balance and the other capabilities, the characters of the people involved and how the personalities of the board would work together.

Senator Murray did make a very good point about his own experience on boards. The former minister Senator Bob Collins would know from his own long experience that when it comes to boards you have to have leadership and the right balance of leadership. The best boards always work when there is a spirit of teamwork, where the various skills, experiences and characters of those people meld together to achieve a good outcome for the area where they have responsibility. It is very hard to get that balance and this legislation seeks to give us a better chance to allow that to happen in the future with this very important board.

Like Senator Collins and all other senators, we have an intense vested interest in matters of air safety. I think it was Senator Collins who pointed out to the Senate a few years ago that he had inquired of one of Australia's major airlines as to who was the most travelled passenger in Australia. I think he found that he came out on top with that airline and that I was the second most travelled in that particular year. As Senator Collins and I know—as does my friend Senator Murray—coming from Western Australia or the Northern Territory, in particular, you are able to get to the top of that particular ratings table in Australia fairly easily.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not a position I aspire to.
—No. It is not the sort of league table that I like to be at the top of, even though I fear that I am very near the top of it again.

SPEECH.PARA: Through you, Mr Chairman: Senator Murray, it is for those reasons the coalition is opposed to these matters. Ultimately, the processes of the cabinet which must be gone through to get nominations brought forward for these sorts of boards are quite rigorous, and Senator Collins particularly would know this from his own experience. In my own short experience in government where I have had to recommend appointments to various boards—and I have had to deal with the Antarctic Science Advisory Board and a couple of others—the process is most rigorous. Certainly in relation to this board, that process would be rigorous also.

With regard to tying the hands of the minister with this legislation, as I said to you, Senator Murray, the indication that the Senate has now given to the minister by way of the second reading amendment gives him a very clear view of the Senate's intention there—a motion that was passed without opposition. As I put to you privately, I would have thought that is the sort of direction the Senate representing the people of Australia might give to a minister. But to do so in a bit of black and white prescriptive legislation, I think, is against the interests of achieving an aviation board that will serve the best interests of the travelling public of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, the minister has made some statements which do need to be challenged. If it is too prescriptive to have seven qualities, from which a person needs only one or perhaps two—and preferably more, I suppose—to be sought for board membership, one wonders what the rationale is for seeking to dismiss members of the board because they do not have particular attributes.

BREAK.PARA: If that is the case, if you have ministers seeking to dismiss members not because of, presumably—and I have not heard the argument—their performance as individual members of the board but because it is assumed they are lacking certain qualities, then it seems bizarre to have that being done in a de facto way without mentioning those qualities which are considered to be necessary in making up a board that will perform this very important function.

One might be able to take this as an issue: that it ought to be said it is too prescriptive to indicate what qualities might be useful on such a board—and that does not mean this is the be-all and end-all of what qualities might be useful. But it does seem to be hypocritical for people to be, if you like, hunted out of the board for not having certain qualities when there are no lists or guidelines of what kind of qualities are necessary for this very important issue of safety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond quickly. I think that in a way Senator Margetts helps me to make the point that we are not, I would hope, trying to revisit matters of controversy over the last couple of weeks. We are putting in place a bit of legislation that, based on the trouble we have had getting this legislation up on the Notice Paper , is not likely to come back here for a while. We are putting in place a piece of legislation that is to form the basis of this board for some time to come.

SPEECH.PARA: In the event that you would want to come back here and have a sort of rolling checklist of the kind of people you might want on the board is exactly why the government is opposed to it. We do not want that. We believe that the minister has the responsibility of appointing that board, under the relevant acts and under acts that apply to all statutory authorities; and that the minister, through the cabinet process and through his accountability to the parliament, is required to do that and is accountable for those decisions. That is the appropriate process to go through, without giving him a prescriptive black‐letter law checklist or menu to choose from. That just should not be necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senator BOB COLLINS

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to respond briefly to the point that Senator Margetts made, and also to agree with a point that Senator Campbell made earlier. I guess, as someone who has been in the position of having to do the job of finding people for boards, I have to say that it is often a difficult job. I can remember that when I was minister for transport the then secretary of my department, a highly competent and well experienced bureaucrat, spent an inordinate amount of his own personal time headhunting for boards.

SPEECH.PARA: I do wish to agree with Senator Campbell that, by and large, the process that is gone through in terms of making selections for boards is indeed rigorous and often difficult in trying to get all of the combination of skills you need. Senator Campbell said, again correctly, that one of the things you also have to give some regard to is the personalities, not just the expertise, of the people you are putting on a board because you do have to have a group of people who can work together. That is why leadership qualities, particularly of the chair of these boards, are important.

Senator Campbell made another point earlier: if you combine one with three—and I agree with him—it is putting a degree of constraint on any minister in a real world that would be literally, Senator Murray, with respect, almost impossible to achieve. We are supporting one because, having considered carefully all of the areas that have been laid down, we think that the kind of people whom you wanted, if they were not technical experts, would probably arguably at least be able to claim some expertise in areas of administration, financial management, accounting or so on, and you could get from the field of candidates sufficient qualified people. But if you were to apply the constraint of amendment No. 3 as well, I just think it would be creating a task for any government and any minister that would literally be impossible to achieve.

I noted with some interest the concern that Senator Campbell raised—rightly—of not having dills on boards. I think that is import ant. Perhaps Senator Campbell could suggest moving a no dill clause in respect of the board. But perhaps it might be fairer—

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think he should move it!

—Considering we are passing the laws, perhaps you could have a clause that said that you could, at least proportionately, have no greater number of dills on boards than you have in parliament. He might like to consider that as an amendment—but that would still give the boards a fairly wide scope, I would imagine.

SPEECH.PARA: I do agree with Senator Campbell. With greatest respect to Senator Murray, I am actually asking him to give some consideration to withdrawing amendment No. 3 because I can assure Senator Murray that to make it prescriptive—as amendment No. 3 does—that you actually have to have on a board of six people, with an ex officio chief executive, every single one of the qualifications from (a) to (g), is putting a task in front of a government or a minister that is literally impossible to fulfil.

TALK.START.PARA: —The points made are useful to the debate. My political memory does not go back far enough to know whether Senator Bob Collins had the passage of the Wool International Bill when it was taken through in 1993.
—That is correct.

—That is quite helpful. He would, therefore, be cognisant of the precedent. My political memory also does not tell me, but maybe Senator Collins would know, whether the coalition government—opposition as it then was—supported section 10‐25 in part V which refers to the membership of the Wool International Board. If they did, they are now arguing a different case.
—They did, Senator Murray.
—They did. Well, let us make that clear, Senator Campbell. You supported the following prescriptive board of Wool International. You agreed to the following:

BREAK.PARA: 23.(1) Wool International consists of the following members:
(a) the Chairperson of Wool International;
(b) the Chief Executive;
(c) a member to represent the Commonwealth;
(d) 8 other members.
(2) The members referred to in paragraph (1)(d) must be persons who have qualifications relevant to, or experience in, one or more of the following fields:
(a) wool production;
(b) wool processing, including the manufacture of wool products;
(c) business management;
(d) financial services;
(e) marketing;
(f) international commodity trading;
(g) wool testing and specification;
(h) law and industrial relations.

Senator Bob Collins quite properly continues to support a list where it is essential for the board's operation. Yet the coalition, when it is dealing with air safety, cannot apply the same principle it supported with wool marketing. With respect to the enormous importance of the wool industry, it does not have quite the same impact on lives and livelihoods that air safety does. I think the government erodes its own argument by refusing to acknowledge the precedent that existed prior.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather impressed with the comments made by the opposition about amendment No. 3. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Minister must ensure that the members collectively possess qualifications or experience in all the fields referred to in subsection (1A).
The question that arises in my mind is: is the board validly constituted if not all of those are met? We are going to have a great deal of difficulty in respect of that.

I feel that proposed amendment No. 5 is an overkill. This parliament does have a responsibility, in the end, to challenge the minister and to ensure that the minister is answerable to parliament. We have a number of ways that this can be done, but to virtually stalk the minister, day to day, prior to the appointments being made on the basis that is envisaged by amendment No. 5, and to tie it with a code of practice which is a disallowable instrument, is probably going too far. The minister should, and does, have certain responsibilities imposed on him or her under the legislation. I think this is very much an overkill. I am not wishing to denigrate what Senator Murray is attempting to do, but I think it is just going that bit too far.

I see nothing dreadfully wrong with amendment No. 1, except that you could have persons on the board who do not have expertise in these specific areas but who could make valuable contributions. For example, we have heard today that Senator Bob Collins and the parliamentary secretary are on the top of a particular list of fliers if they retire from the Senate. They are very experienced in areas of civil aviation, but under this prescriptive amendment—Senator Murray may be able to correct me—I cannot see how either of them could be appointed to the CASA board. Yet they would make, I am sure, a considerable contribution to the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try (d), Senator Harradine.
—Consumer advocacy? Maybe, but I may not agree with them. I think it is a bit too prescriptive. My intention is to vote against the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to discuss an issue of critical importance to the public of my home state of South Australia; that is, the divisive treachery which afflicts the South Australian Liberal government, particularly as is evidenced by the systematic serial leaking by government leaders, factional leaders and ordinary members of the South Australian government.

SPEECH.PARA: This clandestine disclosure of information over the last two years in an attempt to destabilise firstly Premier Brown—and successfully so—and now Premier Olsen can best be described not as a leak but as a flood. For the three years of the Brown government, the leaking to Labor leader Mike Rann and other Labor MPs was led and orchestrated by the present Premier John Olsen and former Liberal leader Dale Baker. These ministers led a group of ministers and MPs in the state Liberal government who together undertook a vendetta in an organised campaign designed to grab the Liberal leadership from Dean Brown.

The losers have been the South Australian people. While this rabble of a government has been fighting each other, they have not been fighting for South Australia. While they have been busily plotting to destabilise the premier, they were taking their eyes and attention off their main responsibility—to run the state in the interests of South Australians. They have seen their positions in government as personal fiefdoms from which to conduct intensive warfare. While all of this has preoccupied their attentions, first Premier Kennett and now Treasurer Costello have stripped the state of much needed economic resources.

There have been two waves of leaking. The first wave was conducted by the people I have just revealed. The second wave was conducted by some whom I am not, as yet, able to identify. Mike Rann, of course, can identify the leak. It has been said in recent days that he is prepared to do so in certain circumstances.

Let us turn for the moment to the second wave to get a real idea of the magnitude of the warfare that is going on. In recent days the Labor Party has received—in what is, without doubt, the biggest confidential leak in South Australian political history—750 pages of information about the water privatisation deal South Australians did not want. We were also given cabinet submissions, the minutes of cabinet subcommittees, private internal memos between ministers and between political staff, opinions of Crown solicitors and the Solicitor-General and confidential advice from CEOs to their ministers.

Perhaps the most important thing we have received recently was the taxpayer funded polling about the water privatisation deal. Both John Olsen and Dean Brown knew of the polling and yet denied the existence of the poll even though Olsen wrote to Brown about it just months before the matter was brought up in parliament. Both of them misled parliament and misled South Australians, and that is probably the only thing they have done together in recent years.

The polling shows that no-one wanted our water sold to the French and the British, but John Olsen, believing he knew best—arrogance at most—did it anyway. He spent hundreds of thousands of taxpayers' dollars trying to convince South Australians that the deal would be good for us. We all said we did not want it, and we kept saying we did not want it, but John Olsen did it anyway.

As if that were not enough, the documents also showed that there had been a serious breach of probity in the handling of the water contract. I have spoken about that before. Although the government had been informed, Olsen and Brown did not order an inquiry into this until months later when evidence from witnesses before a select committee of the parliament of South Australia forced them to do so. Mike Rann was also given information relating to the business activities and land deals made by former Liberal leader Dale Baker while he was minister. I must say that this leaking is continuing. It continued last weekend and continued even up until Monday of this week. The beast that is the South Australian government continues to bleed a slow death.

Let us turn back to the first wave—the wave for which Olsen and Dale Baker are responsible. These latest leaks are only a culmination of three years of leaking, which was designed to damage Mr Brown's standing in the community, the media and parliament within his own party. The senior Liberals I mentioned provided information to the Labor Party about Catch Tim Ltd and the Moriki financial scandals that rocked the Brown government in early 1995. We received information telling us that political donations were being laundered through shelf companies in Hong Kong to disguise the true source of the donations. One Liberal MP even drafted questions for the opposition to ask in parliament in order to embarrass Dean Brown. That is about as low as one can get.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you name them?

—I have just named two of them, Senator. I have just named Olsen and Dale Baker. I do not know why you were not listening. One Liberal MP drafted questions for the opposition. Liberal MPs also gave material to the state opposition about the government's proposed sale of the state forestry assets and, more recently, buckets of information designed to undermine Dean Brown's attempts to sack the Adelaide city council. Damaging information about the premier's information technology outsourcing contract with EDS was also given to the opposition over many months until just days before Dean Brown was deposed as premier.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, the vendetta of serial leaking had one objective, and that was to get rid of Dean Brown. That was successful. The opposition in South Australia revealed the existence of documents that showed that the former premier had misled parliament about the level of subsidies offered by the MFP to establish a head office at Technology Park.

This first wave of information had been leaked because of enormous personal battles between individuals and the state government. It reflects a childish inability to govern the state. They are not responsible enough to govern themselves, let alone to govern South Australia.

None of the leaking was ever motivated by a concern for the people of South Australia; it was based on internal hatred and motivated by a desire to overthrow the previous Premier Dean Brown. This sort of bickering is irrelevant to the lives of most South Australians, but the information that was provided to us was not.

John Olsen is not Premier because he is capable and honest, because over recent years he has shown he is none of those, nor is he loyal. He is Premier because he, together with Dale Baker, continually leaked destructive information to the opposition in a vicious campaign against Dean Brown. It is no wonder that Dean Brown now still believes that he can and should return to the top job. He is busily calculating who will be left in his parliamentary Liberal Party after the election and who will vote for him.

Unfortunately for South Australians—while this has been going on for the last three years, while the main protagonists in the South Australian government have been slogging it out day after day, month after month—no-one has been fighting for South Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —In this afternoon's debate I will discuss recent media attention given to the Australian Workers Union and its troubles in Queensland your home state, Madam Acting Deputy President Reynolds. In particular, I refer to Mr Bill Ludwig's, the AWU Queensland Secretary, cashing in of his long service leave which exceeded $100,000. When I first read the media reports I was convinced that they could not be true. I knew there was a law against such behaviour. The Queensland Industrial Relations Act 1990, section 249 states, as an introduction, `[No payment in lieu]'. The section reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Except upon termination of an employee's employment, an employer is not to make, and an employee is not to accept, payment in lieu of long service leave.

You could not get much clearer than that. This section of the Queensland Industrial Relations Act, which is mirrored in similar legislation all around this country, is held up by Labor and the trade union movement as a shining example of what the Labor movement has achieved for its members.

Given that long service leave and the outlawing of cashing it in is one of the hard fought gains that Labor claims, I thought it impossible that Mr Ludwig—a Queensland Labor power broker, Queensland Secretary of the Australian Workers Union, National President of the Australian Workers Union, Vice President of the ALP, a member of the ALP National Executive with direct links into Mr Beazley's office through Wayne Swan, the defeated member for Lilley and would‐be senator—could countenance any employer or employee breaching such a fundamental principle. Yet that is exactly what he did for his own personal benefit, a benefit of $103,269.88.
