I have to say to you that, but for seeing the actual documentation, the letters written by Mr Ludwig and the letters to Mr Ludwig enclosing the cheque, I would not have believed the information, nor would I have got up in this parliament to have raised this issue. I have seen the correspondence dated 28 March 1996 signed by Mr Ludwig to Mr Ian Cambridge, the Joint National Secretary of the Australian Workers Union.

Mr Ludwig cashed in his superannuation, a benefit not available to any of his members who pay him his salary, which is in excess of $61,000. I understand the union rules may allow Mr Ludwig to cash in his superannuation. If he can, why can't all his members? Why did Mr Ludwig and the trade union movement fight to disallow this benefit to their members and then draft union rules to give themselves that benefit? It is ironic that Mr Ludwig got his cheque for $103,269.88 by a letter dated 1 April 1996, April Fool's Day. Mr Ludwig clearly has fooled his membership and has laughed all the way to the bank with his $103,269.88.

What makes this a bit more concerning is that after Mr Ludwig got his payment there was another request from officials to cash in their superannuation benefits. All of a sudden four officials, all undoubtedly acting independently of each other, requested on 3 December 1996 to cash in their superannuation benefits, relying on the bizarre rules of the AWU which are in conflict with the Queensland legislation—section 249 of the Industrial Relations Act, as I have indicated to the Senate.

Why did all these officials decide on the very same day that they would want to cash in their superannuation benefits? Undoubtedly they came to that conclusion independently, without discussing it with anybody and just decided it would be a nice thing to do. It is strange that if we have a look at the requests of all these officials we find that all their written requests are dated 3 December 1996. Those officials are: R. Slater, who got $91,884.41; B. Meiklejohn, $94,851.47; W. Paton, $101,086.28; and K. Goding, $108,442.72. All the cashing in was in excess of $500,000.

Why did they all decide on the same day to cash in their benefits? That question I simply pose rhetorically, but it looks as though there must have been some discussion between the officials concerned. Were they concerned that union rules may shortly be changed to bring them in line with the long service leave rules in the Industrial Relations Act of Queensland? Once again, I simply ask that question rhetorically.

I wonder if Mr Ludwig and his officials are going around to their membership saying that the privileges of union officials ought be extended to the membership—chances are not. And chances are that is why Mr Ludwig's personal request to cash in his superannuation was in fact headed `private and confidential'. He clearly did not want his membership to know what he was up to. If it was clearly an entitlement that he felt comfortable with, that the union rules provided for, that it was all above board, why on earth would he be concerned that his request be dealt with in a private and confidential way?

I suppose the very fact that I, as a Liberal senator, have been provided with this documentation indicates there are some very real concerns about the state of the AWU in Queensland. There are other aspects of this Labor doyen's activities which have been asserted to me but I am not willing to go into those allegations as there is no supportive evidence as yet provided to me. But if that supportive evidence does materialise, I look forward to making a further contribution in relation to this matter.

The Australian Workers Union is in a mess. Its direct link with the Labor Party, the shared office holder status of Mr Ludwig in the AWU and in the ALP, raises the question about Labor's concern for propriety. It raises questions about Labor's integrity and its internal mechanisms for dealing with allegations of this kind. It raises questions also as to why Mr Swan, who is so closely associated with Mr Beazley, is, as I understand it, actively involved in Mr Ludwig's re‐election campaign to the position of trade union official in the Australian Workers Union.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to place on the parliamentary record my continuing concern about the circumstances surrounding the recent appointment of a new chair of the National Health and Medical Research Council because I think it is a matter of public interest. I am not so much concerned with the lack of accountability or transparency in the appointment process or with the government's failure to adequately respond to legitimate concerns that have been raised about the political interference in that process. That is not the focus of my remarks today—my views on that are already on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I want to concentrate on allegations which were made in the Senate in relation to Professor John Funder, the preferred candidate of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) for the position, whose nomination was rejected by cabinet in what can only be described as extraordinary circumstances. In this chamber last week, Senator Harradine, in response to a question from Senator Brown, tabled a letter from Dr Andrew Hapel which Senator Harradine said he had given to the government in support of his objections to Professor Funder's appointment as the NHMRC chair.

Senator Harradine also alleged that the then director of the John Curtin School of Medical Research, Professor David Curtis, was critical of Professor Funder's performance in reporting on the application of the Stephen committee report to the John Curtin School of Medical Research. In effect, Senator Harradine put on the record allegations made by two people who were, rightly or wrongly, disgruntled by something Professor Funder had allegedly done. Senator Harradine says he passed on these concerns to the minister, presumably in addition to the concerns that he had raised earlier with the government.

What concerns me is that Professor Funder was given no opportunity to respond to these particular allegations prior to cabinet rejecting his nomination. From media reports we can see that the Attorney‐General, Mr Williams, did take the extraordinary action of asking Professor Funder to respond to Senator Harradine's concerns. I must say that there is still no satisfactory public explanation as to how or why Mr Williams became involved, although I suspect it was very likely that the Attorney‐General was behaving honourably and giving Professor Funder an opportunity to refute some of Senator Harradine's concerns.

But Professor Funder was not made aware of the specific allegation being made against him by Doctor Hapel, through Senator Harradine. Professor Funder told the Attorney‐General he was only aware of two occasions on which Senator Harradine had voiced his concerns. On the first of these occasions, in 1992, Senator Harradine's concerns had been voiced in the context of the NHRMC's record in funding research into embryo experimentation. On the second occasion, in 1994, Senator Harradine's concerns revolved around his view that Professor Funder was a supporter of RU 486.

I do not need to go into Professor Funder's very strong defence of his position in relation to these matters. The point I want to concentrate on is that concerns about Professor Funder's recommendations in relation to the John Curtin School of Medical Research were not raised with him. Neither was the letter from Dr Hapel which had, according to Senator Harradine, been passed on to the minister.

Dr Hapel's letter is dated 28 January 1997 and Professor Funder's response to the Attorney‐General is dated 14 February 1997. Maybe the Attorney did not know about the letter or these additional concerns. Maybe the minister did not know about them at this time. I accept that that is quite probable. But these issues concerning the John Curtin School of Medical Research certainly seemed to have miraculously bubbled up to the surface when it became apparent that there was not a lot of support around for the notion that the moral beliefs of the chair of the NHMRC were apparently a more important selection criteri on than his scientific and medical qualifications.

I also note that Dr Hapel's letter is addressed: `To whom it may concern'. I think that is a little odd in the circumstances and something which does raise questions as to whether Dr Hapel initiated this action or whether he was approached to do so. Whatever the circumstances, my concern is that Professor Funder knew nothing of Dr Hapel's letter until it was tabled in the parliament by Senator Harradine. I think that is a fundamental breach of natural justice, and it is one which I seek to rectify today.

I seek leave to table a section of a letter from Professor Funder to the Vice Chancellor of the Australian National University—the section that deals only with references to Dr Hapel. I will have to adjust the documentation before I do it.Dated 18 November 1991, it contains Professor Funder's actual report on the discussions he had with the staff of the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

The report shows that Dr Hapel is being a bit loose with his facts when he states in his letter—the letter used by Senator Harradine—that Professor Funder recommended that Dr Hapel not be offered an NHMRC fellowship because of his poor eyesight. What Professor Funder in fact recommended—as we can see in this excerpt—was that Dr Hapel should be offered an NHMRC fellowship subject to his undergoing appropriate medical evaluation so that he and the John Curtin School of Medical Research could be assured that his continuing to work at the bench `is not only possible but does not endanger himself or those around him'. In other words, he did not say, `Don't give this man a fellowship because of his eyesight.' He said, `Give this man a fellowship subject to his having his eyesight tested.' That is a very different thing.

Professor Funder made no secret of the fact that he had not been able to interview Dr Hapel. He said so in his report. He said Dr Hapel's eyesight `appears to have deteriorated' but he did not recommend—as Dr Hapel in his letter tabled by Senator Harradine asserted—that Dr Hapel should not be offered a fellowship because of his poor eyesight. Professor Funder did not—as Dr Hapel asserted in his letter—attempt to prevent Dr Hapel from being awarded an NHMRC fellowship.

So what we have here is someone who was disgruntled with something Professor Funder was perceived to have done, and that person's views were given to the minister by Senator Harradine, tabled in parliament, and Professor Funder has no opportunity to respond to them. I do not pretend to know all the circumstances surrounding Professor Funder's report. Neither, I suggest, does Senator Harradine.

Perhaps Dr Hapel's view of events is an understandable one, but it is certainly an incorrect one, which is now on the record. It is an incorrect one in view of the content of Professor Funder's report. I do not think any of us has any objection to any senator, or Senator Harradine, passing on Dr Hapel's letter to the minister. That is his prerogative; it is our prerogative. What I have a problem with is that, at a critical stage in the appointment process, Professor Funder, the health minister's nominee, never got a chance to refute Dr Hapel's version of events. Whether the complaint of this one person was or should have been sufficient to raise questions about Professor Funder's appointment as the NHMRC chair is apparently something we will never know, given the government's almost pathological reluctance to discuss the matter.

All I am doing today is simply placing additional facts on the parliamentary record—facts which Professor Funder should have been given an opportunity to present himself. Since I have been speaking, I have been able to ascertain through my staff with Professor Funder that this entire letter is a public document. Therefore, I do not need to excise any elements of it. I wish to table the entire letter, which I understand has been shown to representatives in the chamber. I seek leave to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, leave is not granted unless the whole of the letter is incorporated, or is tabled.
—Yes, it is. It is a public document, so I am getting the whole of it.
—Senator, you are seeking leave to table the whole document?
—Yes, I am. I just made that explanation at the end, Madam Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to speak—
—Why? It is the matter of public interest debate.
—I am not now speaking in this public interest debate. I seek leave to speak on this particular question of the tabling of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding was that Senator Kernot asked for some part of a letter to be tabled. Was that this particular document or was it some other document? I am sorry that I am not aware of precisely what has proceeded. Normally speaking, those who are going to raise a matter of public interest and who are going to target a colleague, another senator, do the courtesy of letting that senator know that this is to occur. I was phoned at in a meeting, namely, the Parliamentary Amnesty—

—Senator Harradine, I think you are straying a little. Perhaps we could seek clarification from Senator Kernot. I think she is seeking leave to table the whole document. If she is, that may allay some of your concerns. Senator Kernot, are you seeking leave to table the whole document?

—I am. When I first came in here, Senator Vanstone raised with me the question of whether one element of this letter was particularly sensitive. It referred to early retirements. My understanding was that it was a public document but, because I had to speak without being able to finish my conversation with my adviser on the phone, I thought that the compromise would be to seek to table the relevant section. I was then advised that the whole letter is a public document, and at the end of my remarks I sought to table the whole letter.
—Thank you. Does that clarify the matter for you, Senator Harradine? Is there any objection to the document being tabled? Is leave granted?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to raise with Senator Kernot a point of clarification. This document you say is a public document. How did it get into the public domain? Has it been distributed widely; is it available for public inspection? The reason why I raise this is that the government is inclined to agree to paragraph 1.3 being tabled, but there are other people mentioned in this letter who perhaps might not know they are the subject of comment in this letter and it might affect them in some way if this were to be tabled. If it is in the public domain in a wide sense, certainly no prejudice befalls them, but if there is a chance of that then the government would say that only paragraph 1.3 should be tabled. I have not had a chance to speak to Senator Harradine about this—
—I have not seen the document. I was not ever aware that the document—
—I take your point that you were not aware.

—Senator Ellison, I may be able to assist here. Senator Ray wishes to speak on another topic. I suggest that we leave the topic of the tabling of this document, Senator Ray could speak and you could have a discussion and clarify the matter with Senator Harradine and Senator Kernot. Then she could seek leave to table either the whole document or a part of it and we will make a decision then. I call Senator Ray.
—A very wise course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address a few issues today on the communications industry and in particular television. I want to start my remarks by referring to an answer given by Senator Alston to a question he was asked earlier this week on advertising on gambling matters. This had been somewhat provoked by the comment on the weekend of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—and not a bad one, I thought—that he was concerned at the degree to which gambling was taking hold in this country. I must declare a self‐interest here: I like a punt. I was brought up in a racing family and I have been known on occasions—
—You weren't a jockey, were you?

—No, I was not a jockey, Senator O'Chee, but I was always big enough to carry one. I must say I have no philosophical objection to gambling. I quite like a game of blackjack or stud poker. Sometimes I have been foolish enough to play poker machines, knowing that it is only self‐laceration and you cannot win. I take out the odd lottery ticket and go to the races on Derby Day now. I was brought up in a racing family so I knew you could not win gambling. I know that you cannot win; I know that no‐one can win gambling.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not mind that the opportunity is available to people in casinos and elsewhere. What I object to is the intensifying pattern in my home state of Victoria for advertisements, false advertisements, on television showing how you can win gambling. We in Victoria have all seen them. I am not sure what happens in Queensland, Senator O'Chee's state. We have got all the TAB ads. The blokes are playing golf and one bloke pulls the covers off and there is a new set of Cobras. And they all gasp in amazement: how did he possibly get those? And he knocks the ball 280 metres down the fairway. Of course, they are Cobra clubs and he won them at the TAB. On the ads go: taking the spouse off to a restaurant and shocking the waiters by pulling cash out; gazumping the yuppie stockbrokers by saying, `I had a 15,000 per cent return from a bet at the TAB.' And on they go. There are now the ads for poker machines, with people winning jackpots. There are the ads for the casino, there are the ads for Lotto—all showing winners.

BREAK.PARA: If they were fair, they might like to go and film those who have had to join Gamblers Anonymous. They might like to go to those who have done their money. The fact is that in lotteries, the state and the operator take 41 per cent of the take straight off the top. The TABs take 15 to 17 per cent straight off the top. The only gambling game worth playing in Australia is blackjack, with a 98.7 per cent return to the punter. That is why the blackjack tables are disappearing, other than for high rollers, in the casinos right around Australia, and the machines are going in.

People will argue philosophically, `Leave it up to individual choice.' We do not do that with smoking; we have banned all ads on smoking. I think we should either introduce a very severe code of conduct on gambling ads or ban them outright. That is an authoritarian view and it is not necessarily shared around this chamber, but I certainly think that the ads currently appearing on television for gambling are outrageous and misleading and are doing great social damage. It is not a question of product differentiation here; it is encouraging gambling, and it is on the rise.

It used to be once that, if you introduced one more form of gambling, it redistributed the gambling dollar from, say, the racing industry to a lottery. There is increasing evidence now that the overall cake is rapidly expanding and mendicant states are using this as a way of financing public programs irrespective of the social damage that gambling is doing. So I do think the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) should not be quite as offhand as he was here in the chamber the other day and he should give some consideration, at the very minimum, to an enforceable code of conduct on gambling advertising.

The second issue to do with media I want to raise is the coverage of Super League by the Sydney broadcasting corporation of Australia. We know that the ABC is into networking. We know the economies of scale that networking provides. But, for heaven's sake, to block out the 5 to 7 p.m. slot in television in Victoria for Super League is an absolutely crass and stupid decision.

Any parliamentarian becomes multifaceted in their sports tastes, because we all come to Canberra. I confess that I enjoy rugby league and I always have. And I have started to understand and really enjoy rugby union at an international level. Victorians do not mind rugby league being on their television sets—even on the national broadcaster—at 11 o'clock at night. But, if you cut out that prime time viewing to see a few people run around the park, firstly, the ratings will collapse and, secondly, quality programs—like the Barchester Chronicles and all the Jane Austen stuff they run between five and six and the terrific wildlife stuff that we never see because we are on our way to Canberra between six and seven—will all go off the air. This is all because they want to do a network deal around Australia and that is driving the viewers away in the four Aussie rules states. This is because the ABC is totally Sydney centred—we all know that. All the arts programs are no longer being produced in Victoria and are centralised in Sydney. That is to the disadvantage of Australians and does not meet the ABC charter.

To make matters worse, last week what did we have at 9.30 on Saturday night? We had Super League. We had a referee shouting non‐stop into his personalised mike, so everyone turned off because they could not stand it anymore. Anyone who is home on a Saturday night would start with the great food program on SBS, switch across and watch Heartbeat and The Bill—as most people in this chamber would have done—and then settle in for a nice viewing evening, even though the cricket is not on on time. And we cop Super League! They should rethink this. By all means, cover the Super League. Put it on at 11 o'clock at night, when all the social isolates and recidivists—including me—can watch it, but do not put it on in prime time.

Let me move on to the third issue: the coverage of the cricket, which has had a bit of argy bargy around this chamber. Senator Alston came in and proudly announced that the final two sessions would be shown live. He gave the previous minister for communications a whack around the ears by referring to him as `a boy Bradman', which I found strange. I thought the previous minister would have enjoyed that appellation. But the fact is, when the acid was put on minister Lee in 1995, he got the full live coverage on free to air television in Australia. Senator Alston has not delivered the same product. However, he had one particular difficulty that minister Lee did not face. That is, networks, because of viewer loyalty, are reluctant to interrupt their normal ratings programs from 8.30 through to 10.30 by putting on a sporting event—we might actually get the televised rights to the one going on in the chamber in a minute—and that reluctance is understandable.

So, in getting the cricket from South Africa for the final four hours, Senator Alston would have met the requirements we put on him. We do not hold it against Senator Alston that it is live only on Foxtel. We understand that, even though Foxtel is wired up in the street where he lives, he has not tapped into it and has made the sacrifice the rest of us have made.

We are not getting it live for those two hours. When I saw the first test on Friday night last week, it came on at five past 11. It was 55 minutes late that night. Lo and behold, on Saturday night we were lucky: we got it live to air at 10 past 10 for the only time. What happened? Bad light stopped play at 10 past 12, and we missed out. But when I was here in Canberra on Sunday night, it did not come on at 10 past 10. They ran their movie through, and another half hour was missed. The same thing happened on Monday night. Last night, just as we settled in to watch it—because it was almost going to start on time—what happened? The Australian spinners knocked six of them over in an hour and a quarter, and we never got to watch it again.

Also, the final four full sessions are not being shown live to air in South Australia, Queensland and Western Australia because of the time difference. But we must give credit to Channel 7, because they are not doing delayed telecasts. They are picking it up live when it starts. I give them some credit for that. Still, something is better than nothing. I congratulate Senator Alston for getting some of the cricket on the air, but comparisons with the great efforts of Minister Lee are invidious in this case.

The final part of my Media Watch section this afternoon deals with the Whitlam lecture. People have been critical of that lecture being put on at 11 o'clock on a Sunday night and The Embassy program being cancelled. They have been rightly critical of some of the procedures—the lack of crediting and the deal between the ABC and the ACTU. That criticism is all valid criticism. But for heaven's sake, if the ABC is serious and suggests that this is a show or an event of national importance, why did they put it on at 11 o'clock at night and not advertise it? There is another group out there who would have wanted to watch this and were not given the opportunity because they were not given advance notice and they were not told about it.

Even though the government is probably right to look at the methodology of it, they should go a step further and say, `If you are right, ABC, that this is an event of national importance then, for heaven's sake, advertise it so that everyone can watch it.' I do not know how many of the people around this chamber knew the program was on that night. I think it was on a Sunday night and followed the Compass program. Some colleagues here, who are a little more devoted to their religious duties than I, may have actually picked it up. I must say that I am not a regular watcher of the Compass program. Well, let's be honest—I have never watched it but I am glad it is there.

In summary, I hope that Senator Alston will read some of these comments and take them on board, when he gets a spare moment—especially my comments on gambling advertising. That is a serious issue. It is an issue that his own Prime Minister has taken seriously and I would hope that he would take a serious view of it, in order to rectify the problem that exists.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, while Senator Ray—alias Senator Littlemore—was giving his contribution, I hope you sorted out the leave issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, I have. I think this is acceptable to all of those who have a view on this. I seek leave to table page 1 of the letter, which identifies the origin and the recipient and sets the context of the letter; item 1.3 on page 2 of the letter, which refers specifically to Dr Hapel; and the `yours sincerely' and signatory of the letter at the end of the letter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the short period allotted to me this afternoon to deal with an article that is in the Hobart Mercury today. It is under a very unfortunate heading and relates to a statement by one of the members for Denison in the state parliament, Mr Bob Cheek, who is the population task force chairman of the Tasmanian government.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the article, Mr Cheek, speaking yesterday from Melbourne, said:
A South Australian plan to offer cheap loans and initial accommodation to new settlers, would not attract the sort of people Tasmania wanted.
He is then quoted as saying:
. . . the sort of people we want down here are the sort to afford their own housing. We want quality people.

I have to say that most Tasmanians—and give us some credit on this—would absolutely cringe that that sort of class comment is made on behalf of the people of Tasmania trying to attract people to what is a very friendly and, I must say, not at all class conscious state.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Senator Bucket?

—Thank you for that, because I was wondering, Senator Mackay, if, in making that sort of comment, Mr Cheek had not been talking to a Hyacinth Bucket‐like character. Really it is one of those giant faux pas that Mr Cheek is wont to make from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is absolutely incredible that someone purporting to represent the state of Tasmania would say to the population of Australia, `We would like more citizens from other states to come and join us and live in our friendly state with its great environment and opportunities aplenty for people who are prepared to put in', and, almost in the same breath, say, `But we don't want you if you are not the sort of quality we want. After all, only a certain class of person is acceptable.' They have got to have money, apparently. That is the criterion according to Mr Cheek. That is a matter over which I and many other Tasmanians will cringe.

The sooner Mr Cheek apologises to the people of Tasmania and the people of the rest of Australia, withdraws the comment and, frankly, gets out of the position of population task force chairman the better. The way he is going, he will be heading a depopulation task force. Not only will people not be attracted to a state whose population task force chairman is saying which class of people is unacceptable there but also people in Tasmania, despairing of the quality of their government—given the comments of this task force chairman—may well be enticed to leave. I conclude by saying that I humbly apologise on behalf of the people of Tasmania for this crass comment by Mr Cheek.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond, so far as I am able, to the comments made by Senator Kernot. I point out to the Senate that Senator Kernot launched her attack on me without doing the courtesy, as is normally done, of advising me that was to take place. I happened to be at an Amnesty International parliamentary group meeting. I was phoned by my staff after Senator Kernot embarked on this underhand tactic. I then had to come out of what I believe to be a very important meeting to respond.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is the way that the Leader of the Australian Democrats is going to operate in the Senate, then I am most disappointed indeed. I defy Senator Kernot to point to anything I have said publicly in denigration of her office or, indeed, any colleagues here in a personal sense. I think it is very important for people in this chamber to respect their colleagues. If they are going to attack their colleagues in this chamber, then at least give them the courtesy of advice.

I understand that Senator Kernot has accused me of passing on a letter, written by a senior academic in the Australian National University, a senior scientist, Dr Hapel, head of the experimental haematology group at the John Curtin School of Medical Research, to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge). Why would one not pass to the minister any material that is appropriate when that minister is giving consideration to a matter of such significance as the chairmanship of the National Health and Medical Research Council? I do not need to relay to the Senate how important it is to have as head of that organisation a person not only who is a capable researcher but also who is able to discharge the office with fairness and who is capable of doing a good job in that particular area.

I wish congratulate Professor Larkin on his being appointed chairman of the National Health and Medical Research Council. I do hope that his time in that office is one that is devoted—I am sure it will be—to the improvement of medical research in this country. I hope that not only will he be devoted to the improvement but that also he will be able to redress some of the problems that have emerged. For example, Professors Baume, Kuhse and Singer were given scarce medical research funds to do a survey on euthanasia. For goodness sake! Here is something that ought not to have occurred and would not have occurred had there been a rigorous investigation of the application. Should these scarce medical research funds have been provided to people who were very much pro‐euthanasia? So one does look for more rigour in the process, as I indicated previously.

Getting back to the issues that Senator Kernot raised, of course I provided this to the minister. It was not for me to make it public then. Is she suggesting that I should have made this letter public and thus put Professor Funder under the public spotlight? Surely when one has a letter such as this one sends it to the appropriate minister and it is up to the minister to investigate whether or not that material should be taken into account in the exercise of the duty of the minister.

I remind the Senate that, prima facie, the letter I received from Dr Hapel was one which raised a number of questions, not least the question of the rights of persons with disabilities. In this particular case, as I believe the document Senator Kernot tabled shows, Dr Hapel's eyesight was in fact adverted to by Professor Funder. He said that the offer was conditional upon his undergoing appropriate medical evaluation. He had done that without discussing the matter with Dr Hapel. Where he got private medical information from I don't know. As Dr Hapel says:

As an innovative scientist poor eyesight is only an intrusion when it comes to certain aspects of bench work and in reading fine print in manuscripts. Given adequate technical support, there was never any reason why my scientific output would be impaired by my vision defect.

Let me say this: we are talking about a top scientist who is recognised internationally. For example, this top scientist won a fellowship from the international union against cancer, which enabled him to work at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York during recent years. He was awarded the Eleanor Roosevelt fellowship. To Australian scientists, that is a very rare event indeed. Dr Hapel is one of 21 recipients of such an award since the Union International Contre Le Cancer began its operation in 1961 and one of only five who are current members of the UACC Society of Fellows. The sort of derogatory comment made by Senator Kernot of Dr Hapel is a disgrace.

During his sabbatical as a visiting professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Dr Hapel made a construct to knock out the gene encoding the receptor for an important haemopoietic regulator, CSF‐1 (M‐CFS). Previous highlights of his career include the molecular cloning of the gene encoding interleukin‐3, the first demonstration of the role for T cells in recovery from togavirus infections, and the first demonstration that enveloped forms of poxvirus were responsible for transmission of disease following immunisation with killed vaccines. Dr Hapel has had 86 publications of his work, covering a variety of fields in biomedical research, of which three have been published in Nature and one in Cell, the two most prestigious scientific journals.

We are talking about a letter from that particular scientist and about the adequacy and the capability of Professor Funder to be chairman of the NHMRC. I passed that letter on to the minister. I think I did what I should have done in the circumstances. It was for the minister and the department to consider the relevance or otherwise of that letter and if they wanted to raise it with the professor. It was not for me to publicise the letter. That would have been unfair to Professor Funder.

Let me make it perfectly clear: there has been a beat‐up about this matter and some sections of the media have been involved in that beat‐up. I refer to the Sydney Morning Herald and Geoff Kitney's analysis of the reasons for the non‐appointment of Professor Funder. His comment noted that Professor Funder's `1990'—actually it was 1991—criticism of the John Curtin School of Medical Research at the ANU `went down very badly in some quarters'. Perhaps there should have been an extra sentence to indicate that one of those quarters was an Australian Senate committee which, after three days of hearings, crossed party lines in finding major shortcomings of process in the review conducted by Dr John Funder of the school. Surely it would not have been unreasonable to add that. We should expect some accuracy and fullness in reporting by the media about this.

And the Sydney Morning Herald also had an article by Dr Paul Komesaroff which indicated that the author was `Executive Director of the Eleanor Shaw Centre for the Study of Medicine, Society and Law in Melbourne'. What it did not say was that Dr Komesaroff is an employee of the Baker Institute and, as such, is presumably responsible to its director. And do you know who the director is? Dr John Funder. Wasn't that pertinent? Wouldn't it have been reasonable to expect that the Sydney Morning Herald might have made that comment? Yet it did not, and there is a number of other examples.

BREAK.PARA: Let me remind the Senate in pretty direct terms that the Senate committee was not convinced that the John Curtin School of Medical Research attached to the Australian National University should become part and parcel of a National Health and Medical Research Council group.

The diversity of scientific research in this country is very important. There are great issues at stake here and those issues should, of course, be considered very thoroughly by the research community as a whole. I believe that the research community as a whole will congratulate Professor Larkin on his appointment as Chairman of the National Health and Medical Research Council and will wish Professor Larkin the best in that very important and responsible position.

Again, I express disappointment that Senator Kernot has stooped to the level of the surprise tactic, attacking a member of the parliament, a colleague, without having the decency to notify that member. If that is the way she wants to play it, that is her decision. I do not intend to play it that way, and I do hope that her colleagues might have a word or two with her about that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. I refer to your unwillingness or inability yesterday or on the 7.30 Report on Monday to endorse the principle that, where a senator resigns and is to be replaced by a nominee of the party he or she was elected to represent, that party should be granted a pair until the replacement senator is sworn in. Are you aware that the Commonwealth Record of 4 to 10 May 1987 reports the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I believe that the person appointed to fill casual vacancies of this kind ought to be the person nominated by the retiring Senator's political party. Until the current impasse is resolved, the Opposition will continue to grant the Labor Party a pair in the Senate in relation to Senator Grimes' vacan cy. This means that the voting strength of Labor in the Senate will not be diminished in any way.'
Why is it that your own leader is prepared to support this principle, yet you are not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say it is astonishing that, with all the major issues facing this country—the challenge to small business to achieve growth, the challenges of unemployment, health issues, education issues and all the big issues facing Australia—after 12 months of opposition all this opposition can ask a question about is a pair in a hypothetical situation. We know what they are all about, because their total focus at the moment is on hounding Senator Colston out of office and their motive—retribution, revenge, punishment. They have a total preoccupation with it. As they said yesterday, they find him guilty of treachery and he will be punished. He will be hounded out of office. Now they are already planning on the spoils—who will get the pair.

ANSWER.PARA: This is an astonishing question. If ever there was a question that demonstrated how irrelevant the Australian Labor Party has become in the Australian political scene, it is this question—the first question; the question of the day. There are all these other issues. I thought I might have got something from you on national accounts or what is happening with unemployment—the big issues—and all you want to talk about is pairs. There is a total preoccupation with the internal affairs of the Labor Party and how they can punish someone and seek retribution from someone who decided to leave their midst.

The question is hypothetical. The quote from Mr Howard does not in fact say what you assert it says at all. I assume this hypothetical question refers to the situation of Senator Colston, who is a member of this place. I see no reason why he should be leaving. I actually believe in the presumption of innocence, which is very different to the ALP. But if an independent is leaving this place, he leaves as an independent. What is Senator Faulkner talking about?

What I suggest to the ALP is that they cease this preoccupation with their internal affairs; that they cease this hounding of Senator Colston; and that they start addressing some of the big issues that are facing this country. If they do that, they will be taking the first step on the long road to returning to being a relevant political force, because we see no sign of that today from that rabble over there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not true that the possible resignation and replacement of Senator Colston was raised by Queensland Premier Borbidge on the Sunday program? And do you or do you not support the principle that, where a senator resigns and is to be replaced by a nominee of the party he or she was elected to represent, that party should be granted a pair until the replacement senator is sworn in?

—As I said, this side of the chamber, the coalition side, supports the principle of innocence until proven otherwise—the presumption of innocence that this Labor Party scoffs at. There is no vacancy. I know of no expected vacancy. When a vacancy occurs, you will find out what flows therefrom, if and when it occurs. As I said yesterday, we do not find the relevant provisions of the Constitution ambiguous at all. I said we will stand by the provisions of Constitution both in letter and in spirit. I would have thought that that should be clear enough even for you.

—My question is to Senator Hill, Leader of the Government in the Senate. One year has passed since an overwhelming majority of Australians voted Labor out of office after 13 years, which included the worst recession in 60 years, one million unemployed, massively high interest rates and massive foreign debt. Will the Leader of the Government outline to the Senate the achievements of the first year of the Howard government? Does it still enjoy community support for its policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the honourable senator has returned to the big picture—what is important to Australians. What is important to Australians are government policies that are designed to reduce expenditure, encourage small business in particular, create jobs and raise standards of living. These are the important issues facing modern Australia. That is what this Howard government is all about, in contrast to your dismal efforts of concentration on and total preoccupation with the internal affairs of the ALP.

ANSWER.PARA: So it is not surprising that people like George Campbell are saying, `I don't know what the ALP stands for any more.' I am not surprised that we hearing that. I am not surprised that we are hearing such confusing statements from the now Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, as `We are going to have to start thinking of some policy soon—float one or two, to see how they run,' because that is the best that the ALP of today can offer. And it is not surprising in those circumstances that the people of Australia are still sending the ALP a clear message.

It is amazing that, after 12 months of hard decisions—albeit fair decisions—the Howard government is held in higher esteem than at the time of the election and Labor in lower esteem. Why in lower esteem? Because they have shown no signs that they have learnt any lesson at all.

The ALP gave Australians a million unemployed, business interest rates of about 20 per cent, bankcard interest rates of about 26 per cent, foreign debt of $150 million and a current account deficit of $180 billion. One would have thought that the first thing a party in that situation, unceremoniously thrown out of government, would say was, `We recognise that we let the Australian people down. We recognise that we made mistakes, and we are going to try to constructively work our way back.' Have we seen any sign of that? We have not seen one sign. All we have seen is a preoccupation with the internal affairs of the Labor Party and an attempt to seek retribution against one who left their midst. That is all we see from the ALP of today.

We are pleased—we don't dwell on it—that the Australian people are now endorsing us even more strongly than 12 months ago at the last election. We are pleased about it because we believe that it is a recognition that we did make the hard decisions in the first year. We tackled that deficit that we inherited, the one that Senator Cook told us did not exist: $8,000 million of deficit that actually in the end turned out to be nearer $10,000 million. We tackled it. We took the hard decisions to cut expenditure, but we did it fairly. We gave money back to families, who did it so badly under Labor's recession—the worst recession since the 1930s. We gave it back in the first year of government. We have put policies in place to stimulate and support small business—the provisional tax uplift factor. Labor put it up; we brought it down. Capital gains rollover—
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise on my left is far too high.

—I am making the point that, in only 12 months of government, we have delivered on so many of the major promises that were designed particularly to support small business and particularly to support families—those who did it hardest under Labor's policies. That's what the people—
—Rubbish!

—You can say `Rubbish'; you still aren't prepared to accept your fault. You are still not prepared to recognise that you were thrown out because you failed. You are not prepared to recognise that we were elected to do the job, and we are gaining the support we deserve.(Time expired)
—I have a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, you have outlined some of the important achievements, but could you provide the Senate with further details?

—On a point of order, Madam President, I know we were all being a bit noisy, but did you actually hear Senator Calvert's question? Can it be constituted as a supplementary question when he says, `Can the minister provide further details?' It does not relate to any part of the previous question or seek clarification or anything else. We know there is a wide ambit on supplementary questions, but that should be ruled out on the grounds that it is not relevant and is totally humiliating to Senator Calvert in having to ask it.
—It is certainly as wide an ambit as it could possibly be, but the supplementaries have a very wide ambit these days.

—I would like to tell this lot about the Natural Heritage Trust: $1.1 billion reinvestment in the Australian environment. At last, there has been a government elected that is actually going to do something about the damage that has been caused to the Australian environment. But, apart from that, let us look at what is happening to business.
—What about growth?

—I heard the interjection. Growth is still good in this country under policies that have been put in place for it. Retail sales picked up in January. Good news, Senator Bolkus. Business investment outlook remains strong—good news. Business expectations now are 10 per cent higher, Senator Sherry. Housing affordability is improving under the coalition government. Home interest rates are now lower: there have been three official reductions of interest rates since the coalition came to government. Profits are up—(Time expired)

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Argentina led by the President of the Senate, His Excellency Dr Carlos Ruckauf. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of the Senate, I invite the President to join me on the floor.
—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. Thousands of mainstream Australians are speaking out against your government's destruction of our national legal aid system. Is it not true, Minister, that the Common wealth's arrangements for legal aid are now going to be different in the ACT from what they are going to be in Queensland? Is it not also true that Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia and South Australia all look like going it alone—providing no support to the Commonwealth at all? Given the fact that the Attorney‐General has refused to take this matter back to cabinet, why is the Prime Minister, who has ultimate responsibility in such matters anyway, refusing to intervene to clean up this mess?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept that there is a mess. You do not understand that when we inherit a deficit of $8,000 million, we have to do something about it. We made the deliberate decision to cut expenditure.
—Order! Senator Cook!
—We made a decision to cut expenditure because we wanted to keep interest rates down, we wanted to keep inflation down and we wanted to keep taxation down.

—So we could create jobs, Senator Carr. We on this side of the chamber are interested in long-term sustainable jobs. We are interested in businesses growing and employing more Australians. It was not going to occur with an $8,000 million to $10,000 million budget deficit.

ANSWER.PARA: We have tried to share the cuts in expenditure fairly across a range of portfolio areas. In part, that has also meant that we have had to reorganise the delivery of some of those programs. What we have said on legal aid is basically that the Commonwealth will pay for legal aid arising out of Commonwealth matters and Commonwealth laws and we expect the states to pay for matters arising out of state laws. What is wrong with that? It is a perfectly legitimate position to adopt and a position that we have adopted. It does call for a federal response. I am pleased to see, Senator Bolkus, that some of the states are now coming to the table and entering into discussions. The principle is sound and we stand by the principle. If the principle is sound, why should the Prime Minister interfere?

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, you may not agree that the system is not a mess but hasn't the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia said that the legal aid system—the justice system—is in crisis? Is it not a fact that until now we have had an internationally respected legal aid system? Why has your government decided that it is not worth saving?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —For as long as I can remember I recall people saying that the legal aid system is in crisis. There is nothing new in that, Senator Bolkus. Even running a $10,000 million budget deficit, your legal aid system was still said to be in crisis. Perhaps the problem was that you sought to cover too much of the states' responsibility. We are seeking to return to a fair division under our federation of responsibility. Out of that we are already getting a negotiating process that will lead to reasonable outcomes.

ANSWER.PARA: You know, Senator Bolkus, as well as I, that too much of the legal aid money has gone to too few cases. Too few have benefited from it. It was badly in need of reform. Out of this process you actually end up with a legal aid system which is fairer to the average Australian.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know, it is the champagne set, the chardonnay set, the big cases. It is the masses who actually deserve support and benefit from this scheme. Out of what they are getting from us, they are more likely to get it. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Has the minister seen an article in the Age today entitled `Women lose their place in new halls of power', which alleges that the Howard government has abandoned women? Will the minister comment on whether such claims are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pretty clear indication of the distinction between our side of politics and the other that you rarely, if ever, heard a man asking a question about concerns of women in the previous government whereas under this government men and women are concerned about a fair go for women.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the article that you are referring to, Senator Eggleston. It is full of blatant untruths and misrepresentations. I would like to take you through some of the examples of the factual errors and the innuendo. For example, the article suggests that two months after the government knew about Ms Townsend's departure from the Office of the Status of Women, there has still been no appointment.

What are the facts? The facts are that there is a normal time frame when somebody is being appointed to the Public Service. We have not changed that. The process of finding a replacement for the head of the Office of the Status of Women commenced as soon as Ms Townsend announced her resignation on 17 December. A headhunting firm was chosen and contacted on 24 December, just one week later. That is the first time that an executive search company has ever been used, in addition to advertising nationally, to find a suitable person for the head of the Office of the Status of Women.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much is that going to cost?
—If you do not want an executive search, you should say so. We are casting the net as widely as possible to look for the most talented woman for the position.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Eggleston, you would be interested in hearing—even though the cockatoos opposite are obviously not—that the final interviews are to take place on 11 March. We expect that an announcement will be made soon after that.

Another of these furphies was that the Affirmative Action Agency has been effectively dismantled. That, again, is totally incorrect. The difference between the policy of the last government and this government is that we believe that there is a very positive role for the Affirmative Action Agency to play. There should be much greater emphasis on promoting best practice in corporate Australia.

From this year those organisations that have implemented a high quality equal employment opportunity program and have complied with the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act for three years will not have to submit a report for another three years. Annual reporting will still be required of other businesses. It is interesting that many of the businesses who have had annual reporting waived have said that they intend to voluntarily continue to report annually because they now view it as a very important and valuable performance indicator in their firm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—There are also suggestions about what has happened to the Office of the Status of Women. Let me make it clear to the Senate that the Office of the Status of Women now has a prime responsibility for policy development and coordination of policy development across the public sector. There are currently some vacant positions which are in the process of being filled. It is very important that that be a strong component which surveys the proposals coming from other departments and provides advice to the Prime Minister and me on that.

ANSWER.PARA: Another remarkable thing is that the article says that the federal government seems `alarmingly silent on the issues of superannuation for women and violence'. I do not know where that particular journalist has been for the last year—probably in the Antarctic. Even in the Antarctic they would know that there are two particular areas where this government has been particularly outspoken; one is on superannuation and retirement income for women, and the other is on the question of violence.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Retirement for women? Look at the retirement savings accounts that have been implemented by this government already—an election commitment. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator McKiernan wants to ask a question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President. I thought maybe I was standing for a photograph! My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, Senator Vanstone. I refer to your answer to a question I asked on 6 February, in which you said:

QUESTION.PARA: The claim we have used incorrect figures or admitted to using incorrect figures is untrue. The government has not used incorrect figures.

If this is true, how do you explain the fact that, in letters to the Victorian and ACT Attorneys‐General dated 10 January, Mr Williams admitted that Victoria was entitled to at least $29 million, not the $26.1 million previously claimed, and that the ACT was entitled to $3 million, not the $2.1 million previously claimed? If that is not admitting to using incorrect figures, what is? Minister, why did you mislead the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McKiernan, I gave you such information at the time as I had. I do not have any other information. If you believe that information is incorrect, quite obviously I will go away and have it checked. If it turns out to be incorrect, I will, of course, come back and correct it.
—Will you apologise?

—I have not been advised by the Attorney's office that that information is incorrect. It is not my view that I have been advised that, but I will go and check that. Senator West unwisely objects, `Will you apologise?' This raises yet again Gary Gray's comments recently—you might have seen them—on Labor's complete failure to accept what a disastrous government it was and, equally, its complete failure to ever apologise to the Australian people for everything it got wrong. In direct contrast—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—In direct contrast, whenever something has gone wrong, both in this portfolio and across government, this government has introduced a new sort of civility in government where it is no embarrassment to apologise.

BREAK.PARA: Senator West interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Madam President, there is a lot of quack, quack, quacking going on down there; it is very distracting. Senator West is not her usual charming self today. If there is something wrong with these figures I will come back and correct them, and I will apologise for them being wrong—of course I will.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I am being my usual charming self today, Minister. I am going to try to assist you in getting that information when you do come back to me. In the same answer that you gave to me last time—which was, incidentally, on 6 February—you said:

QUESTION.PARA: The figures for the 1994‐95 financial year were the latest complete data available to the Commonwealth at the time of the budget—and still are.

Minister, isn't it a fact that the Attorney‐General first notified the states and territories of their share of the legal aid cuts on 19 October 1997? Isn't it also a fact that the Commonwealth published a complete set of figures for the 1995‐96 financial year in the quarterly legal aid statistical bulletin on 9 October 1996—10 days before that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McKiernan, you are being your usual charming self today. You even have on, relatively speaking, a nice tie. It is not saying a lot in respect to you but, relatively speaking, you are on a winner today. Nonetheless, Senator, as I indicated to you, I gave you the information I had available at the time from a brief provided by the Attorney's office. I do not have subsequent information. If I get subsequent information indicating that what I have told you prior to that is incorrect, I will, of course, come back and correct the record. But I can only tell you I do not have any more information.

—My question is to Senator Parer, Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. Minister, while this government is considering, behind closed doors, whether or not a nuclear reprocessing plant should be built in Australia, are you considering, firstly, that reprocessing spent fuel rods creates more waste—up to 80 times by volume of waste—and does not reduce the amount of radioactivity that we have to deal with? Secondly, is your government considering that it will not be `economically viable', to use one of your favourite terms, as we produce so little waste, and therefore we will be pressured into either looking at reprocessing someone else's waste here or getting involved in a nuclear power industry in this country?
—Bet you they don't do it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I might get Senator Collins to answer that for you. The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation currently holds some 1,600 spent fuel elements. ANSTO's storage capacity, as you probably know, will reach capacity in 1998. It is not environmentally responsible to store the spent fuel rods indefinitely in their present form as the aluminium cladding may corrode over time, resulting in increased risk of radioactive release and environmental contamination.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht—Where are you going to build it? Lucas Heights?

TALK.START.PARA: —You kept putting it off, didn't you? The government recognises the need to take action on the disposition of ANSTO's spent nuclear fuel. One of the options under consideration is to condition the spent fuel elements domestically and encapsulate the resulting waste product using synroc technology. Synroc technology was developed by ANSTO and the Australian National University.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Schacht!

—Its technical qualities have been proven in extensive international collaborative studies. I know Senator Schacht does not believe in synroc processing. He takes the view that this is just some sort of a gimmick so that they can increase their research programs, but we won't go into that.
—For 15 years I've been trying—
—You were the government for 13 years, Senator, for God's sake.
—Order! Senator Schacht!

—Synroc immobilises radioactive elements within a crystalline structure or synthetic rock, effectively trapping the radioactive waste in a form similar to that in which the radioactive substances are found in nature.

ANSWER.PARA: Synroc technology has the added benefit that it dramatically reduces the amount of waste produced compared with other methods currently used. For example, to process ANSTO's current stockpile using synroc would produce only two cubic metres of intermediate level waste compared with around 250 cubic metres of concreted intermediate level waste if it was reprocessed at Dounreay. Consequently, the total amount of waste material generated from processing our own spent fuel would be minimal. It would be classified as long-lived intermediate level waste and would be suitable to be stored in an aboveground storage facility.

The Commonwealth and state consultative committee on radioactive waste management will be considering a proposal for a national intermediate level waste storage facility. The government is considering—I think this answers another of the senator's questions—processing only our own stockpile of spent fuel. Consequently, the size and cost of such a synroc facility would be much smaller than the commercial reprocessing facilities run overseas to cater for the nuclear power industry. Any processing would involve significantly lower levels of radioactivity than those already associated with ANSTO's current radiopharmaceutical production. Radioactive releases to the environment continue to be well within ANSTO's existing authorised public dose levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that quite comprehensive answer, but I ask: as Australia is the coordinator for the regional cooperation agreement for the International Atomic Energy Agency, will we be giving the green light to other countries in this area to start reprocessing if we move down the reprocessing road?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know of any proposals for reprocessing within our own area, to be frank. As I pointed out in the answer I gave, we have two options. One is to do the reprocessing ourselves and the other one is to send the spent fuel rods back to either Dounreay or the United States, which was their origin.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, was your spokeswoman accurately quoted in the Age on Monday when she said that any move to tighten eligibility for welfare benefits was not a savings measure? Was she speaking on your behalf? Under what circumstances would a move to tighten eligibility not be a savings measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously Senator Denman has a bit of a hazy notion about budgetary processes.
—You can talk!
—Order, Senator Carr!

—There are a lot of strands in developing good policy and good budgetary outcomes. Some of them relate to consistency of treatment of people right across the portfolio. Some relate to simplicity of administrative processes. A lot of considerations are taken into account. I am not prepared to discuss hypothetical questions about the future.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you explain to the Senate how it is possible to tighten eligibility for welfare benefits and not save money? Are you perhaps proposing to increase the amount of the benefits, or is it that you and your spokeswoman fail to appreciate the difference between savings and a spending measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I would think this supplementary question actually reveals part of the Labor Party's approach over the last few years. The tightening of eligibility is obviously very relevant to those who are poorly off in our country. Under the past regime, eligibility was pretty wide open for people who had quite affluent means. If we tighten eligibility for those at the top end of town, we have savings which are available to spend on the bottom end of town.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, will you confirm that your department and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy agreed upon a nominee to be the new Chairman of the National Landcare Advisory Committee? Can you confirm that a Mr Hockey from Minister Anderson's office had two meetings with that nominee? Can you confirm that, despite the backing of both departments, this nomination was overruled by cabinet? Can you confirm that your nominee was the former executive officer of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Rick Farley, who is eminently suited to be chairman? Lastly, can you confirm that the post of chair is now being offered to none other than the former Deputy Leader of the National Party, Mr Bruce Lloyd?
—If all that happened at cabinet, it must have been a meeting I missed.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could you confirm that your department's nominee was Mr Rick Farley?

—My department does not nominate a head of NLAC. NLAC is administered by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. If there was to be, as you say, a nominee from my department, it would be a nominee from me—not from the bureaucrats.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, I refer to your government's plans to close 35 Medicare offices this financial year. Do you recall health department officials saying at an estimates hearing last week that they expected to be closing branches around the end of the financial year? Can you inform the Senate what offices are expected to be closed and what consultation you are undertaking with the communities that will be affected, especially those in rural and regional areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I do recall the estimates committee hearing in which the opposition asked a number of questions on this matter. I have a briefing note about this. I will give you what is in it and see whether there is anything extra that you need. The government is about enhancing access to Medicare services to rural and remote Australia. We are not about reducing it. I am advised that by establishing up to 400 Medicare agencies in pharmacies over the next four years we will be taking access to claiming services closer to more country Australians than ever before. As part of implementing this broad network—
—We explained this to you the other night.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator West is interjecting so loudly that poor Senator Neal is covering her ears and intimating that she may put in a workers compensation claim, like the bloke who fell off the bike and the person who burned their arm. She is going to say, `West yelled in my ear.' Senator West can interject, but softly, softly, please.
—There is no point of order, but the level of interjections is far too loud.

—Some of these senators profess concern for some of the people in the rural areas of their states. It is strange that they are not prepared to listen to the answer as to how people in country areas in their states will have better access to Medicare claiming.
—I explained the problem about that last week; don't you understand?
—Senator West doesn't seem to understand that she is not being asked the question.

—That would be fun, wouldn't it! As part of implementing the broader network, the future of some Medicare offices is being reviewed. You were told that in estimates. I repeat Dr Wooldridge's commitment: there will be no closures of established Medicare offices without appropriate consultation with local communities potentially affected and without alternative claiming arrangements being in place. Labor talked about Medicare access as being a right for all, and it is. But it has been left to this government, the incoming government, to actively take Medicare services to rural and remote Australia rather than force many of these people to go many miles to the nearest Medicare office. As a Tasmanian, you should understand that as well as anybody, Senator Mackay.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, if you have a briefing note, could you please indicate which offices will be closed? Was the departmental official who stated that they expect to be closing branches around the end of this financial year right? If so, what consultation are you going to undertake between now and the end of this financial year? Please let us know which offices you intend to close.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously were not listening. Perhaps it was the noise from Senator West and Co. The advice I just gave you from the minister is that no offices will be closed until adequate and proper consultation has been achieved. I cannot give you any list of Medicare offices, because those consultations are to proceed.
—Will none be closed by the end of the financial year?

—You said, `By the end of the financial year.' We are several months away from the end of the financial year. I know you have trouble counting, but just try a bit harder! I do not think there is anything to be added to what I have already said to you. There is no more information yet available.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. What is the government's approach to the issue of electromagnetic radiation in relation to telephone towers? How does the government's responsible policy contrast with the political expedience and scare tactics approach of the Australian Democrats?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very serious issue and I think what is particularly serious from a political point of view is that Senator Allison not only is guilty of fomenting a public scare campaign but also is now very dangerously close to compromising her own leader. At lunchtime today, Senator Kernot introduced a shameless charlatan by the name of Dr Neil Cherry in relation to the emerging research on EMR.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, just listen to this. This bloke is a charlatan. His biographical details start off with mindless and irrelevant gobbledygook. He says that he specialises in solid state physics and electron spin resonance spectrum changes with exposure to microwaves specialising in atmospheric leeway.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I listened to Senator Heffernan's question and I did not think that anywhere in that question he asked the minister to go on a vilification campaign against a private citizen who has no right to defend himself in here. The minister really is using this place as coward's castle. He ought to be brought to order. If he has something to say about a particular person, let him go outside the door and say it.
—There is no point of order.

—The biographical details also say that he was a scientific team leader in 1995 for an appeal to the New Zealand environment court on a mobile phone cell site. What he does not of course say is that his side lost and he was discredited by the courts.

BREAK.PARA: This individual addressed a conference in Sydney yesterday. He is quoted as saying—if he has been wrongly reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, I am happy to accept that—that the Australian government had allowed the telecommunications industry to set standards for electromagnetic radiation from towers. The fact is that there is a joint Australian‐New Zealand standards committee which sets these standards for both countries. It consists of 24 members and only two of those represent telecommunications carriers. So his comments were a grotesque misrepresentation of the standard setting process. He is also reported to have said:
I seriously wonder how many children and adults will have to die before we will adopt proper public health protection standards.

That flies in the face of all of the evidence on this very important issue. This man is a rabid populist and totally uninterested in any considered scientific debate. His remarks are highly inflammatory. If one looks at the decision of the New Zealand environment law court, one will see that in a 43-page judgment handed down on 5 March last year the court held that there was not sufficient basis for concern about harmful health effects from base transceiver transmissions for mobile phones. They then said of this Dr Cherry that he had maintained that scientists in the thermal school were burying their heads in the sand.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President: I draw your attention to privilege resolution No. 9 and ask you to read it to the Senate. I think it is particularly relevant to the attack on this private citizen.
—I will draw attention to it at the end of the answer, Senator.
—Dr Cherry had maintained that scientists were burying their heads in the sand. The court said that other expert witnesses did not support his claim about two schools of thought.

BREAK.PARA: The court dismissed out of hand his suggested reasons why there had been a paucity of scientific studies. It said his evidence was that another witness had a pervasive effect on the content and conclusions of many of the international reports—in other words, the usual everyone else is wrong except me approach—and it found that to be an unhelpful distraction.

But the knockout punch was this. In a devastating understatement, it said, `The appellants called three expert witnesses to support their case. The first was Dr Cherry, a senior lecturer in agricultural meteorology at Lincoln University, whose academic training and professional experience are in other areas of physics but do not include health effects of radio frequency radiation.' This individual was asked today about his qualifications at the press conference and said, `I am not an expert in the classical sense, but I have been accepted by the courts.' The only court he refers to is the one which rejected his evidence and dismissed the application of those who were applying to it.

He is not interested in the facts. The facts are that the United Kingdom department of health recently published a national study which concluded that people living close to radio or television transmitting masts are not at increased risk of developing leukemia. Dr Cherry simply refuses to take notice of that. This man is not interested in the facts. It is very dangerous for the Australian Democrats to associate themselves with such a snake oil merchant. (Time expired)

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bob Collins

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President: with the greatest respect, the privilege of this parliament is an extremely important matter. I do rise on a matter of privilege. It is very rare, I am pleased to say, that we have the occasion when an individual—and I have not the slightest idea whom this person is—is attacked, particularly in a high profile time like question time, in parliament with the most extraordinary assertions about his—

INTERJECT.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of privilege.
