In terms of Senator Alston's preoccupation with the facts of the case, could I suggest that he test the facts of the case that he has made in referring to this person as quite a shameless charlatan by walking out that door and saying exactly the same things outside parliament. That would be a true test of the facts of the case that Senator Alston is putting to us.
—Order! There is no point of order. That is debating the matter.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, what action does the government propose to take to ensure that the Australian public is not misled on this important issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely why we have commissioned a $4.5 million program over the next five years to ensure that the government is well and truly up to date with international experience. There is absolutely no evidence to support these scare campaigns and they have been discredited in the courts.
—Why didn't you just say that?

—Because of the inflammatory language—like, `I seriously wonder how many children and adults will have to die before we adopt proper public health standards'—used by someone who comes to this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is we do have standards set by an impartial body. They are amongst the most stringent in the world. We are very seriously concerned about the issue and that is why we are conducting further research. We are in close contact with the World Health Organisation. We want to make sure that our citizens are protected.
We want sensible discussions on a scientific basis, not emotional nonsense that will simply mislead people into fearing that there is a problem when there is not on the evidence to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw senators' attention to the standing orders relating to parliamentary privilege that were adopted in 1988, specifically to paragraph 7 relating to raising matters of privilege and paragraph 9 about the exercise of freedom of speech and the subclauses of that particular section.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from France led by Monsieur Thierry Cornillet. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the chamber. I wish you a very happy visit to this country and hope that you will return again before too long.
—Hear, hear!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer representing the Treasurer. Minister, are you aware of the Treasurer's statements on the John Laws program on Wednesday, 26 February in reference to the so-called superannuation surcharge when he said, `Well, what it says is that, for anyone whose taxable income is over $85,000, the tax'—the tax—`collected on employer contributions will be 30 per cent rather than 15 per cent'? Is Mr Costello correct in saying that the superannuation surcharge is in fact a tax?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I point out to Labor senators that this is a question asked by you and you should listen to the answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first occasion I was in this Senate as a minister, the difference between a tax and a surcharge was canvassed. I will have to go back and check the Hansard , but I think I made it very clear to Senator Sherry that he should take his pencil out and note this down. I thought that that may have settled the argument for you, but, no, I see you continue to focus on the main game, Senator Sherry.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the John Laws show, I have not got the text of the John Laws show beside me. I would have to say that, given the capacity of people on your side to misquote, anything is certainly possible.

Senator Sherry, have you got your pencil out this time? Do you want to know the difference between a tax and a surcharge? You don't want to know the difference. He shakes his head; he says he does not want to know the difference between a tax and a surcharge.
Senator Sherry, the question has been comprehensively answered on this program. I have nothing further to add to the definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Senator Kemp, everyone in Australia knows this is a tax on superannuation. The Treasurer says it is a tax on superannuation. The budget papers describe it as a new tax on superannuation. Why won't you admit it is a new tax on superannuation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I don't know whether there is a standing order for overacting. Boy, I can assure you that if there was a standing order, Senator Sherry would be straight out the door. He would be slung out. What an incredible beat‐up! We have defined very carefully for you, Senator Sherry, the difference between a tax and a surcharge. In conclusion, Senator Sherry seems to have forgotten just one thing. Senator Sherry supports the 15 per cent surcharge. You seem to think the 30 per cent surcharge—
—The tax, the tax, the tax!
—There is fair too much noise in the chamber. Senator Kemp, you should direct your remarks to the Chair and not directly across the chamber, and you should ignore interjections.

—Thank you, Madam President. It is very hard when you get that loud barrage of people from Keating land over there. It is very, very difficult. Or have you buried him? That is what we want to know. Have you buried him or not? Not a word of apology. I have nothing further to add to the answer I have given. I might say it was a very, very comprehensive answer. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. It refers to the so‐called throwaway Chinese children, the hundreds of thousands of them in orphanages—mostly baby girls—who human rights groups consider have less than a 50 per cent survival rate. Is it a fact that Australia and the PRC have been engaged in discussions leading, hopefully, towards an inter‐country adoption agreement? Why is this agreement taking so long? Is it a fact that the fault is not really on the side of the PRC? Will the Prime Minister, during his visit to China, raise the matter with the Chinese government, after he has sorted the situation out here, and sign or make sure that there is an inter‐country adoption agreement between China and Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am familiar with Senator Harradine's interest in this matter because he asked me a question late last year concerning the failure to negotiate a bilateral agreement on adoptions with the PRC. He asked basically, as I recall, what action the government would take. This question is asked again in the same vein. I have to say, Senator Harradine, that it seems from the notes that I have been given that, regrettably, notwithstanding efforts that have been made in the meantime, there still does not appear to be a negotiated bilateral agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, a bilateral agreement is essential under Australian state law before an overseas adoption can take place. Interestingly, it is claimed that China has no bilateral agreements with other countries in relation to inter‐country adoptions, although that is disputed by at least one of the non‐government adoption agencies, which claims that it has an agreement with the United Kingdom, though we have not been able to substantiate that.

I said on the last occasion that a meeting was going to be held in Victoria. The Victorian government department seems to be taking the lead on the Australian side in this negotiation. There was to be a meeting in December to further coordinate Australia's efforts. I understand that took place and that our department of foreign affairs gave assistance in identifying the relevant Chinese agency with which to negotiate. Up until that time, it had been believed that there were at least two Chinese agencies and there had been problems as to which was the appropriate one to deal with. I understand that subsequent to that the Victorian Department of Human Services wrote on 14 January this year to the China centre for adoption asking that they might recommence negotiations. That letter was duly delivered with department of foreign affairs assistance. But, to date, there has been no response.

BREAK.PARA: You ask about outstanding issues. Two outstanding issues of which I am aware are, first, the requirement of the Chinese for payment of a $US5,000 bond and, secondly, a difference arising over permanent residence status that would be held by the adoptive children upon arrival in Australia and their loss of Chinese citizenship. There was a concern that, if the intended adoption broke down, the child could be left without citizenship. I understand that there is no reason why these two obstacles cannot be overcome.

As a strong supporter of inter‐country adoption, I would wish to see those issues resolved and Australia enter as soon as possible into a bilateral agreement with China that might facilitate adoption of these children. I will pass to the Prime Minister your request, Senator, that he intervene and take this matter up further with his Chinese interlocutors. I will ensure that he is provided with the base information that I have given to you today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the minister also provide to me or table in the parliament details, if there are any, of any attempt by the Victorian leaders in this area to properly pursue this matter over the last five years? What sort of correspondence has been had? My information is, from Chinese sources, indeed, that there has been a lack of proper interest by those who are leading on the side of the Australian negotiators?

—I will inquire as to what further information is available. What you have said, Senator, certainly seems to be inconsistent with what has occurred of recent times. I was told that this meeting would take place in December; it duly did. It seems that the parties who were to contribute to it duly did. It was followed up with correspondence to the Chinese. Our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has pursued that. So I am not sure of the longer term history, but I will see if there is anything else available. However, on the evidence I have, it looks as if they are certainly diligently pursuing the issue at the moment.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Now that question time is finished and so that we do not take up any of that time, could I ask you again to read out to the Senate the text of privileges resolution No. 9 so that Senator Alston may reflect upon the outrageous and unwarranted attack, under privilege, on a private citizen, Dr Neil Cherry, who happens to be sitting in the gallery at the moment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Clause 9 to which I referred reads as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Exercise of freedom of speech
That the Senate considers that in speaking in the Senate or a in committee senators should take the following matters into account:
the need to exercise their valuable right of freedom of speech in a responsible manner;
the damage that may be done by allegations made in parliament to those who are the subject of such allegations and to the standing of parliament;
the limited opportunities for persons other than members of parliament to respond to allegations made in parliament;
the need for senators, while fearlessly performing their duties, to have regard to the rights of others;
the desirability of ensuring that statements reflecting adversely on persons are soundly based;
and that the President, whenever the President considers that it is desirable to do so, may draw the attention of the Senate to the spirit and to the letter of this resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a question of you as to the conduct of the chamber.
—You would need leave to ask any question at this stage.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. It is quite proper for any senator during question time to direct a question to you. We have had this matter raised recently in the chamber where I did take a point of order and pointed out to a government senator that it was not appropriate, after the Leader of the Government has asked that further questions be placed on notice, for a senator to take the time of the chamber to raise a question with you.

INTERJECT.PARA: I would make the further point that the opposition is not aware of what the substance of Senator Abetz's question might be. There may be occasions where it is appropriate to grant leave, and I do not take the view that on all occasions the opposition would not grant a senator leave. But in the circumstances where clearly it is appropriate a question be directed to you during question time, and a senator who wishes to direct a question to you outside question time seeks leave to do so but has not had the courtesy to consult the opposition about it, the opposition takes the view that leave should not be granted—and, on that basis, leave is not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My point of order is on the conduct of matters in this chamber and, in particular, the matter that flippantly, yet appropriately, was raised by Senator Jim McKiernan about photographers. It is that matter that I want to raise by way of a question.
—It's not that bald patch, is it Eric?
—No, I am not like your former leader; my bald patch is on the front.
—Senator Abetz, leave is not granted.
—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. My point of order is whether it is appropriate for photographers to take photographs of honourable senators who are not seated. I understand that—
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is this—
—Order! There is a point of order that has been raised by Senator Abetz.
—It is an abuse. It is a question to you, and you know it.
—Order! What is your point of order, Senator Abetz?

—My point of order is very simply this: as I understand it, there is a ruling from either yourself or the Senate as a whole detailing the conduct of photographers in the galleries. It would appear, given today's papers, that that ruling has been breached. Madam President, my point of order is to request you to make a ruling and/or repeat the ruling that has been made previously and take whatever appropriate action is required against the photographers.
—Order! I do not need any further help on this. That is, effectively, the question that is being asked. I will make a statement on the matter at an appropriate time.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. You did not rule on the point of order that I made. You properly called Senator Abetz to address himself to my point of order. My point of order to you, Madam President, is this: this is an absolute abuse of Senate process on the part of Senator Abetz who, knowing full well that he is not entitled to ask you a question, abused your indulgence and abused the standing orders of the Senate to try to sneak his question to you under the table in the guise of a point of order. I put it to you that it clearly is an abuse of the processes and procedures of this place. I ask you to discipline Senator Abetz accordingly. Perhaps you may call him aside to your office and indicate to him what the courtesies of this place are, and perhaps you might also ask the clerk to run through the standing orders with him and give him a crash course.

—Madam President, on the point of order. It is very difficult to understand anything the Leader of the Opposition says when he is not shouting, but as I understand Senator Faulkner's point of order, he was raising with you that he originally raised a point of order and that you had not ruled on it. But, Madam President, as you may recall, he raised the point of order with you initially and then quite foolishly—and I am not sure why—ended up by saying, `Leave is refused,' and sat down. He was obviously confused about whether he was, in that contribution, refusing leave or raising a point of order. I would suggest that that is why you probably were not called upon to rule on that original point of order by the Leader of the Opposition.

—There is absolutely no confusion in my mind. Leave has been refused to ask a question. There is no question before me at the moment. I will answer and deal with the matter raised at an appropriate time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), to questions without notice asked by Senator Bolkus and Senator McKiernan, relating to legal aid.

This government is in self‐denial mode on the issue of legal aid, as with so many other issues. But they are on their own. They are in denial of the fact that this system is falling apart. They got it into this mess and they are taking no responsibility for it. They are not my words that the system is in crisis; they are the words of the Chief Justice of Australia who asserted towards the end of last year that our justice system is in crisis. That crisis has been occasioned by this government's inactivity and slashing of funding in the legal aid area.

National legal aid, the system we have in Australia, is one that is recognised internationally as being impressive. It is a system that is currently being destroyed by this government and this Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) and, by his inaction, this Prime Minister (Mr Howard). You could argue, in his defence, that the Attorney-General, at best, just does not know what is going on. In respect of the Prime Minister, he should know better and he should take an interest. So long as this issue continues—and it will continue—it will bleed on the government. At best, you could say that the current situation with the national legal aid system is fluid—at best, that is, if you were the government. But most objective commentators call it a crisis. You have to acknowledge, Senator Hill, that it is a pretty ordinary mess that you have got us into on this one.

When what is needed is reform, what we are getting is destruction—destruction of a system which is internationally recognised. What does the Attorney‐General do? He roams around in blissful ignorance of the fact that states are getting agitated, states are concerned that they have been ignored and states are monumentally upset that they have not been involved in the planning process. He does not assume his responsibility in this issue in terms of working it through with the states; he has not done so from day one, and he refuses to do so now.

The way the Attorney‐General is handling this issue, you can liken him very much to Chauncey Gardener in Being There. It is all happening around him; it is all falling apart around him. But this Attorney-General does not care, he does not want to care. As far as he is concerned, he has no time for it. You just have to look at the litany of stuff-ups in this area. You look at the figures they have been using—the figures used by the Attorney-General were incorrect. Even if you accept the formula that they are applying for the basis of allocation of funds, he asserted that he used the latest available figures. Evidence upon evidence, from commission after commission, to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee inquiry on legal aid has contradicted the Attorney. He has misled the parliament, but he has misled it in a way that he does not want to acknowledge.

The figures that were available to the government to base their formula on were the 1995-96 figures. As I said, legal aid commission after commission can show that. Figures are available monthly to the Commonwealth government as to how legal aid money is spent. The Commonwealth government has, until recently, had a person from the Attorney-General's department representing it on every state legal aid body. They knew what the latest figures were. In fact, they published the 1995-96 figures before they notified the states of their allocations under the new arrangement.

In the House of Representatives today, once again, the Attorney-General has misled the parliament by saying that with Queensland, on an agency arrangement, the federal government has what it has been seeking, when, in his letter of 10 January to all state and territory attorneys, he made it very clear that the Commonwealth government was not seeking agency arrangements. Either he misleads deliberately or the poor bloke has no idea about what is going on. What is the situation at the moment?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is highly inappropriate to refer to a minister of the Crown as a `poor old bloke' or `poor bloke'. I think some courtesies ought to be extended.
—I think the language used could be a little more delicate.
—The poor Attorney-General has no idea about what is going on. What is the situation at the moment?
—A very weak speech, Nick.

—I am glad you were there and I am glad you were listening. You need to, Senator Hill, because you got it wrong in question time today. First, you are presiding over the destruction of an internationally respected legal aid system. Second, we are sure that no matter what happens there will be less money provided for legal aid—$120 million less will be available through the legal aid system and access to justice systems, but it is going to be pretty close to that in terms of the slash back of this government.

SPEECH.PARA: We are also sure that some 250,000 Australian battlers, mainstream Australians, will miss out on assistance. We are also pretty sure that over 100,000 women will be the major losers as a consequence of your government's cutbacks in this area, Senator Hill. We know that the new formula is unsustainable. At a time of joint operations, cross‐vesting, and agreements to administer things jointly, having a formula that separates the Commonwealth from states is totally unsustainable.

We also know there will be no more Commonwealth money to the Attorney‐General's Department. So if this Attorney is going off and flicking extra resources to some states and not others, we know that money is going to come from within the A-G's department. Areas such as community legal centres, environmental defenders' offices and women's justice centres will be the losers.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Hill, you said today that we have a Rolls-Royce system. That is a dishonest assertion to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.

—You inferred that. The Attorney-General has said that we have a Rolls-Royce system by invoking the fact that 70 per cent of the money goes to 26 per cent of the cases. You know full well that the mainstream access user of legal aid gets handled and serviced very quickly. You also know full well that some cases have to go to court and some cases have to be battled out. That is where you get that imbalance of allocation of funds. An overwhelming proportion of people who access legal aid get handled and processed for very small amounts. That is the evidence before us. It is the gall of the government to call these people—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to rebut what the opposition has said, in particular Senator Bolkus's submission, with respect to the Attorney-General (Mr Williams).

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the facts. What we have here is a situation where the Attorney-General has negotiated an agreement with the ACT in relation to legal aid. What is more, in relation to the Queensland Legal Aid Commission there have been further negotiations where the Commonwealth stands ready to conclude detailed negotiations with representatives of the Queensland government to ensure that there is continuity in the arrangements for joint delivery of Commonwealth and state legal aid services in Queensland.

Indeed, the Attorney-General for Queensland has announced that there will be a reconstitution of the present Queensland Legal Aid Commission to achieve greater efficiencies while still allowing business as usual at the shopfront for legal aid. So what we have in Queensland is a change within the state itself and a situation where the Commonwealth has negotiated with that state, and an agreement there is imminent.

BREAK.PARA: It has been stated by the Attorney-General that he has been keen to conduct negotiations with the various states in a bilateral fashion and that it has been difficult to negotiate with the states and territories as a whole. That is quite reasonable. So for Senator Bolkus to say that there is anything unusual in this approach is quite absurd. What the Attorney-General is doing is negotiating with each state and territory on a discrete basis. The agreement with the ACT is heartening and, with these two developments in legal aid, it would appear that the Attorney-General is well on his way to solving the legal aid problem.

I want to hark bark to the question of these figures. The Attorney-General stated that the initial cuts were based on figures which were only available from the states themselves. These figures were for 1994-95, and the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee received evidence that the Commonwealth could only rely on those figures provided by the states themselves. So what the Commonwealth has to do is to get those figures from the states in the first place. How else can the Commonwealth negotiate any deal or any resolution to this problem if it is not getting the up-to-date figures from the states?

With respect to the fact that Senator Bolkus has said that it has been stated by the judiciary that legal aid is in crisis, I believe the comments that are alluded to refer in a wider sense to the judicial system. Part of this whole situation regarding legal aid requires scrutiny of the courts themselves to ensure that the courts themselves are running as efficiently as they could be. That is part of the Attorney-General's scope. The Attorney-General has stated time and time again that he wants to ensure the efficiency of delivery of service; that is, that the legal aid dollar goes as far as it possibly can. I believe that the states, in their own way, would want to see that as well. So we have here a situation where the Commonwealth and state governments really have a similar goal, and they can achieve it by negotiation.
On 8 February the editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

Mr Williams shows no sign of budging. Nor should he . . . No amount of other urging has led lawyers to reverse the trend towards ever‐rising costs by, for example, bringing the length of trials back to something like it was before the days of taxpayer‐funded legal aid. That funding has flowed too freely and Mr Williams is right to begin to turn off the tap.
Similarly, the Weekend Australian editorial of the same weekend stated:
. . . Mr Williams is right to insist the States must do more to make legal aid work properly. There seems no good argument why legal aid should be spared a significant cut at a time of austerity.

We have been left an outrageous situation—a budget deficit of enormous proportions. There have been cuts across the board. Legal aid is no exception to that. It would be irresponsible not to address that situation, and that is what the Attorney-General is doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Senator Ellison) in speaking on this motion to take note of answers given by Senator Hill and Senator Vanstone on the question of legal aid.

SPEECH.PARA: The parliamentary secretary relied on media comments to support the actions of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams). I am not going to rely on media comments to try to turn the argument around against him. I am going to use comments of one of his Liberal Party colleagues, the Attorney-General in Western Australia, the Hon. Peter Foss QC, MLC, who is pretty forthright in his argument about what is happening in the Australian legal aid system. In a letter to Mr Williams, dated 19 February this year, Mr Foss had this to say:

You have created a crisis by your unilateral decision and now you are saying that this imposes some duty on us to meet you part way. I would have thought the duty was on you to fix the mess you have caused.
That is from a member of the Liberal Party government of Western Australia. That is from the state Attorney-General, Peter Foss, addressing the Liberal Commonwealth Attorney-General in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another chardonnay socialist!

—I do not think they are chardonnay socialists. I think Mr Foss on this issue had the interests of the constituency of Western Australia in mind when he wrote his letter to Mr Williams. I certainly hope so. I look forward, as a member of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, to meeting with Mr Foss at some time in the future and to hearing at first-hand his evidence as to what is happening with the Australian legal aid system, as the committee has heard from two other attorneys from the states and two further attorneys from the two territories.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Foss is willing to work with the Commonwealth to resolve the crisis in legal aid, as he stated in his letter to Mr Williams. He said:

I have no problem with money being provided on the level of need. Western Australia can always demonstrate level of need due to the size of our State and the extra costs in trying to service it. However, I have a feeling that by "need" you are referring to the incidence of Commonwealth matters, and to call that "need" is an excellent example of what George Orwell would call "double speak".

I am not having a go at Mr Williams at all. That is his colleague Mr Peter Foss, a colleague of Senator Ellison, who has taken the fight right up to the Attorney to try to avert the crisis that Mr Williams and the cabinet has caused in Australia by virtue of their decisions.

Mr Foss's letter has been leaked to the media and it is out there for people to see. I just want to address the matter that I raised again in my question to Senator Vanstone, the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I asked about the collection of statistics and I alleged in my question that in the answer she gave to me on 6 February she had misled the Senate. The statistics were available to the Attorney-General when the calculations were done and the states were given wrong figures on wrong statistics. That is clearly on the public record. Yet we have not have had a retraction of that.

She has been given a further chance today and indeed the Attorney-General has been given a further opportunity today to correct the record. I wished Senator Ellison had been on the other side of the table when the Senate estimates committee was addressing these questions to the department last week. Perhaps we might have got the record straight. Unfortunately, even after the hours of questioning, it appears there is a great deal of confusion. Part of the reason for that is the Attorney‐General's Department as the full facts of the matter are not out there on public record.

One important point that needs to be made in all of this argument, not necessarily a political argument, is the cost of collecting these statistics. It has been argued to the committee that one particular Legal Aid Commission spends some 12 to 15 per cent of its budget collecting the statistics and providing them to the Commonwealth, yet the Commonwealth—when push comes to shove and it is really needed—gets the figures wrong. But like so many other matters—this happened with the Attorney-General's Department since this administration took over—whenever an error is exposed in the calculations it is always somebody else's fault. On this occasion statistics are collected by the commissions for the Attorney-General's Department and the Commonwealth got them wrong.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —In this discussion about legal aid commonsense really has to prevail over the tawdry politics we have witnessed from Senator Bolkus and Senator McKiernan this afternoon. There is no doubt that legal aid is an important institution in this country and has served Australia well.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite would be aware from their time in government that whenever the Commonwealth and states start renegotiating deals there will be all the necessary posturing and muscle flexing by both sides before commonsense prevails and an agreement is reached. As the honourable Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison) has pointed out to the Senate, an agreement has already been reached with the ACT. Queensland does not seem to be far off and we still have another three months to go before 30 June 1997, which will be the day when the agreements expire.

BREAK.PARA: It is interesting to note that in the contributions of honourable senators opposite none of them referred to the fact that the previous Labor government complained that state and territory legal aid commissions were diverting Commonwealth funds away from issues of Commonwealth interest, particularly family law, but they never sought to correct this anomaly. So when the Labor Party was thrown out of office they were already in the throes of looking into this situation. They themselves had come to that point of view either rightly or wrongly.

The other point is that I am astounded honourable senators opposite are not prepared to recognise or indeed detail in any way the question of why this government has had to consider making any expenditure cuts whatsoever. The reason is clear and is very simple. You people went to the last election promising that the budget was in surplus. We got in and found that you were out only by a factor of $10 billion! If ever Senator McKiernan wants to come into this chamber and complain about somebody getting figures wrong, rather than talking about a few million dollars in legal aid, he might like to talk about $10 billion of the whole federal budget which his party, through the then Minister for Finance, now Leader of the Opposition, misled the Australian people about.

The Labor Party can sit there and throw all the stones they like but the people of Australia know that the real justice issue is: do we as an Australian parliament corporately give to the next generation of Australians a huge debt because we want to live beyond our means? Or are we as a parliament going to be saying to them, `We are not going to leave you with an outrageous legacy of debt. We are in fact going to give you a country with a balanced budget that is not outrageously in debt.'?

That is a real justice issue which affects each and every Australian and that is what we have been charged to do, to provide justice to the Australian people by providing them with a balanced budget. Ten billion dollars worth had to be made up as a result of the former government's negligence. Unfortunately, part of the cuts that we have had to implement— and it gives us no joy in doing so—is to clean up Labor's mess.

It is very disingenuous of those opposite to beat their breasts and say that this is something that is really bad. Why do we have to consider these cuts? Because of your profligacy, because of your over‐expenditure, your view that there was no tomorrow and damn the next generation. You had no interest in their future. You said, `We will just spend and try to keep in government.'

The real issue of justice in all this discussion is the kind of legacy we leave to the next generation. There is a lot of good happening in Attorney-General's, not the least of which is the appointment of the honourable parliamentary secretary. I am sure he will play a very important role in that position. The Attorney-General is on the way, the ACT has been bolted down and Queensland is just about there. We will be in a position where legal aid will be continued to all the people of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Heffernan today, relating to potential health effects of exposure to electromagnetic radiation associated with telecommunications equipment.

I need to say at the outset that I was appalled and ashamed to hear the remarks made by Senator Alston. I have become used to a level of personal attack from the minister. Not only has he directed remarks to somebody outside this chamber, but he has directed them to somebody in the gallery who was listening to those remarks, and I thought that was indeed shameful. I say again that I am appalled and ashamed and apologise to Dr Cherry for those remarks directed towards him.

As I understand it, this is an unprecedented attack on a citizen who has no right of immediate reply. Not only that, but it is of course most untrue. Most of the remarks made by Senator Alston were highly defamatory and Senator Alston would realise that it would both be stupid and require more courage than he has to repeat those words outside this chamber.

I was immediately reminded of that phrase that is so often used, `Methinks he protesteth too much.' The measure of this attack indicated to me that what is being said by the Democrats, by me and by eminent scientists such as Dr Cherry is hitting home. Perhaps this is striking a chord which the minister is not prepared to hear.

Above all else this issue is about public health. That is another reason why we in this chamber should be so worried, that a minister who is responsible for telecommunications has so readily dismissed the work of scientists, and I am not just speaking of Dr Cherry, but also of the other scientists whom he represents. He came along to the Senate today and spoke in the committee room at lunchtime. He talked about the work of those other scientists right around the world. His message to us was that as parliamentarians we have an obligation to have an open mind, to take on board all manner of views, research and work that is being done in this field and to simply hear and listen to that work in order to make sensible judgments about what we do as people who write the laws of this land and who have the responsibility to protect the health of Australian citizens.

It is an indication that our minister does not take this role seriously and that he has chosen to make these immoderate and outrageous remarks in this place today. It is trivial by comparison, but I want to refer to some remarks made by Senator Alston just a couple of days ago. He was referring to a remark made about Senator Newman. I gather that Senator Newman was called a `dope'. The response Senator Alston gave was:
I think you ought to make it clear that this sort of sledging should not be allowed to continue.

Clearly what we have seen here today is not an ill-considered, off‐the‐cuff remark about somebody being a dope. He has made a five‐minute long unrelenting attack on an individual who has no right of reply and who has also demonstrated that he is a learned and very well informed scientist in this field.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Alston shows his ignorance and lack of willingness to open his mind and listen to the scientific discourse. He stands in line with all those other conservatives over time who have fought very hard to protect against those who warned of the dangers of things like tobacco smoking, DDT, setting off bombs in this country, seat belts and the like. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —There are only a couple of minutes left and I understand Senator Ferguson wants to make a comment, which may be a bit difficult. I was appalled at the remarks made by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) when he described Dr Neil Cherry as a shameless charlatan. Then in his supplementary he called for there to be a rational debate about the issue of electromagnetic radiation emissions. How can you call for a rational debate when you immediately start, in answer to your own dorothy dixer, to slag somebody who has been participating in that debate, even if you disagree with that person 100 per cent?

SPEECH.PARA: We have before us in the Senate a massive number of telecommunications bills. One of them deals with the future infrastructure of telecommunications in this country, including the placing and siting of mobile telephone towers. All around Australia, local communities, who are not shameless charlatans by any means, are asking relevant questions about the siting of those towers.

The opposition has said to the minister on a number of occasions, through the Senate committee looking at this legislation, that we want to get a rational outcome, a proper process of management of these towers where the community has an effective say. That has not been helped by the minister going bananas in here today in his description of a member of the public who has a concern about this.

I met Dr Neil Cherry today at a private meeting with Senator Allison and Senator Crowley. He did not strike me as a lunatic, an idiot or a charlatan. I may disagree with some of his views. I would also point out to Senator Alston that Dr Cherry admitted to me that, in 1987, he stood as a Labor candidate in New Zealand. I am surprised that we did not get him bagged for that as well. He also pointed out that he was subsequently elected to a regional local government body with a substantial majority by the votes of local people. So this is a person who has put his credibility on the line and has been supported by the public in his own country.

Yesterday, when I saw on Channel 2 news a segment of Dr Cherry speaking at a function in Sydney, I actually rang the minister's office to say that this was an example of why this issue should be treated very cautiously and sensibly, not expecting the minister to come in here like a ranting, raving maniac to bag an individual whom he has yet to meet and whose arguments he is yet to hear. The minister has put this debate backwards by a large degree by attacking an individual rather than arguing on the merits of the argument. And that is not unusual for Senator Alston, unfortunately.

This is going to be an ongoing debate in this community and, unless it is handled rationally and sanely, we will go nowhere with it. Unfortunately, Senator Alston is going to encourage those people with fears about it to think there is a conspiracy by the government, because the minister is attacking an individual and not arguing on the merits of the issue. They will take this as evidence that there is something being hidden, because Senator Alston is not arguing the merits of the argument; he is attacking this individual. I believe that, when this is debated in the Senate in a couple of weeks, this issue will get a proper airing. I only hope Minister Alston participates in the debate sensibly and rationally and takes account of very moderate views across a broad range of this community concerned about electromagnetic radiation emissions and does not bag anybody who disagrees with him. If that is the case, we are going down a very unfortunate road.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, I did not interrupt Senator Schacht but I point out Senator Schacht's reference to Senator Alston as `a ranting, raving maniac'. I am sure it would not worry Senator Alston. I think this hardly adds to the tone of the debate, particularly in view of the fact that Senator Schacht's whole speech was about the tone of the debate, and attacking and using intemperate language, yet he was using it himself. Perhaps Senator Schacht might like to withdraw his remarks.

—On the point of order, at least Senator Alston has an opportunity to come back here and attack me and get stuck into me whichever way he likes, and that is a fair cop. I never complain about that; that is the robust nature of the debate. But when an individual who does not have the right to come in here and defend himself—and who can only put a report in at a subsequent privileges committee hearing, if the matter went that way—is described as a shameless charlatan, I do not think it is unreasonable to say to the minister that he was `ranting and raving' making those sorts of remarks. Therefore, I do not think they are unparliamentary in the context of how this debate unfortunately started.

—I heard the comment clearly and I thought the minister was likened to something like that. Perhaps for the second time today I could say that a little more delicate language could be used sometimes. The time for taking note of answers has expired.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned respectfully submit that Social Housing is a major social safety net, crucial for all Australians.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Senate to maintain a commitment to the buying and building of new housing properties. The new Commonwealth State Housing Agreement must provide the States with monies to buy and build more Public and Community Housing. Dismantling the safety net of Social Housing will mean homelessness, overcrowding and the scrapping of public housing redevelopment plans, all of which will impact on the most disadvantaged groups in the Australian society.
Your petitioners support an increase in assistance to low income earners in the private rental market, but not at the expense of Public and Community Housing.
Your petitioners thus urge the Senate to reject current plans in the area of public and community housing.

PETITION.TITLE: Telstra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that citizens of the City of Rockingham, Western Australia, draw to the attention of the Senate the exclusion of Rockingham from Telstra's designated inner city area. We further point out that Rockingham is on the very edge of the inner city area and portrayed as being part of the metropolitan area, yet a telephone call to Perth is charged at the Community Call rate.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate supports a review of the boundaries governing telephone call types and that STD telephone charges be removed for calls between Rockingham and Perth.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Denman, Sen Kay; Faulkner, Sen John; Ray, Sen Robert
PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable overseas `active service' under `Operational Service' at Section 6(1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

A defined group of Australians, who served in the Malaya area, being members of the Royal Australian Navy so affected, have been wrongly excluded, whereas members of the Army and Air Force were not so excluded, and this is supported by documents in the Australian Archives and elsewhere on public record.

Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for benefits under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnam Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of whom appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then secretly `unallotted' to enable the introduction of the excluding legislation.

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962, which act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) the Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of Australian citizens' honourable service with the Royal Australian Navy for Australia, Britain and Malaya, whilst on `active service' in the Malaya campaign between 1955 and 1960.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that 15 sitting days after today I shall move that the following delegated legislation be disallowed:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Airports (Building Control) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 292 and made under the Airports Act 1996.
2. Bankruptcy Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 263 and made under the Bankruptcy Act 1966.
3. Family Law Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 265 and made under the Family Law Act 1975.

4. Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports)(OECD Decision) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 283 and made under the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989.
I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with this legislation.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include administrative decisions which may not be subject to external review of their merits; defective procedural provisions; absence of the right to respond to adverse material; and defective drafting. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Airports (Building Control) Regulations Statutory Rules 1996 No 292

BREAK.PARA: The Regulations provide for the control of building and other work at airports and for certificates of fitness for such building work.
The Regulations included the following apparent anomalies:
(a) decisions by State and local government authorities or bodies, and by individuals or corporations appointed as airport building controllers, which were subject to review by the Commonwealth AAT;
(b) discretions with regard to building standards and building approvals, with no apparent review by the AAT; and
(c) inconsistent time limits within which an airport building controller must make decisions.

The committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on whether there are any administrative or legal problems with AAT review of non‐Commonwealth entities; whether AAT review is available for all discretions; and about consistent time limits for decisions.
The Regulations provide for matters consequent upon the passing of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Act 1996.

Regulation 15.06 provides that the Inspector‐General may terminate the membership of a number of statutory committees. The reasons for termination include, among other things, physical or mental incapacity and neglect of duty. This would have a serious effect on the reputation of the member involved, but the regulations do not provide for a statement of reasons or for an opportunity to respond to adverse material.

Also, the Explanatory Statement advises that it is the intention of regulation 16.11 to provide for AAT review of decisions made under regulation 16.10. However, that provision as drafted does not effect this intention.
The committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on a member's right to respond to any allegations before removal from a committee, and on the drafting of regulation 16.11.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Family Law Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996 No 265

BREAK.PARA: The Regulations provide for new procedures for parentage testing.

Regulation 21D provides for a laboratory accredited by the National Association of Testing Authorities to carry out parentage testing procedures in accordance with standards of practice which entitle the laboratory to be so accredited. The accreditation of a laboratory appears to be a commercially valuable privilege.
The committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on the process of accreditation and the rights of review for laboratories which are refused accreditation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports)(OECD Decision) Regulations Statutory Rules 1996 No 283

BREAK.PARA: The Regulations provide for an approval regime for the export or import of hazardous waste.

Regulations 16, 23 and 29 set out matters which the Minister must consider when dealing with applications relating to hazardous waste. These provisions, among other things, require the Minister to be satisfied that the applicant is a suitable person to be granted a particular permit and that for these purposes the Minister must consider both the applicant's financial viability and previous record on environmental matters.

Similarly, regulations 34 and 41 provide, among other things, for the Minister to revoke or vary a special permit if the Minister becomes aware that the applicant gave false or misleading information or did not disclose information which ought reasonably to have been disclosed.

The committee has written to the Minister suggesting that it may be appropriate for the Regulations to provide for applicants to be made aware of adverse material, and to be given the opportunity to respond to it, before any such decision is made.
