DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 473, standing in my name and relating to the reconvening of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee, be taken as formal.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Faulkner moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 473.

This is an urgent matter. It is vitally important that the Senate estimates committee has an opportunity to fully investigate a range of allegations that have been made against Senator Colston. There are quite a number of issues that need to be clarified as soon as possible. I think it is important to put this particular motion in context. The Senate estimates committee is our pre‐eminent mechanism in terms of accountability—parliamentary accountability and government administration accountability—and the administration of the parliamentary departments.

It is true that a number of allegations were canvassed at estimates committees last week. But of course there also are a range of new matters that have arisen out of those issues that were canvassed at the estimates committee. No doubt they have arisen as a result of the estimates committee hearings. I think in particular there were some matters referred to by the Usher of the Black Rod, Mr Rob Allison, on the Channel 10 news on Sunday, 2 March. Mr Allison is quoted as saying on camera:
It would appear, from the airline schedules, that Senator Colston was in one place when his travel allowance claim suggested he was in another.
The interviewer asked a question. Mr Allison said:
At this stage, it appears that the allegations can be proven on the documentation.
The interviewer said:
There are eight suspicious dates where $140 a night travel allowance was claimed.
Mr Allison said:
Well, I would imagine that Senator Colston has a case to answer.
I think senators would also recall that these issues were raised in Melbourne's Sunday Age on 2 March. Paul Daley, their national affairs correspondent, wrote:

The embattled independent Senator Mal Colston was paid up to $140 a night in allowances for staying in Canberra at least eight times while airline records indicate he was elsewhere, Senate officials have discovered.

One of the Senate's chief administrators, the Usher of the Black Rod, Mr Robert Allison, said random checks with airlines by his department had uncovered flight information that contradicted the senator's travel allowance claims in 1994 and 1995.

The Usher of the Black Rod was quoted in the Sunday Age and direct to camera on Channel 10 news, and then on 3 March Mr Harry Evans, the Clerk of the Senate, circulated a disclaimer in relation to Senator Colston's travel. On this occasion Mr Evans said that press reports have cited an officer of the Department of the Senate as a source of a suggestion that there are discrepancies in Senator Colston's travel and travel allowance payments, and these reports are not correct.

These matters have arisen from the estimates committee. It is appropriate that the estimates committee be reconvened to deal with them. It is not unusual for Senate estimates committees to be reconvened in this way. There are many precedents. The most recent ones I can recall related to the Wright family affair and further investigations into the DDB Needham gun buyback rort. That happened just last year. On 7 February 1995 Senator Kemp successfully moved a motion to reconvene the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee to deal with the National Media Liaison Service.

This is an urgent matter. We do need to get to the bottom of what is happening in the Department of the Senate. We need to know what they are doing and why they are doing it. It is appropriate that this particular Senate committee meet, and meet quickly, to deal with these very serious matters. I commend this motion to the Senate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is totally without merit. The fact is, of course, that estimates committees are there for a purpose: to scrutinise government expenditure. The opposition has had all the time in the world to play these sorts of games, and they have done it to the hilt. They have made every use of every parliamentary device to try to denigrate Senator Colston and to keep this issue alive. They have just about reached the stage where the view of the gallery is that they have dramatically overplayed their hand.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that Mr Beazley was terribly nervous about this whole issue from the outset. He basically disowned Senators Carr and Ray when he was given the opportunity to support them on a Channel Nine program on 16 February. Quite clearly he would now be very concerned that, in putting down all those questions that Senator Ray put down yesterday and descending to the level of alleging that people were speeding in the car park, it is quite clear that they have reached the level of desperation.

As far as this motion is concerned, it is quite clear that the Labor Party is not seriously interested in exploring the issues. If they are, they will have plenty of time to do that when the estimates committees next convene in a couple of months time. But that is not what they are interested in. They are interested in keeping the heat on and trying to keep—

TALK.START.PARA: —When do the estimates committees reconvene?
—It is in May, isn't it?
—Yes, 7 May.

—So! If it is an important and ongoing issue, then it can be scrutinised in the proper processes. You are not interested in that. What you are interested in is trying to ensure that you have as many media opportunities as you can to keep the pressure on and to get some momentum.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that you have given it your best shot, you have got down into the gutter, you have Senator Ray boasting that he is a very ignoble person. I had not thought that he was until I heard him confess that, but I suppose that is the tag he wants to wear. He is making it very plain that this is entirely an exercise in retribution and revenge that has nothing to do with any honest assessment of these issues.

We all know the matters are being examined by the Department of Administrative Services. Other matters have been referred elsewhere. Those inquiries will run their course. If you have any material you want to bring to the attention of the relevant authorities, you can do it. But simply saying, `I read something in the newspaper and therefore I want to convene a special hearing of a parliamentary committee,' is quite unprecedented.

TALK.START.PARA: —The words are straight out of the Usher of the Black Rod's mouth.
—But that is where you got them from. You got them from the Sunday Age and the Channel 10 news. That is where you got them from. What are you carrying on about? The motion says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the consideration of additional estimates . . . to consider evidence raised in the Sunday Age . . . and on 10‐Capital television news . . .

In other words, you thought, `I saw something on the news. I think we might be able to get some political mileage out of it. Therefore, we should convene a special hearing of a parliamentary committee.' In other words, who cares about the cost of it, who cares about whether this is really achieving any part of the democratic process. No, you want to pursue this issue as far as you possibly can to milk every last ounce of it. Of course, this is just another grubby tactic in that approach. We all know that. It is quite transparent. What you should face up to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you concerned about what the Usher of the Black Rod said?
—I am very concerned that he did say things about this matter. Yes, I am very concerned.
—Are you?
—Yes, I am. I certainly am.
—Why?
—I am very concerned that he should be out there making comments. If you read the Sunday Age and heard what he said on the channel 10 news, you would see why people should be very concerned.
—He has an obligation, hasn't he?
—No-one has an obligation to prejudge an issue. No-one should be out there saying what the evidence amounts to and in any shape or form pre‐empting an inquiry that is in train.
—So it is not proper for the Senate to have an opportunity to explore the position?

—Of course it is—and you will have that opportunity in May this year. If you want to explore an issue, you have all the normal parliamentary avenues. But squandering money on a specially convened parliamentary inquiry simply to indulge your hate retribution fantasies is not in the interests of democracy.
—What would be the cost of reconvening the committee on Friday?

—Are you seriously suggesting that, whenever we read something in a newspaper and someone else wants to have a special committee hearing, we should? We have just had those hearings. Senator Ray excelled himself in terms of his physical capacity. He stayed up all night working on this project. He barely came to question time for days on end because he was away doing his homework. He had every chance to explore all of this then. You did not use it. You will get your chance in due course. Just be patient, but do not abuse the processes of the Senate in the meantime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the difference between Senator Alston and me is that I have attacked an individual who has the capacity under privilege to respond to a whole range of allegations but Senator Alston has come into the chamber today and attacked an individual who has no such right. No doubt that person can go to the Privileges Committee and have a statement of response put down on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, as the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) indicated, ample precedent for reconvening estimates committees. We have done so several times by our motion and by motion of the other side since the coalition won the government last March. What we want to explore is the fact that an issue was raised at an estimates committee and an investigation from that particular question was not asked for. The question was asked about the possibility of a senator claiming travel allowance when that senator was not present in the location claimed.

If you go back through the Hansard record, you will see that at that stage I did not ask for an investigation. What then happened was that a story was put about that Senator Colston had initiated this investigation. I find that curious because officials from the Department of the Senate had rung me earlier for more information on this particular subject long before Senator Colston initiated an investigation. What we then hear is that there has been an investigation into travel allowance claims, cross‐correlation with transport and Commonwealth car records and some doubt thrown on the validity of claims.

Because the Department of the Senate, coming out of the previous estimates committee, has taken this initiative, we seek to reconvene the committee to ask certain questions. But I should qualify that right away. We may be very circumscribed in the types of questions we can ask. If, indeed, the report has not been sent to the President and acted upon, we would be loath on this side to ask questions directly concerning a particular senator or a particular issue even if we reconvened the estimates committee on Friday. We have a long history of not interfering in operational matters—be they matters by way of inquiry, or the Federal Police or anything else. So I make that clear to everyone before they vote on this motion and maybe a subsequent one that that is our attitude.

BREAK.PARA: If, in the circumstances, we found that inquiries were still under way and no report had been sent to the President, or if we found that there was a reference to the Australian Federal Police, we would not be asking specific questions on this particular matter. We would then go to the methodology of the investigation which is, I think, fairly before us. As Senator Faulkner indicated, we have conflicting evidence—maybe not conflicting evidence, but we would like it resolved—between various officers who work for the Department of the Senate. This is not in any way intended as a witch-hunt against any of the officers of the Senate but is just to clarify what those issues are.

As I say, if indeed we are not able to pursue our specific questions which might be regarded as new questions as to allegations, what we would be seeking to thoroughly check would be that the methods of analysis and investigation were appropriate to what the investigation was about. As I say, there is ample precedent for reopening the estimates committee.

Let me move to the issue of 7 May. We have arranged the estimates committee program basically to suit the convenience of the government, but taking our own self‐interest into account at the same time. One of the great concessions to this government was not to have to have or force supplementary hearings during this sitting period. We moved it to the non-sitting period and we gave departments weeks and weeks to get their answers back in, all designed for a fairer and more balanced program.

But if we find that that is going to be used against us, to inhibit us in our questioning at estimates committees, then I guess we are going to have to reconsider that and have supplementary hearings to additional estimates and to estimates just a couple of weeks after the initial hearings. Those on the other side should think about that. That is not desirable. We are not seeking to reopen dozens of estimates or committee hearings. We are seeking to open one with a very limited brief of inquiry. We will keep to our word that, if in fact there are operational matters or inquiries still under way, our questions will go to the methodology and not to the actual substance of the inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The motives of the Labor Party are quite frankly irrelevant in this particular matter. What we have is a situation where both natural justice and the needs of the moment require that this process be hastened. We have in the Senate two senators at least and in the House of Representatives one member at least who are subject to allegations of having rorted, to use the colloquial phrase, the allowances and entitlement system. It is natural justice that those allegations, whether they are true or not, are put to bed as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: It is apparent to me, having sat through the estimates committee, and it is apparent to us as Australian Democrats, having observed the allegations subsequent to those estimates committees, that further information and further allegations have emerged since then which deserve the proper exploration of the issue. The Australian Democrats made a request of Labor to amend their motion, because our concern is the much broader issue—that is, the fact and the reality of how these allowances and entitlements are dealt with at present and how we can communicate the way in which they are to be dealt with in future to lay to rest some of the damage done to our reputation as an institution and to our reputation as individuals.

We will not seek to put into words the amendment we requested of Labor because we will support their motion and then use that process of estimates, if it is agreed to by the Senate, to pursue the issues that matter to us. I will spell out those issues. Firstly, we will look at whether the Department of Administrative Services is resourced with people and money in a manner which enables it to do its job in such a way as to prevent massive loopholes occurring—in other words, that the internal management and audit and administration systems all work correctly.

Secondly, we will look at whether they have the means to audit or to compare such things as travel allowance claims, Senate sitting days, committee sitting days, airfares and car usage to make sure that there is no mechanism whereby a senator can lay off one against the other and get away with moneys or entitlements that otherwise they would not be able to enjoy. Thirdly, we will be seeking to see if there are some means by which the department can report to the minister or the Senate on a regular basis to ensure that a regular audit not only goes on but is known to go on and is reported as having gone on, and that the normal functions which go on in the better institutions and organisations in Australia in terms of corporate governance occur in these matters.

Lastly, we will be seeking advice from the officials as to where the problems are so that in future Australians, the Senate and we can be satisfied that the opportunity for misconduct, impropriety, corruption or fraud are absolutely limited because, in the pursuit of this issue, we are all splattered with the blood when an individual or individuals are shot. It is for those reasons that we want this process sorted out as soon as possible. We see the extra estimates sitting as one more piece in the jigsaw of accountability and urgent review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to participate in this debate as the chairman of the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee to which the motion refers. I have to say, particularly having sat through the estimates hearings dealing with many of these matters last week, that I see this motion as nothing other than the next chapter in Labor's continuing campaign, driven by sheer naked hatred, against Senator Colston.

SPEECH.PARA: If you wanted any evidence of this, you would simply have to have witnessed Senator Ray's extraordinary attack on Senator Colston yesterday in this place. I cannot recall a more vicious, premeditated, impassioned speech of vitriol in my time in this parliament. I am pleased to see that the debate today is on a more responsible and rational level.

The motion is another sleazy, grubby exercise by Labor to judge and convict a member of this place before even any charge has been laid. That is really what it is about. It is a basic tenet of our civilised society and of the rules of law that there is a presumption of innocence until guilt is proved. If the Labor Party ever believed in that rule of law, it completely threw it out the window in respect of its approach to Senator Colston and the allegations. In doing so, I must say that Labor has brought disrepute to the parliament and charted us into very dangerous waters indeed. What we have witnessed in recent days is political thuggery at its worst and I think that is very dangerous.

The motion in my view is redundant and unnecessary. There are already more than one official investigation into the matters that are essentially the subject of this motion. One is by the Department of Administrative Services, another I understand is within the confines of the Senate, and I think there may be others.

The Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee formally concluded its examination of departments and agencies within its charter last week, with the exception of ATSIC, which we are dealing with tonight. It did so, as Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner well know because they were there, particularly Senator Ray, after spending hours and hours on questions relating to possible misuse of travel allowances. There is insufficient reason to reopen the committee's hearings on additional estimates for the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's this cover-up? What are you covering up?
—Here he goes. There may well be supplementary additional estimates hearings in early May. I think there will be. Those matters could be taken up then if necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to express some concern and real doubt as to whether, in any event, the estimates committee is the appropriate forum in which to pursue this particular matter and the allegations made. Serious allegations have been made and they must be examined. The government is fully supportive and encouraging of those being fully examined, but it has to be done in a way that is fair to all concerned, in particular to the person against whom the allegations are made.

I come back to my starting point. I think this is all about the next instalment in Labor's campaign of hate against their former colleague. It is all about retribution. It is all about revenge. It is all about punishment. It is all about hatred and, as shown by the questions on the Notice Paper from Senator Ray yesterday and as, I think, Senator Alston said, it is all about desperation.

As my colleague Mr Jull said in the House today, I am afraid that what ALP now stands for in this place is Allegations Lynchings and Persecutions without regard to the decent proprieties of parliament. I, therefore, fully support the government's opposition to this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Carr.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I hate to ask, but—
—No, you don't.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: O'CHEE

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray, you do not even know what question I am about to ask. Unless you are Marvin the Mindreader, it might pay to wait until you have another chance to speak properly.

INTERJECT.PARA: My point of order is on the order of call. Prior to Senator Short receiving the call, there were two speakers from the other side of the chamber, then Senator Short received the call. Quite clearly, I attempted to jump before Senator Carr. What we are now going to see during this period of time is four speakers from the other side of the chamber and two speakers from this side of the chamber. Madam Acting Deputy President, is that your intention in terms of this debate?

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Madam Deputy President: it is traditional in these debates that, when the opposition moves a suspension of standing orders, it receives the opportunity to have three speakers address the issue of urgency. Two speakers from the government is traditional and Senator Alston and Senator Short have spoken. There is usually one speaker from the Australian Democrats or a minor party. If Senator O'Chee would care to consult the Hansard , he would find that on every single occasion—certainly in the time that I have been in this chamber since 1989—that has been the way the chair has called. It is appropriate; it is in order to call Senator Carr. I suggest Senator O'Chee stop the time wasting and we get on with it.
—This is not time wasting.
—On the point of order: I called Senator Robert Ray and, at that time, both Senator Murray and Senator Carr jumped. I called Senator Murray and then Senator Short and then I returned to Senator Carr.
—Senator Carr did not seek the call.

—He had sought the call because I also called Senator Murray. I think, Senator O'Chee, that there is not technically a point of order. It has been indicated that there is a precedent. Could Senator Carr please continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is one of urgency. It goes to the very basic questions of accountability within this Senate. There has been new evidence put before this Senate in the form of various media reports and officers of this parliament suggesting that there have been irregularities in the claims made by a senator in this place. These are matters of fundamental importance—fundamental in terms of accountability and the integrity of this place—that ultimately go to the issue of the integrity of the government's legislative program.

SPEECH.PARA: There could be no more serious an issue, given the composition of the Senate, than allegations that a senator is rorting his allowances. None of us of here have any time for rorters. I am surprised that, over on that side of the chamber, we have people who are prepared to defend this sort of behaviour. We have people in this chamber who are obviously prepared to defend the actions of a senator in this matter. That is a matter that you ought to take up amongst yourselves. I wonder how many of you could expect the same level of support if these were the sorts of allegations made against you from within the leadership of your party? What would happen is that you would be out the door so fast it would not matter and they would have a replacement in here.

What we have here are very special circumstances that go to the fundamental way in which votes are counted in this chamber. They go to the issues of this government's legislative program and the manner in which votes are bought in this place. So it comes back to this very basic issue: what is the level of accountability in this parliament? What is the basis on which there can be a proper examination of the claims made?

I understand there are issues that go to whether or not appropriate claims were made in February 1994. Of course, it has been alleged that on a number of occasions in February 1994 there were claims made when actual travel does not indicate that those claims were justified. There were similar matters in May 1994, February 1995, March 1995 and May 1995. These are the issues that I would like to consider at the estimates committee. I would like to be able to consider what action has been taken within this parliament to make sure that appropriate measures have been taken to actually defend the integrity of this parliament. In the Mercury of 4 March, Senator Colston himself is quoted as saying that he has found irregularities in his own claims. I look forward to a further investigation of those matters.

Senator Short raises the issue about the rule of law. We state it quite clearly. I understand the report is going to the President of the Senate concerning affairs relating back to 1992. We are not pursuing irregularities referred to the Federal Police by the rule of law and properly investigated. We are pursuing the process by which claims and payments are made in terms of the way in which this parliament actually functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is already under investigation.

—Senator Short, there has been no reference to the Federal Police for further investigation. There has been this sleazy cover‐up by this government about assessments of issues that are being raised, not an investigation. There has to be a proper consideration of where this parliament is going, the manner in which votes are bought in this place and the mechanisms by which this government functions. The levels of political integrity, propriety and ethics in this chamber are fundamental issues for this chamber and cannot be brushed aside by any sleazy cover‐up by this government. We know what hangs on these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not just some petty vendetta, as you are trying to propose. These are fundamental questions that go to the way in which laws are made in this country. The privatisation of Telstra is one thing. In months to come we will have the questions of the cross‐media laws. On what basis is law made in this country? What is the mechanism?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I would ask that Senator Carr withdraw what is clearly a reflection on the Senate when he refers to votes being bought.

—On the point of order: Senator Campbell is right. The standing orders clearly preclude senators from making adverse references to votes which have been taken in the chamber. It is very much in breach of standing orders for Senator Carr to try to do that and to suggest that there was some improper motive in a vote which occurred in this chamber.

—On the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I find it quite extraordinary that the Manager of Government Business would take such a spurious point of order. I put it to you that there is nothing unparliamentary about a senator suggesting that a vote has been bought in this chamber. These allegations have been made not only in this chamber but outside by any number of people who believe, frankly, in relation to the issue that Senator Carr raises, that there was a price for the coalition government's support for Senator Colston for the position of Deputy President in this place. It has been said by any number of people in any number of newspapers, not just politicians from this side of the chamber but also journalists and commentators, and I think you will find it is being said very widely amongst the general public.

—On the point of order: I am advised that under standing order 193 senators are prohibited from using words against the Senate. Senator Carr, I would suggest that, if you were to make it clear that you are not reflecting on the Senate, you may proceed.

—On the point of order: I make it very clear that I am not reflecting on the Senate. I am raising an issue about the integrity of the Senate and about the actions of members in the Senate, not the Senate itself.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Faulkner has clearly displayed today that he uses conventions and principles when they suit his own cause. That means they are the sorts of principles you take off the shelf and put back again when you no longer need them. Anyone who can dispute that saying a vote was bought is not a reflection on a vote of the Senate or on the Senate either is being extremely cute or basically wants to put their principles on the shelf when it suits them. Madam Deputy President, I suggest that is something that Senator Faulkner does, as I said yesterday; it is something that Senator Carr is showing inclinations of doing today—
— Does this go to the point of order?
—It certainly does—but it is certainly something that a presiding officer of this chamber could not do.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: Senator Carr has just said that he was reflecting on the integrity of the Senate. That is an admission that he is outside standing order 193 and, therefore, he should be brought to order.
—On the point of order: I heard Senator Carr saying he was not reflecting on the integrity of the Senate.
—He is reflecting on your integrity—you, the government.
—He couldn't reflect on yours because you don't have any.
—Order! On the point of order: I would repeat what I said in ruling in relation to standing order 193, and I would ask Senator Carr to use his remaining time in an appropriate way in this debate.
—This issue goes to the matter of the way in which this government functions.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Can I take it that you are ruling and creating a precedent in the Senate that you can now say votes in the Senate have been bought, reflecting on a vote in the Senate, and that that is now considered within standing orders? If that is the case, I ask you to refer this matter to the President and for her to report back on that ruling. I would never want to see such a terrible precedent set in this chamber by a presiding officer or an acting presiding officer.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: finally Senator Campbell has matured into a position and made a reasonable suggestion. I was about to make the same suggestion myself. If Senator Campbell and others are a bit dissatisfied with your ruling, the normal precedent here is at least to refer it to Madam President and she can reflect on it and say what she would like to at a later time.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: when you do refer the matter to the President, would you draw her attention to the fact that Senator Campbell allowed a statement to be made and, only after it had been repeated three times, like an incendiary bomb went off.

—On the point of order: I will refer the matter to the President. I was ruling on the advice of one of the officers. But I am very happy to refer the matter to the President because it is obviously of some contention. Senator Carr, I would ask you to keep in mind the effect of your comments and proceed accordingly.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. This is an issue that is of fundamental importance to the accountability of this chamber, to the manner in which this government functions and the extent to which its members are prepared to go to cover up what are quite clearly very serious allegations of impropriety, to cover up the failure to live up to the standards of ethics that we have come to expect—to cover up your lack of propriety when it comes to finding mechanisms to get the numbers in here and the various devices to ensure that you get the numbers you need. In your voting against this proposition today, you are making it crystal clear to the Australian people that you are covering up these rorts, you are covering up these standards. (Time expired)

Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:

The abandonment of Australian farmers by the Federal Government as demonstrated by the refusal of the Queensland Government to sign the new National Drought Policy which slashes tens of millions of dollars from future drought funding.
