Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The abandonment of Australian farmers by the Federal Government as demonstrated by the refusal of the Queensland Government to sign the new National Drought Policy which slashes tens of millions of dollars from future drought funding.

Last week federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Anderson, used the last meeting of the Agricultural and Resource Management Committee of Australia and New Zealand to announce that the meeting endorsed a new drought policy which basically cuts drought relief by tens of millions of dollars and heralds a shift towards so-called self-reliance for farmers suffering from drought.

The minister's media release announces that the federal and state agricultural ministers endorse the plan but fails to mention that his National Party counterpart in Queensland, state primary industries minister Trevor Perrett, refused to sign the endorsement. What an omission! Minister Anderson also omitted to mention that the New South Wales agriculture minister also objected to the new policy.

This new policy to be ratified in June would end the drought exceptional circumstances system which automatically triggered assistance for farmers suffering severe drought. It is so ironic that the drought package introduced by Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating—and I say that because Labor can stand on its record here—has been abolished by a National Party primary industries minister. I am sure honourable senators will remember National Party members and senators stomping up and down the country screaming blue murder at inaction by the Labor Party over drought funding two years ago. Now their own National Party minister is going to abolish the whole program. They should hang their heads in shame. On this occasion, the National Party primary industries minister in Queensland is quite right.

The minister for primary industries wants to terminate drought exceptional circumstances and force farmers and state governments to go through the whole process of jumping up and down and lobbying and getting federal politicians out of Canberra to drought affected areas before farmers can get any special drought funding. This is bad policy, cynical in the extreme and it will go down like a lead balloon in the bush.

I am making a fuss about the Howard government's massive cuts to drought relief because my own home state of Queensland, despite the recent rain which is very welcome, has suffered drought for most of this decade and is still around 20 per cent drought declared. It will be hardest hit once this policy is introduced. Rich farmers in New South Wales of course will not have to worry very much. In Queensland, farmers are just beginning to recover and the government plans to show them a clean set of heels.

Minister Anderson says, `I don't walk away from drought relief provisions currently applying in Queensland and New South Wales.' But what about when they run out? Is this government God? Can this government say, `There will not be any more droughts because we have declared that there should not be, so we do not need any contingency plans'? These cuts are mean in the extreme.

The Howard government's new drought policy eliminates subsidies for fodder—you know, the fodder drives that have gone out to drought affected families. It is a wonderful initiative which has enabled all Australians to understand better the problems of the bush, but this government cannot even support community initiatives like that. You really cannot understand where they are coming from. The new drought policy also removes exceptional circumstance interest rate subsidies, which have been so important.

The new drought policy refers to a social security task force on farm welfare. Let me say that it is repeating work already done in the Senate; repeating exactly the inquiries which we have conducted which were, for the most part, chaired by National Party senators. They are doing the work all over again so they can avoid taking any action. Have an inquiry and then they will not have to do anything. Right now farm families are suffering terribly.

What about Senator Vanstone's shocking Austudy means test? The evidence coming in today is that, despite the fact that she says it has been fixed up, farm families are still unable to access Austudy. This government, like the government before it, has failed completely to address the problems of the Austudy assets test, which discriminates against farmers. So farm welfare goes into the too‐hard basket and drought relief is cut.

Isn't it great having a National Party in government so farmers have a voice in Canberra! Only the farmers do not think so. Instead of using the ARMCANZ conference to help farmers come up with ways to help them deal with drought, outbreaks of disease like anthrax, ovine johns and anthracnose affecting lupins, the federal minister for primary industries used one of the most significant agricultural conferences of the year to fulfil his cabinet's budget agenda to cut, cut and cut.

BREAK.PARA: Let me quote from an article that appeared in the Courier‐Mail yesterday. It is very interesting to see what ministers from the National Party in Queensland think of the federal government. The article states:
Queensland farm leaders welcomed the tough stand taken by Primary Industries Minister Trevor Perrett.
Mr Perrett said the State Government would not walk away from producers suffering from severe drought.
"The Federal Minister, John Anderson, has been given the message that we are just not prepared to roll over," Mr Perrett said.
"The proposed new policy would virtually cut off the support lifeline after six months, pushing producers over the brink through no fault of their own.
"The message finally seems to be sinking in that the north is more prone to severe drought than the rest of Australia.
"We endorse the broad direction of farmers being more self‐reliant.
"But this policy cannot work until there are real incentives for producers to put money aside."

In the same article, the President of the Queensland Grain Growers Association said that the new policy was `a bureaucratic whitewash to save money'. If you want anyone to really put it on the line, you should always listen to Ian MacFarlane. The article continues:
United Graziers Association chief executive Michael Prendergast said the Federal Government did not recognise the recovery period needed after severe drought.
"The policy under consideration is just not acceptable to Queensland," he said.

What we have is a government with National Party members in it that is unable to deliver anything to farmers in this country. On top of the abolition of the drought funding relief a few months ago, we had the abolition of funds to Lifeline in Toowoomba for rural counselling and the removal of the sugar subsidy. I noticed in the Age today that some National Party members may cross the floor on this issue. We will wait to see what happens. I commend De-Anne Kelly, a National Party member in the House of Representatives from Mackay, because she probably will cross the floor. She seems to be showing a bit of guts where many other National Party senators and members simply roll over and let the Liberal Party walk all over them and the bush.

Another issue which has affected farmers in Queensland is what looks like the closure of offices of the farm finance services in Maroochydore and Rockhampton through cuts to state legal aid over the next three years. We have a government which cares nothing about the bush—not today and certainly not in the future when droughts will come, as they inevitably will. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the urgency motion moved by Senator Woodley that the Australian government has abandoned Australian farmers. I have to express some disappointment with the wording of the motion. Having sat on many inquiries with Senator Woodley in rural and regional affairs committees, I know he has a genuine interest in Australian agriculture and those who work in it. However, to suggest that the federal government has abandoned Australian farmers and to base those views largely, I suggest, on an article in the Courier‐Mail does not reflect the understanding and interest he has in the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: Drought is an ongoing concern and an anguish for Australian agriculture. For as long as we have farmed this country, there have been droughts. From my entire term in the Senate, the issue of drought and how governments—both state and federal—should manage drought policy have been an ongoing debate. Senator Woodley has participated in many of those debates. I think it ill-behoves him today to bring forward such an emotional worded urgency motion suggesting that this government has abandoned farmers.

It is important to put the decision made by ARMCANZ ministers last week in historical perspective. In May 1989 the previous government established a drought policy review task force to undertake `an independent and comprehensive review of drought policy in Australia'. They did so because in April 1989 the then federal government made the decision to remove drought funding from the national disaster relief arrangements. The task force published two reports. The final three‐volume report was presented to the government in May 1990. From that report's recommendations, the Labor government adopted a national drought policy in 1992.

The current drought policy review task force was established under the previous minister, Senator Collins, following an agreement by ARMCANZ ministers in August 1995 to review the national drought policy and the responses to it. It was a high level government, Commonwealth and state, task force involving experts from both state and federal departments of primary industry as well as other co‐opted experts. On coming to office, Minister Anderson supported its work and the task force reported to ARMCANZ in September last year.

Last week the Commonwealth and state ministers for agriculture agree on the major policy directions for farm business risk management, including the management of drought. The major policy directions agreed to included: to encourage the widespread adoption by primary producers throughout Australia of a self‐reliant approach to farming risks; to encourage good natural resource management to maintain and protect Australia's agricultural and environmental resource base; to ensure that farm families are provided with the means to secure their welfare requirements; to ensure that desirable ongoing structural adjustment in Australian rural industries is not impeded; and to improve the understanding of drought and drought policy.

Senator Woodley, those concepts are not new. In fact, they are widely endorsed by the rural sector. Over 230 people attended the national rural finance summit last year and they endorsed a number of recommendations that supported exactly that concept—an environment in which farmers could become self‐reliant. As the summit clearly demonstrated, farmers want structures in place that will allow them to become better equipped, more self‐reliant and therefore more financially able to meet the vagaries of farming.

A recurring theme over the three days was that farmers did not want handouts. They wanted the government monkeys off their backs; they wanted a stable economic environment. As one of the workshops at the summit concluded:
Industry and farmers recognise the need for dynamic flexible and responsive farm business structures enabling profitable sustainable and self‐reliant agriculture.

The activating committee established after the summit endorsed those views. The committee's report last week demonstrated quite clearly that farmers recognise the need to become dynamic. They want an economic environment that allows them to do that and they want the right incentives to encourage long‐term investment in the rural sector, and the government is going that.

The national drought policy fits well into the criteria that farmers themselves have asked for, because the objective of the national drought policy is to move from a drought reactive approach to a drought preparedness approach. In recent years, commodity downturns, historical high interest rates and other economic factors have prevented farmers from developing this self‐reliant approach. What we need to ensure is that we now put in place incentives that encourage farmers to prepare for drought and the other downturns, so that they can put away in the good years to prepare for the tough years.

The ability of farmers to access funds during a downturn is crucial to the ability of farmers to manage drought and the incentive to put the money away in good times is paramount. I think you agree with that; all the farmers in Australia agree with that. For too long, Australian agriculture has suffered from a lack of clear policy objectives. What this government wants to achieve is more certainty for the farm sector. We want a farm sector equipped to face the challenges of international competition well into the next century. And we are doing that. The minister is currently developing a business plan for agriculture that will establish a broad vision for Australian agriculture and identify key issues which need to be addressed if the rural sector is to capture the significant opportunities now emerging in export markets, especially in Asia.

While developing that business plan, this government has not been idle in other areas of rural policy. Let me highlight some of the achievements we have made in rural policy alone in the last 12 months. The government has provided additional drought relief in two packages totalling $170 million in its first year in office—not too bad, I would have thought. This included the extension of drought exceptional circumstances to several parts of New South Wales which previously had been denied assistance, and we modified the drought exceptional circumstances criteria to take greater account of the effectiveness of rain—something that farmers in the west of New South Wales, in particular, had been arguing for for some time under the previous government. We have extended the standard drought recovery period during which the drought relief payment and the special assessment for Austudy are available after DEC is revoked from six months to 12 months.

The Commonwealth, Queensland, Victorian and New South Wales state governments have agreed to provide matching financial assistance for drought regional initiatives totalling $12 million. The Queensland drought regional initiative encompasses 20 projects throughout regional Queensland, which you would know about Senator Woodley, which support on‐farm activities. The initiative started in September last year with total funding of $5.2 million.

Senator Woodley, as a Queensland senator you would know that this government has responded quickly and appropriately to assist farmers in your state and to suggest that we have abandoned them, or would abandon them, is scaremongering and petty politics—something I would have hoped you would be above. In making the announcement last week about the new approach to drought, Minister Anderson said very clearly that the federal government would not walk away from drought relief provisions currently applying in Queensland and New South Wales. So, why the scaremongering?

Progress has been made in a number of other rural areas and the implementation of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill will see many significant projects coming on stream. Landcare will receive additional funding of $279 million over the next five years. The Murray‐Darling Basin will receive $163 million to improve water quality and encourage sustainable land use. Work has commenced on a national weeds strategy, a national feral animal control strategy, a national rangelands strategy and a national land and water audit.

We are developing five‐year plans for the grains industry and the government has worked closely with the wool industry to ensure a more viable future for wool growers and we are making changes to meat industry structures to assist a resurgence of this important sector. An integrated package of reforms has been developed for the sugar industry and, in my own area of responsibility in horticulture, we see an enormous growth in exports with wine and citrus leading the way.

The government has not abandoned agriculture, Senator Woodley. We have embraced it. Under this government, the rural sector will regain its strength, its viability and its independence. I utterly reject Senator Woodley's assertions and I am confident that, over the course of the next few years, the policies that we are putting in place will provide a sound economic base for true sustainability in the rural sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I left my portfolio at the last election—
—That must have been a shock.

—I took some satisfaction out of the fact, even though perhaps Senator Sandy Macdonald may not have, as a Labor minister for primary industry that, in the two years I held that portfolio, cabinet had either spent or committed $2 billion in additional resources to primary industry. Of that, $600 million was committed to drought relief. For the two years that I was in that portfolio there is no question that the major event that overshadowed everything else that happened during that time was what was unarguably the worst and most catastrophic sustained period of drought in the country's history. Certainly in terms of the production lost, it was an all time catastrophe. Indeed, Senator Brownhill has confirmed that it was.

BREAK.PARA: On my way to the airport last week in the early hours of the morning I listened to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) announcing that a new drought policy would be released that coming Friday at ARMCANZ, which interested me. The review process that Senator Brownhill, quite correctly, laid out was the review that I set in train. The purpose of that review, Senator Woodley, was to enhance the drought facility for primary producers, not to cut it to ribbons.

After I listened to the minister talking about self-reliance and preparing for drought, all of which I agree with and all of which was the policy of the previous government, there was one thing he did not mention, and neither did Senator Brownhill. That was exceptional circumstances. Treasury and Finance have won again. I can translate this press statement.

I had some other things to attend to in Darwin and I had not caught up with the new drought policy. I was keen to pursue it when I got to Canberra. I said to my staff when I arrived, `Have you got a copy of the new drought policy that was announced on Friday?' My staff said to me, `We have a one page press statement that the minister issued on Friday but because it said absolutely nothing, we did not even bother sending it to you in Darwin.' I said, `It must say something.' They said, `No, it doesn't.' I have it here in my hand. Of course, my staff were quite right. I heard the minister on ABC radio announcing that he would be announcing this new policy last Friday—this brand new approach to drought. It is one page of absolute nothing. It says:
Farmers will have to play an increasing role in achieving self‐reliance and profitability . . .
I can translate that into English, and so can you, Senator Brownhill. That means, `Don't look to us for what you got in the past, folks.' That is what it says. It also said:
The findings of the Task Force have provided us—

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen:

BREAK.PARA: with a strong foundation for future drought policy . . .
So the drought policy is still coming, Senator Woodley; it was not announced on Friday at all. I can translate all that into English.

The minister also said—I was interested to hear this—that this new drought policy would get away from drawing lines on maps. There is a problem with that. I know the problem with drawing lines on maps. That drought policy, with all of its deficiencies—I was well aware of them—was put into place very quickly to get the maximum amount of help on the ground where it was needed very quickly, and it succeeded, Senator Brownhill. If you need any testimony for that, go to Queensland and ask a few primary producers whether they appreciated the drought package being put together so quickly and delivered so quickly.

I knew that there were problems with lines on maps but, by definition, if it is a drought assistance scheme—knowing that this country is always either in or out of some kind of drought, knowing that it is commonplace for it to be in drought at one end and flooded at the other, which is currently the situation, and knowing that last year regions of Australia had their wettest period on record and in the same year others had their driest period on record—and if you are going to provide a drought relief package for drought affected farmers, you have to draw lines on the map somewhere. You cannot apply the assistance to every farmer in Australia. So at some point—whether it is a regional boundary, a state boundary or a property boundary—there has to be a line sooner or later where somebody is getting drought assistance and somebody is not.

I translated all that, and I think accurately, to the fact that this government is about to dump any recognition of exceptional circumstances. That is a recognition by government—and a very important one, because resources have to flow from that recognition—that there are sometimes catastrophic natural events in this country that are beyond the capacity of the best managers in Australia to cope with. I defy anybody with a straight face to tell me that that did not occur during that last drought that has thankfully been broken for some significant period of time. It did occur. The best managers on the Darling Downs could not cope with it, and they are as good as any in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are.

—Yes, they are. We recognise the fact that it was beyond them and they could not be blamed for not having the resources to cope with it. It was a catastrophic exceptional event. We recognised in government, rightly, that there were circumstances and events—and I think we talked about one in 25‐year events; we put a fair stricture on it—in this wide brown land of ours which were catastrophically bad and it was appropriate for governments to provide additional assistance. Treasury and Finance had a different view then. I am very familiar with that view. They did not win the day then but they have won it now with this new government.
—They have won it now.

—It is highly ironic, is it not, Senator West? We are talking about the friends of the farmers—the so-called natural constituency and the party that rural voters overwhelmingly supported. I was aware that they would at the time. It is one of the things that I am proud about. Our cabinet did not provide that massive amount of help—and it was—in any hope that that was going to provide a return at the polling both. We did it because it needed to be done. We knew perfectly well that those votes would not flow. We did it because the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, to his great credit, and he meant it, said that we were not going to allow people in these appalling circumstances to fall below the rest of Australia in terms of extending that assistance. The cabinet of the day made sure they did not. We now know, translating all of this gobbledegook into English, that this government is proposing to dump the recognition of exceptional circumstances.

BREAK.PARA: I might add that the one intriguing little line in all of this—the only line in there that is of any interest; all the rest of it is just pap, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Brownhill) knows it—is this business about accessing welfare benefits. A delightful lack of any detail whatsoever has been provided for that. I was looking forward to actually hearing it today, but did not. It will be interesting to see how we propose to do that. The one thing that you can draw the line on absolutely is that the real translation of these so‐called new initiatives is the retention of all the old initiatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —Minus one.
—Yes, minus one, and a major one—that is, that exceptional circumstances are about to be scrapped.

BREAK.PARA: It is interesting to have a look at the approach adopted by the minister for primary industry when he took office. Senator Brownhill said he was going to recount all the achievements in the last 12 months. It was a very short list. I have had a look at the last 12 months with great interest. The minister's approach has been to review absolutely everything. I put a question on notice in May last year about these reviews. Let me tell you, Senator Sandy Macdonald, that there are dozens of them. I asked how they were all going. I would have to say that things are not going all that well. I refer to one aspect of the answer I received to that question. The answer advised me of the establishment of a special rural task force. Senator West, you know about this task force. This special rural task force, announced with great fanfare, was set up to investigate access by farm families to social security payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We already did it.

—Correct. This is why I am interested in this reference to welfare. What has the government done about this? Let me tell you. One year after they set it up with much fanfare—we did it Senator Woodley; that is correct—the chairperson of that task force, Senator Tambling, put out a press statement. Guess what it said. Let me read what it said—this is a year after they set it up.
—Another inquiry!
—Better than that—four of them. This thing had pups, let me tell you. It said:

BREAK.PARA: The need for improved service delivery in social security offices in rural and regional centres is an obvious area of concern.

Other recommendations contained in the report will need to be considered by government in the budget context and in conjunction with other reviews such as the rural adjustment scheme review, the national rural finance summit activating committee report, the review of the rural communities access program and the drought policy review task force report.

I am not making that up. That is a government statement. We are all waiting for it. At the end of 12 months, the task force that was supposed to produce a report indicating how farm families were going to access the welfare Senator Brownhill has just had the hide to talk about turned into four more reviews plus the budget process. As I said before, this particular review had pups, but I would not want the pick of the litter, I can tell you. You can keep them all.

This one example provides a good insight into how this new minister is going in this portfolio: very badly is the answer. That answer also referred to the review of the meat industry statutory arrangements. That is jammed—absolutely jammed. The minister had better move on it fairly quickly or it is all going to start falling apart around the edges. It referred to a review of anti‐dumping provisions by Mr Lawrie Willett. That happened, but the government, on receiving Mr Willett's report, decided to refer the matter to the Productivity Commission. That is yet to formally happen because the wets and dries in the government cannot agree on the terms of reference for the referral. The restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board is also jammed. It is unfortunate that we have to lump the national drought policy into that basket of reviews, despite the fact that the matter has been before the ministerial council for some time.

While this document is vague, as I said—one A4‐page saying nothing—the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the hardheads in both Treasury and Finance are going to have their way. It is clear from this release and it is clear from the parliamentary secretary's contribution this afternoon, scant as it was, that there is going to be very little financial commitment from this Commonwealth government in future times of drought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of this debate, I would like to enter a disclaimer that, as a cattle producer and a grazier, I have probably benefited—or my family has from time to time—from drought relief measures, principally in the form of freight subsidies on fodder in times of drought. We have had a major drought in Central Queensland for the last six years, so I have some first‐hand experience of it. This year alone in the wet season we have probably had about 4½ or five inches of rain against a normal average of anywhere between 15 and 25 inches. So it looks like we are going to move into a seventh year of drought. This motion is really quite an extraordinary one. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The abandonment of Australian farmers by the Federal Government as demonstrated by the refusal of the Queensland Government to sign the new National Drought Policy which slashes tens of millions of dollars from future drought funding.

The business about abandonment of Australian farmers by the federal government is a non‐sequitur. In the first place, no federal government is responsible for any action of a state government. I fail to see the connection in that. But, as Senator Brownhill so eloquently pointed out, none of it is true—not remotely true. You have got to excuse it as being another cheap, headline grabbing attempt by the Democrats to get a bit of publicity and try to win a few votes in the bush. The Democrats have never had as their spokesman in the party anyone from any of the rural industries of Australia with any first‐hand experience. Although Senator Woodley tries hard, his claim to knowing something about conditions in the bush is the fact that he has driven through them, probably, some time or other. That is about as relevant as me claiming, because I own a car, that I represent or am involved in the motor industry. It is just not true. Senator Woodley has got to acquire a depth of knowledge: he has got to get some information about those industries and have some contact with them, otherwise he simply does not earn any respect for his point of view in the community at all.

Most of the debate so far has been the usual exuberant—to put it euphemistically—approach from Senator Collins. I do not doubt for one moment the sincerity of Senator Collins's interest in rural activities. The only problem he has is, like Senator Woodley, a shortage of first‐hand knowledge of what goes on. Yet he comes in and tries to defend the 13 years of neglect that the Labor Party inflicted on rural Australia after the indifference that they showed while we went through droughts, poor commodity prices and all the other afflictions we have had. The last five to 10 years have quite probably been the hardest time for rural industries ever since Federation. It is a bit rich for Senator Collins now to berate the government for the constructive moves they have made.

Under Labor we saw greatly increased operational costs for all rural activities. We saw the enormously high inflation they stacked up. We saw high interest rates, up to 20 per cent, applied to property owners trying to cope with droughts and poor market prices. We saw a total inability to tackle labour relations, the consequence of that being very high oncosts for rural producers. Packaging costs in Australia are 40 per cent higher than they are in the US or the UK. Productivity of the labour market in food processing is only 40 per cent of what it is in the US.

What happened in relation to abattoirs is also a classic example. Productivity in the US is about three times ours. We saw high costs in transport. The sale of abattoirs that the Labor Party supported without any hindrance saw most Australian meat processing facilities move into overseas hands.

We also had the nonsense of the fringe benefits tax being applied to the rural community. The rural community is not an area where a fringe benefits tax has much application at all. There is a valid case to stop evasion in the form of benefits being paid to urban dwellers by way of salary packages, in business and the rest of it. That is a valid application of the fringe benefits tax, but rural Australia really suffers enormously through the imposition of a fringe benefits tax because in so many ways benefits are given in return for wages. It is a lifestyle that has developed for well over 100 years.

What did the Labor government do? It announced the national drought policy in 1992. Under this policy drought was recognised as a normal feature and farmers were to adopt improved risk management strategies. The rural adjustment scheme was to be used as the major vehicle for encouraging families. Hardship resulting from severe drought was to be addressed through the exceptional circumstances provision of the rural adjustment scheme.

But on implementing this policy the Labor government failed to put in place transitional arrangements for the tens of thousands of farmers who simply did not have the resources needed to manage risk. Prior to the partial adoption of the national drought policy of 1992, Labor had rendered income equalisation deposits ineffective. Consequently, they were not used by farmers during the better years at the end of the 1980s, when reserves could have been set aside for future risk management. When we were in government previously, something like $2 billion was involved in deposits under the IED scheme, but in the last two years they have been probably as low as $100 million.

Furthermore, since 1989, when Labor removed drought from the natural disaster relief arrangements, there has been no federal assistance available to farmers experiencing drought. In addition, the Labor government's national draft policy did not contain any support measures to ensure farmers experiencing severe drought beyond their capacity to manage were able to feed, clothe and educate their families.

What has this government done? This government has done quite a lot. We had the announcement on 16 August 1996 of $5.264 million for the drought regional initiative for Queensland. We had the announcement on 4 November of the $1.5 million support for the rural adjustment scheme. We had the drought relief payment scheme recovery package extended. We had the availability of Austudy for eligible families in DEC revoked areas extended, as with access to family payments, parenting allowance and health care cards. We saw the appointment of rural financial counsellors and a whole range of other issues.
We saw the $1.5 million package of drought recovery assistance later on in December. As the minister said in his press release on 28 February—Senator Brownhill made this point:
However, I make it clear the federal government will not walk away from drought relief provisions currently applying in Queensland and New South Wales.

We want our policy to ensure that rural producers are able to minimise—not eliminate but minimise—the effects of drought, flood and fire. Australia is different from other agricultural countries. The United Kingdom, Europe and America do not suffer the great floods, the great fires and the great droughts that we do. We need to put policies in place, which is what this government is doing, to make rural producers more self-reliant. Unlike the Democrat policy, we are not asking for low interest long-term loans or anything like that. We are asking for the resources we have in good years to be available to see us through the bad years. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of interest that I enter this debate today because this is an important issue. This is again a situation where the coalition government, in particular the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), a National Party minister, has come out with a policy that his own colleague from Queensland will not even sign off on. That is a little bit of a worry. It indicates to people just what farmers are thinking. The minister's colleague in Queensland is obviously a little more in touch with his grassroots than the federal minister is.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to look in a historical sense at what the former government did in the last few years in relation to drought. The drought response measures were consistent with principles that recognised the inevitability of drought and the need for farmers to adopt a self-reliant approach, with drought support being provided by the Commonwealth under only exceptional circumstances and state based subsidies being phased out.

BREAK.PARA: In conjunction with that, we were about introducing and doing drought research, drought preparedness, and drought management and support. On the research side, we introduced a number of programs that would support drought related research, including improving climatic forecasting and land, water and crop pasture management. In relation to drought preparedness, we had IEDs and FMBs, which provided incentives for saving income surpluses in good years for utilisation in bad years. We had taxation measures to better physically manage the impact. We had the rural adjustment scheme to support and implement farm productivity measures, including drought preparedness measures such as silage pits. We had landcare programs for improving land and water management, including for the impact of drought. We had rural counselling services.

On the drought management and support side, we had the normal rural adjustment scheme providing productivity support during the drought recovery phase. We had the exceptional circumstances scheme, which provided enhanced productivity and re-establishment support to assist farm businesses to maintain themselves throughout drought. We had the drought relief payment and associated measures, which were targeted to a number of farm families most in need. It provided them with income and it allowed them access to education assistance and to health assistance. As I said, we had the rural counselling service and the drought recovery and management facility.

These are the sorts of things the previous government did, under the former minister who has already spoken. They were well received on the whole in the areas. They were very well received not just by the farmers but by the farming communities. Many of the communities recognised that, when the farmers were assisted and had money to pay a number of their bills and to purchase food, they were enabling a cashflow to be generated within the community and that helped the whole of the community. So it is important to look at what the previous government has done.
It is also important to look at what the coalition's policy was on this issue before they came into power. In relation to exceptional circumstances, they said:

While farmers can . . . be expected to provide for income deficiencies caused by what could be described as "normal" fluctuations in climate and prices, the same cannot be said for "exceptional circumstances".

TALK.START.PARA: —They said that in their policy.
—Yes, they did. Something has happened between then and now; hasn't there.
—Non-core promise.
—I see; a non-core promise! It is not like an apple core, a bit rotten in the middle; is it? Their policy states:

BREAK.PARA: In these situations, special Government measures are justified to ensure the survival of viable farmers and maintain the nation's capacity to produce and export farm produce.
The Government has not applied the drought "exceptional circumstances" provisions uniformly or fairly, leading to major inequities.
There were some problems, as the former minister has already outlined. But that does not mean you chuck the whole program out, which is what this lot look like they are doing. The policy continues:
As part of the scheduled review of the RAS during 1996, we will examine administrative arrangements to ensure they are not discriminatory.

The policy says that they would also `consider whether the "exceptional circumstances" provisions should be triggered in situations where a series of events occurs which are not exceptional in isolation, but are in their cumulative effect'. They are the sorts of things they were talking about in their policy document. This was a policy document of the Liberal and National parties.

They also said they were going to be `working with the states to develop a consistent definition of and administrative arrangements for drought "exceptional circumstances"'. They were obviously going to work closely with the states. It is pretty apparent from the comments of the Queensland minister that they did not work too closely with the states because he is pretty angry about the whole show. He is very angry, in fact. On 5 February last year, obviously during the election campaign, the minister said:

In relation to drought and exceptional circumstances, we will maintain and improve the national drought policy and ensure that exceptional circumstances provisions are administered in a fair and non-discriminatory manner.
I guess the way to be most non-discriminatory is to throw the whole thing out, as I said before.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what they're going to do.

—That is what they are going to do; have no doubts. When I look at the draft policy on this that was taken to ARMCANZ last year, I see that Senator Brownhill did certainly talk about a number of the objectives. He encouraged the widespread adoption by primary producers throughout Australia of a planned, self-reliant approach to farming risks and talked about the need to improve understanding of drought and drought policy, the need to ensure farm families are provided with the means to secure their welfare requirements and the need to ensure that the desirable ongoing structural adjustments to Australia's rural industries are not impeded.
—You left one out.

—He left a number out, I suspect. They are the objectives. There are the general policy measures and then we get to farm business measures. Point 5 on page 10 of this draft says, `Exceptional circumstances subsidies for farm businesses to be terminated.' Isn't that interesting. It was even in their own documentation that they were flaunting around last year.

BREAK.PARA: They talk about farm savings reserve schemes. Most farmers that I am talking to these days are complaining because they are having difficulty having some sort of income. The wool industry is struggling; the beef industry is struggling; wheat prices are down; there is a whole range of these things. Farmers are telling me that their income levels are such that they are not able at this stage to put any money away. It has been only 12 months or less in some areas since the drought ended. These people are still recovering from that drought. And what do their mates do? In a draft discussion paper, they put up to ARMCANZ: `Exceptional circumstances subsidies for farm businesses to be terminated.' That exposes them for what they are about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear.
—They are not about caring for people in the bush.
—Just another big, broken promise.

—Absolutely. Senator Collins spoke about all the reviews they are conducting. I wonder when they are going to conduct a review of the reviews, because it really is getting Monty Pythonesque. If it was not so serious, this would be something of great humour for everybody. But lest they think the rural communities are happy with how they are doing, let me quote Jim Maxwell, the Manilla National Party branch chairman and mayor of Manilla. He is an angry man. An article in the Northern Daily Leader last year states:

BREAK.PARA: He's angry and disillusioned that "the National Party has completely forgotten country people".
And the Manilla Shire mayor is particularly angry with John Anderson, the local Federal MP for Gwydir.
"John Anderson has completely deserted the people who put him there," Mr Maxwell said.
The National Party's Manilla branch chairman said: `There's a lot of anger coming from people who believe John Anderson doesn't care about them, that he's ignoring the grass roots'.
"People out here are
—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak on this urgency motion and deal with a number of matters. I would like to begin first of all by quoting from A national drought policy , a report prepared by the Senate Standing Committee of Rural and Regional Affairs in July 1992. One obviously cannot go into this in detail, but on page xii it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee considers that the Commonwealth Government should provide effective financial incentives for primary producers to prepare and manage for drought.

Who was on that committee? Senator Burns, Senator Brownhill, Senator Bell, Senator Calvert, Senator Crane, Senator Reynolds, Senator Sherry and—would you believe it after what we just heard—Senator West.

What this policy is about and what I believe the previous government was hoping to do at that time was to put that into place. That is the direction in which drought policy in this country at this time is moving. There are a number of misconceptions about this. First of all I want to deal with this motion, which Senator Brownhill and Senator MacGibbon have already addressed some aspects of. The motion says:
The abandonment of Australian farmers by the Federal Government as demonstrated by the refusal of the Queensland Government to sign the new National Drought Policy . . .

I have to say: one, it is very hard to make sense out of it; two, it is an absolute nonsense; and, three, no state government has signed it. It was decided last week, when discussions were held, that further discussions, which I will come to in a moment or two, on a number of aspects of that policy were to continue and then be dealt with.

This motion before us today, with all due respect to you Senator Woodley, is not sensible. You have been quite sensible on the rural committee, on which I have worked with you. In fact, it is quite unbelievable that you should bring forward a motion such as this. I believe it is more about trying to create an atmosphere to assist you in your preselection for the coming Senate election.

I would be rather surprised if the Democrats were going to challenge you, Senator Woodley. On what particular aspect? I do not know. I do not get involved in these things in Queensland as far as Democrat senators are concerned. I think you would have done yourself a service if you had checked out the facts of the current position.

We heard from Senator Bob Collins—`I'll pat myself on the back. I did a pretty good job when I was minister in dealing with the situation when exceptional circumstances arose.' We have acknowledged that in this place. Also in talking about exceptional circumstances, he mentioned the 25-year drought. We have the 10-year drought, the 40-year drought and the 100-year drought, which is what is generally talked about—I had not heard about the 25-year drought, but the number of years does not concern me very much.

It is generally considered that the drought in the 1990s was in the category of the 100-year drought. It was also considered that the drought in the final years of the Fraser government was in that same category. In both instances, the federal governments reacted—one a Liberal government and one a Labor government—at that particular time to the circumstances in which they found themselves.

I would suggest to everybody in this chamber, if we have in 10 years time, 20 years time or 100 years time similar circumstances in Queensland, New South Wales, Western Australia or anywhere else in this country, you would get a similar reaction to those circumstances at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had two 100-year droughts in 10 years.

—That is because of the terminology used to measure the severity of the drought. That is how they are measured. You would need to recognise that the input of the Fraser government would have been worth more, I believe, in real terms than the input of your government. I have not done those figures. I am making the point that, when governments are confronted with these situations, they react accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time I have available to me here, I wish to deal with some of the things still under discussion in relation to this. This is the point that Senator Woodley needs to bear in mind when he moves these motions. One that I certainly would agree with is the first one—the value of the farm savings reserve scheme.

One of the things that this report does deal with is IEDs. To the shame of the Labor Party—and I particularly mention here ex-Senator Peter Walsh—we did have what I believe was a very good IED scheme in place. If you look at the figures for that IED scheme at that particular time, you will see that it was attractive to farmers who invested in their good years. It was decimated.

Senator West said that wheat prices are down. They might not be as high as they were last year, but they are the second highest on record so far as grain is concerned. People need the opportunity to put some money away and that was destroyed. One of the most important things that we can do as a parliament in terms of drought is to allow people to prepare themselves. That is recognised in the report and that has been a thing which we have all spoken of many times.

Another point that was raised that is still being discussed and dealt with is the time frame for the exceptional circumstances measures. Spelt out very clearly in a number of press releases from the minister is the intent to allow exceptional circumstances to continue as they exist in areas that are currently declared as drought affected under those arrangements.

I can go through these particular aspects and the decisions, but I do not have time to continue, so I will wind up my comments. The one thing we have done for people both in drought and not in drought is to address the problems that exist in this country with interest rates mainly because of spending more money than we earned as a nation during the years of the previous Labor government. We have seen the results of our change of policy. I quote this because it is very instructive.

People with $500,000 debt, which is not a lot in the farm sector today, because of the drop in interest rates which has occurred—and people in drought areas are particularly affected by this—already have had savings of some $7,500 and it is higher than that per property. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Woodley's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Carr did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (RECEIVER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1996
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1996

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Telecommunications Bill 1996 and ten associated bills, together with submissions received by the committee and Hansard record of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The 11 bills that were referred to the committee form a comprehensive package of legislation designed to establish the regulatory framework for telecommunications in Australia from 1 July 1997 onwards. The bills contain 826 pages of legislation as well as the associated explanatory memoranda. They were referred to the committee on 10 December 1996.

The objectives of the post‐1997 regulatory framework are to facilitate the development of an Australian telecommunications industry based on: world class infrastructure using the latest market driven technology mix; a multitude of service providers offering diverse and innovative carriage and content services; and contestable market strategies which drive prices down and quality of service up.
The inquiry was advertised in the national press on 14 and 18 December 1996. It was also advertised on the Internet via the Senate World Wide Web homepage from 13 December 1996.

The committee received 88 written submissions and a number of additional supplementary submissions from a broad range of individuals and organisations. Following the closing date for submissions, the committee also received a large number of correspondence about unfounded rumours that it might be persuaded by Telstra to allow the imposition of timed charges on local data calls.

The committee held public hearings on 29 and 30 January 1997, and on 7, 14 and 18 February 1997 at Parliament House, Canberra. A total of 91 witnesses appeared before the committee, many of them appearing on multiple occasions.

The committee's report follows the structure of the bills. The committee's recommendations are considered in order of the section of the bills to which they refer. Chapter 9 of the report considers issues which do not fit clearly into any of the individual bills.

Because of the time constraints faced by the committee, it was not possible to report on all of the issues raised during the inquiry. The report deals only with those issues where committee members have recommended specific amendments to legislation or other measures dealing with a particular area of concern.

BREAK.PARA: Some issues which were the subject of numerous submissions and considerable discussion during the hearings are therefore not discussed in this report. Although the committee spent considerable time examining all of the evidence put to it, on many occasions it decided not to recommend any changes to the bills.

To a large degree, the broad rationale of the proposed arrangements is accepted by all stakeholders. The committee's intention was therefore not to re‐open debate on broad issues of policy but rather to ensure that the bills provide for the implementation of the policy intentions in a workable manner.

This inquiry found that the telecommunications package of bills will effectively regulate the post‐1 July 1997 telecommunications regime. They will provide the framework for an open telecommunications market while establishing world‐class consumer safeguard arrangements. The committee has therefore recommended that the bills be passed, subject to those amendments contained in its report and any drafting problems which may come to light.

The majority report contains recommendations, most of which provide for specific amendments to the legislative package. These recommendations will help the Senate to finetune a very complex, but well prepared, package of legislation. In particular, improvements are proposed in regard to the following matters: carrier and service provider regulation; the universal service obligation; untimed local calls; emergency call services; privacy matters; industry development; carriers' powers and immunities; competition regulation; transitional arrangements; re‐allocation of radiocommunications spectrum; the definition of the standard telephone service; and specific provisions to facilitate telecommunications access for people with disabilities. The committee is confident that the amendments proposed in this report represent an appropriate balance of industry and community interests.

I will make a few brief comments on the way the inquiry was managed. This inquiry was very well run by the committee secretariat. I would like to acknowledge the high standard of the material that was prepared for the committee members, and the competent management of the inquiry process. I am sure that the other committee members would join me in thanking all of the committee staff who contributed to this inquiry for their efforts. I believe that the conduct of this inquiry sets a good example for the running of other bills' inquiries dealing with major, technically difficult legislation. I will therefore take a few moments to describe some aspects of the conduct of the inquiry.

The submissions for this inquiry were provided to senators and witnesses in bound, page numbered volumes. This meant that throughout the hearings both the committee members and the witnesses were able to find quickly the relevant page of a submission without having to shuffle through mountainous piles of loose paper—and anybody who has been on a committee which has had a large number of submissions will remember how those submissions appear in your office tied with pink ribbon and, after you have fossicked through them, to re-establish some sort of order is beyond reason. So this was a tremendous system for which I thank the committee. This approach contributed significantly to both the smooth flow of public hearings and the preparation of the report. In the committee hearing itself, you were able to refer to a page number and everyone knew what you were talking about—and that has not always been the case with some other hearings I have participated in.

For the public hearings, the briefing material was equally well presented. It was divided into the key issues raised with the committee and summarised the main points raised in all the submissions on that issue. This enabled the committee members to identify quickly the main points of contention between witnesses and to focus their questioning on those key points. So what I am saying here is that the briefing material also was well presented.

The public hearings were programmed to deal with subject areas which had received prominence in submissions. The committee questioned the witnesses on each subject area collectively. Up to 18 witnesses appeared before the committee simultaneously during the hearings. Although this approach required witnesses concerned with multiple subject areas to make multiple appearances, it enabled greater elucidation of issues than would have been the case if witnesses were called to appear separately before the committee. Only by using this form was the committee able to hear the views of the large number of witnesses who appeared before it in the very limited time available. This format also enabled the committee to identify quickly the main areas of disagreement between the witnesses and to focus on those areas.

The round table approach placed unusual demands on the committee secretariat and extraordinary demands on the Hansard reporters. I would like to thank both the committee secretariat and the Hansard reporters who were involved for their cooperation in what sometimes was not an easy task in determining who was speaking and getting some order out of what could have been chaotic. But we managed, and I think it provided another model for the approach to a hearing.

Throughout the hearings, Mr Tony Shaw, Mr Rohan Buettel and other senior officers of DOCA were present at the witness table. Again, this is not a usual practice. They were able to provide immediate responses to many of the concerns raised by the witnesses. This added greatly to the effectiveness of the inquiry. I would like to acknowledge publicly the committee's appreciation of the assistance they provided.

During the hearings on 14 February, the committee took evidence from witnesses representing Australians with a hearing impairment. I understand that this was the first occasion on which a Senate committee has taken evidence from witnesses with a hearing impairment through sign interpreters. The evidence they gave the committee on their concerns about telecommunications was very valuable. I was glad the committee was able to find the time to give them a hearing. I would like to thank the Sound and Vision Office for assisting the committee to take evidence from these witnesses.

The Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, provided considerable assistance to the committee. He made himself available to the committee on three occasions for private briefings on the bills. He provided additional resources to the committee to help it deal with the more technical aspects of the bills, and he also gave the committee very detailed comments on all of the amendments suggested in the submissions to the committee. I would like to thank him and both his and his department's staff for their assistance.

In conclusion, I would also like to thank Senator Short who took over as chairman of the committee while I was otherwise engaged on parliamentary business visiting the Antarctic bases. He got the committee's inquiry off to an excellent start. I thank him very much for his contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of the opposition to this motion to take note of the report of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee on the package of telecommunications bills, which were introduced into this parliament in 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I get to the opposition's minority report, we want to place on record the opposition's appreciation of the staff of the secretariat. In my own minority report I list all the staff. In view of the complexity of this package of bills, I can only pay the secretariat the highest compliment for their preparation work for the committee in briefing notes and drafting the report. The report is, despite the complexity of the issues, I believe, quite readable and will become a very useful source of information to the broader telecommunications community in Australia.

I also acknowledge that the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) allowed a couple of staff from his department to serve on the committee. They served the committee loyally and did very well. I also have to make particular reference to Frank Nugent, the secretary of this inquiry, who did so well in preparing the material for us. All staff on that committee secretariat deserve full compliments and congratulations from the senators on the committee.

I also want to briefly mention, as Senator Patterson did, the unique feature of this inquiry, and that is the way this legislation committee enabled the various parties and interest groups to appear before it and speak to their submissions. This was not a references committee inquiry; this was a legislation committee inquiry. When the legislation came before the parliament late last year, I suggested to the minister that the way to stop a plethora of amendments to such complex legislation from all sorts of interest groups, which would be very confusing to deal with in the normal committee stage of the Senate, would be to refer it straight off to the legislation committee, call for submissions and ask those who put submissions in to detail their amendments and have those debated before the committee.

To enable that to happen in a manner which would expedite the work of the committee, we encouraged people to come and sit at the table. We sometimes had as many as 10 different interest groups around the table. I think this has gone beyond what any other committee has tried and it was an outstanding success. I recommend this process to other legislation committees. It was valuable to all senators to hear the arguments of various interest groups at the same time so that we could more quickly get to the nub of an issue. When Telstra and Optus were arguing over interconnect fees or price discrimination, having them arguing the points back and forth enabled senators—particularly, I have to say, me—to get more quickly to a view about who had a more correct argument.

I think that worked extremely well. I also have to compliment the departmental officers who sat there through most of those hearings. Mr Tony Shaw and his officers were able to pass comment on what the views of the department and the government were on the various submissions. I think the process is to be commended. I would commend it to the Senate overall. I think the Procedure Committee of the Senate, if that is the appropriate committee, ought to have a look at the style of this operation and recommend it—even if it means juggling a few standing orders of the operation of committees. I believe this process will make the committee stage of the Senate work better.

BREAK.PARA: The opposition overwhelmingly supports the 500 or 600 pages of these bills—explanatory memorandum and second reading speeches. The process of these bills was started when we were in government, particularly by Mr Michael Lee, the then Minister for Communications and the Arts. The changes made by the new government during 1996 were marginal; they did not change the general thrust of the bills, and the opposition continues to overwhelmingly support that general thrust.

I want to pay tribute to the work that Michael Lee did as the minister who started this process. I also want to pay tribute to the various interest groups who contributed to the process when we were in government and who continued to work with Minister Alston to get to the stage we were at when these bills were introduced last year.

The general thrust of the bill is within the philosophy that we adopted in government and but we are dealing now with what I call fine tuning, but in some significant areas. That has led the opposition to make a number of amendments to the legislation. I do not think the amendments, in some areas, are too far away from what the government is proposing. The opposition still offers to participate with the government over the next week or so, until the committee stage starts, in negotiations to see whether we can reach common ground on the areas where the report has indicated there are still some differences between government senators, the Labor opposition and the Democrats, who have also put in a minority report.

I think it ought to be noted that, despite the differences of opinion between the different parties on the Senate committee, there was an enormous amount of goodwill in the discussion across a whole range of issues. There was a lot of give and take when people found that they were not ideological issues at stake but more practical and commonsense issues on what is the best way for this new regime to work from 1 July.

The opposition indicates that, via its amendments, it will strongly support the continuation of untimed local phone calls for both voice and data for business customers and residential customers. We will also put in a separate recommendation to guarantee regional residential customers that, as far as possible, their local call charges will be the same as those call charges—which will be dropping in the competitive market—of the metropolitan areas of Australia. We do not want to see local calls in the metropolitan areas of Australia dropping to 20c per untimed local call and the rural areas still paying 25c for their untimed local call. We think the competition impact should flow through.

We have a difference of opinion in our amendment compared with the government's. I hope that, during the discussions over the next 10 days, we may be able to reach common ground on that. If we do not, there will have to be a debate in the Senate about that.

The biggest issue, which that had most submissions from the broader community, was that of immunities in relation to infrastructure and roll out. I think we cannot disagree with what the government has put forward in a number of areas. Local government organisations and the local community for the first time will have the right to appeal against the construction of major infrastructure in their area. If they cannot reach agreement with a carrier, either the carrier or the local community or the local government body can go through an appeal process.

The opposition has a different view from the government in that we do not believe it necessary to allow the state governments to impose, in between the local government and the federal provisions, a new provision, a new code and a new planning process. We believe that will create delays, add extra cost and will not achieve, in the end, a speeding up of the process. In our view, what it will do is lead to Australia having eight different planning codes for telecommunications. We do not believe we ought to go down that road.

There ought to be one simple planning regulation. If the community disagrees with it, they have the right to appeal, as we recommend, to the Australian Communications Authority as the final arbitrator, which can balance the local interests and local issues against the national interest of having a national telecommunications system. We believe that is a very important amendment, and we will strongly push that.

We also believe that industry development plans should be mandatory and have a sanction on the carriers so that the Australian industry can develop. We also believe that there should be a long-term plan arranged so that those communities that presently have overhead telecommunications cables on poles know that over the long-term there is a plan to get them underground. We will strongly push that issue as well. In the second reading debate and then in the committee stage, we will explain further our amendments. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak to the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee but, rather than devote my comments specifically to the recommendations that the opposition senators are making, I would like to comment more generally on some of the outcomes of this particular inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the issues that really was highlighted through this whole process was the nature of the development of technology with respect to telecommunications. What we got, as elected representatives, was a very good insight as to exactly where Australia is going with its telecommunications infrastructure, not only with respect to telephony and facsimile services, as we currently are used to, but also the future directions of other telecommunications services, particularly those relating to the Internet.

One of the particular issues of concern was, of course, untimed local data calls. During the inquiry a lot of time was spent analysing and considering the impacts upon the imposition of perhaps a regulation providing for the maintenance of untimed local data calls, whether it be in respect of the residential or business sector.

As my colleague Senator Schacht said, we on the opposition side are firmly in favour of the maintenance of untimed data calls in both the residential and business sector. This is all good and well but, when you analyse why we have taken this position, it is important to understand that we cannot consider data calls in the old context. We have to consider data calls and how those calls will be used in the future. With 40 per cent of Australian homes now with a PC, it is not an unreasonable expectation that some time in the future a far greater percentage than those currently connected to the Internet will be connected.

On the business side, more and more Australian businesses everyday are becoming connected to the Internet. Charging for timed connections for Internet service providers will impinge upon their ability and affordability to access that telecommunications service. I believe very strongly that in the interests of access to the forms of technology that are becoming more widely used in the Australian community we have to preserve the untimed call provision for both local residents and local businesses.

Another issue I would like to mention in a broad context is that of spectrum allocation. In the context of this report, the nature of spectrum allocation with the current reallocation process occurring was discussed very widely. Once again, it is an issue that goes to the heart of trying as legislators to anticipate where future technologies are going to emerge.

In contemplating the factors of this particular set of bills, we need to be able to antici pate technological developments but not confine or restrict this legislation to any specific technology. It has been quite a fine line to provide for the scope necessary to allow new technologies to emerge and become part of the competitive market while still putting in place the appropriate safeguards to ensure that all consumers have access to the affordable and appropriate type of communication networks as they become available.

I think one other thing that really comes to fruition with the outcome of this inquiry is that with this set of technical bills there were so many areas to canvass there was a lot of common ground between all parties. There were around seven areas, as Senator Schacht said, in which Labor has a different view. By and large, the government was prepared to accept many of the issues put before it by various interest groups and industry players.

It was interesting to see the nature of evidence that came before the committee. Not only did we have the standard responses or submissions of industry players, existing carriers, but the quality of the submissions from the various industry representative groups, whether it be from Internet users or service providers or groups representing consumers in a certain area, says so much about where Australia is at with telecommunications and information technology.

I think it is starting to dawn on certainly all the senators present on this inquiry, and I think it is starting to dawn on the government, that Australia is uniquely positioned with respect to our developing information technology industry. We are very strongly placed in our global region, but we are also quite capable as a nation to really seize the opportunity to become a leader in the development of information technology. This is where Labor feels very strongly about the necessity of providing for sanctions to make the carriers commit themselves to a decisive industry development plan.

One of our recommendations that differed from the government's was to impose such sanctions upon the provision and implementation of industry development plans of the various licence holders. In that regard I think what we need to be saying to the industry is that this government and this parliament wants to see that industry expand, see the potential and be able to use it, not languish with some decrepit old legislative structure within which carriers and new technology providers struggle. We need a regime that allows development to flourish, that utilises the potential of this country's innovative companies who are now proving their potential in the export markets.

I think as a result of this inquiry we are all much better informed as to the depth of the innovation that we are capable of in this country. I urge all senators who have not taken the opportunity to peruse some of the submissions to this particular inquiry to do so. They should take note of this expertise, of this unique position that we are in, and apply that knowledge and that insight not just in the context of what is, by and large, a relatively dry set of technical pieces of legislation but apply it in a far more innovative way.

We need to recognise that it does not only impact upon that particular sector of industry; but, as someone recently put it, information technology is an enabling industry. It is not an industry that is insular. It enables all other Australian industries to be able to obtain some advantage. It supports them and enhances their position in the global market. So when we talk about the telecommunications industry or information technology we should be thinking as a parliament, as legislators, of not just the confines and the scope of the potential of the industry itself—which is huge—but also in the context that it enables the rest of Australian industry to advance itself to a point that would give us some advantage in a competitive global market.

In summing up, the thing I found so heartening about this inquiry was the level of new ideas and innovation that came forth through the submissions. A lot of the submissions dealt with quite specific amendments but a lot of submissions came through with some new ideas that were a bit too radical, I think, for us legislators to get a grip on at this point in time. But as our knowledge improves about new technologies, about the Internet, about the global communications revolution that is occurring, it is my hope that in the future we will be able to get a grasp of some of these new and innovative ideas on how to deal with this industry and implement them in legislation that will benefit us as a nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
