TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last couple of weeks we have heard a lot of talk in here about the right to free education. Senator Carr said in this place last week that the downgrading of the pubic education system was appalling and claimed that it was `a mean and philosophically withered view of society' for which we would all be condemned. As usual, his rhetoric is both wrong and irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that Australia's future depends on becoming internationally competitive and that process begins here at home with our schools, our teachers and our pupils. Tonight I want to give the Senate a first-class example of a South Australian school's quite innovative approach to education which links the school with the workplace, which is very important in these days of high unemployment.

In April last year, Salisbury High School, in a struggling area in the northern part of Adelaide, established a $30,000 scheme to tackle the problem of chronic, long-term youth unemployment in their region. They formed a partnership between industry and the school so that they could work together. It is South Australia's first enterprise high school.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the industry?

—The industry, Senator Carr, will be revealed to you if you just listen. Salisbury is an area with chronic high unemployment not only among the young people but also, sadly, among their parents. In fact, there is in some cases third generation unemployment. In Salisbury, youth unemployment has reached a very tragic 42 per cent of the local population.

SPEECH.PARA: Expanding information technology industries do offer enormous employment opportunities. Until recently, employers in the region have had to go outside the area to get skilled workers. This has been expensive for the companies and did not help the local unemployed people. So now in Salisbury there is a connection between the school and other training providers in the region and, most importantly, with employers.

An important first step has been the partnership signed between Salisbury High School and AWA Defence Industries, which is now part of British Aerospace—British Aerospace, Senator Carr. The agreement will increase contact between the school and the industry, linking education to economic development in the area and, most importantly, to jobs.

Students now learn in workplaces such as British Aerospace, Motorola and in some small businesses in the region. This innovative program has already introduced significant educational benefit for students, their parents and the teachers.

It has helped to encourage more highly motivated and enthusiastic students. It has increased opportunities for future productive employment and training. It has provided greater educational awareness, more flexibility in problem solving skills and research and, most importantly, it has helped teachers stay in touch and update their skills and their knowledge.

There are also great benefits for industry. Mr Graham Smith, a manager from British Aerospace, has commented that the program is `a two‐way partnership'. He has given the example of his staff receiving computer education at Salisbury High School, so school facilities are being used out of school hours through sensible sharing of resources. Simultaneously, the school is supporting important adult education activities in the region.This is a scheme that is meeting employers' expectations as well as providing very valuable learning opportunities for the whole district.

Salisbury High School is in one of Adelaide's more disadvantaged areas. It has taken a very enterprising approach to a chronic problem in its area and it is getting results. A brochure from the school expresses quite clearly what is being done to tackle the problem. Its very revealing mission statement says:

The development of an enterprise culture in the school will act as a catalyst for young people to be in charge of their own destiny and successfully attain the required skills and competencies for work.

This approach is consistent with the coalition's policy of providing more diversity and more choice in schools. It is giving families more interest in—some might say more control over—their children's education and a greater sense of involvement and, most important of all, the chance to get a job. This approach also goes hand in hand with key initiatives from the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), with initiatives such as MAATS, which is designed to improve Australia's training system and create real jobs.

Can I say how much I applaud all those people at Salisbury High School who have been involved in the scheme, and British Aerospace, who have also assisted in its establishment. I commend them, as I am sure other senators would, for their enterprise and their vision. In particular, I commend them for the positive contribution that they are making to help young people take a greater control of their lives. We all know that if people are able to go home at the end of a day feeling as if they have achieved something worth while, something that has made their day a little different from a day spent at home unable to find a job day after day, it helps those young people feel more involved and more positive about their lives.

This scheme at Salisbury High School is helping young people to take charge of their future and to do things for themselves which in turn will create, in the longer term, a competitive and prosperous Australia, which we all aspire to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Importation of Cooked Chicken Meat Medicare

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on two matters that I have raised on numerous occasions before. I do want to make it clear to the Senate that they are matters that are still of great concern to the community. The first is the issue of the importation of chicken meats. As you may recall, I had debated that issue previously. I just want to make it very clear that the community has not been tranquillised by referring the issue off to AQIS again. In fact, there are members of the Liberal Party who are extremely concerned about what has occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to read to you a copy of a letter addressed to Mr Andrew Robb, federal director of the Liberal Party. I will not read it all but only some sections of it. If anyone is interested, I am happy to provide copies. It says:
Regarding cooked chicken meat imports:

On 31 May 1996, we wrote to you advising that if cooked chicken meat imports were allowed into Australia, there was no way we would continue to remain members of the Liberal Party. In his latest press statement of the 22nd June, Mr Anderson has made it quite clear that he now intends to allow cooked chicken meat imports early this year as soon as cooking procedures have been finalised and it is obvious to us that from now on, even if he should change his decision, it will only be as a result of extreme pressure from the chicken industry and environmental movement. The effect of Mr Anderson's decision is that cooked chicken meat imports will eventually bring with it Newcastle disease, resulting in disastrous consequences for our native bird life.

Mr Anderson and your government have turned down the unanimous all‐party Senate inquiry findings, the main point of which was area certification—i.e. that imports should only be allowed from areas certified free of disease, an internationally accepted practice. He has not listened to a majority of parliamentarians, including most of his own party. He has turned down a motion passed at the annual conference of the New South Wales Liberal Party, and his decision is strongly condemned by the Australian Conservation Foundation, the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales, the New South Wales Minister for the Environment, the Australian Veterinarians Association, Dr Balkar Bains and Dr Paul Gilchrist, probably the most widely recognised authorities on poultry disease in the world and New South Wales respectively. A survey which showed 95 per cent of Australians are against these imports . . .
The letter goes on at some length and I will not read all of it. Then it says:

. . . Mr Anderson and your government may have the right to destroy the chicken industry in pursuit of justifying a position on trade, but you do not have the right to decimate our native bird life and jeopardise the survival of some species. We accordingly tender our resignation from the Liberal Party to take effect immediately.

It is signed by two people from Mangrove Mountain in New South Wales. It is the largest chicken producing area in Australia. It produces about 10 per cent of the chicken meat sold across Australia. As well, I would like to table 222 letters I have received on the issue of chicken meats, to go along with the hundreds of other letters I have already tabled.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is also another issue that I would emphasise this evening—again, an issue I have raised on numerous occasions before—and that is the decision by this government in the last budget to close Medicare offices around Australia. Despite the statement by the government that they would be closing 35 offices by the end of this year, they seem to have—either through good luck or poor management—not managed to close any yet. But they do tell us that they are on track and will be closing some either just before or just after the end of the financial year.

BREAK.PARA: Some statement was made in estimates and today by Senator Newman in relation to the closure of Medicare offices that, in fact, the effect of these closures would be limited because of the opening up of pharmacies as places where claims can be faxed to the Health Insurance Commission. But, as anyone who is familiar with this proposition would be aware, the pharmacies option is not a reasonable replacement for those Medicare offices because, firstly, rather than providing a personal service and cash immediately, it will only provide the opportunity to fax in your claim form and have it then processed and returned to you in the mail; but, secondly and most tellingly, these pharmacies will only be placed in areas where there is an isolated chemist or a chemist that receives an isolated area subsidy. The fact is that Medicare offices, by their definition, are only placed in areas of higher population. Therefore, there is no coincidence between an area where a pharmacy Medicare processing point would be placed and where a Medicare office may be closed.

There is very strong concern in the community about this continued intention of the government to close Medicare offices—35 by the end of this year or shortly thereafter, as advised by the department—and their budget forecasts indicate that, unless there is a change of decision, Medicare offices will continue to close and members of the community will not be able to get that personal service and cash over the counter that they are used to.

I now would like to table 1,177 protest notes that I have received from just one electorate to indicate to this government that they should really be seriously considering their position. The Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services (Senator Newman) indicated today that consultation will be undertaken before Medicare offices are closed. I say, for the benefit of this government, that you should proceed with that consultation very carefully, because anger will be expressed by people if their Medicare offices are closed, and there certainly will be some rebound on you in the future. But I ask you to reconsider your position and do not close those Medicare offices. I ask for leave to table those 1,177 protest notes.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —There are 4,946 liquor licensed sporting and community clubs throughout Australia. The Australian Democrats are concerned that many private licensed registered clubs are undertaking activities which can be considered as a substantial deviation from their original purpose whilst still being able to claim a tax exempt status. Therefore, they are competing in the marketplace with an unfair advantage over their competitors who are required to pay taxes. It is not even compulsory for all clubs to submit tax returns.

SPEECH.PARA: The competitive advantage to clubs which is derived from their tax exempt status is an important example of major distortions in the Australian tax system. It is also a perfect example of where the government could raise revenue to meet pressing budgetary needs. Conservative estimates show that $85 million could be collected annually by the government.

The private licensed registered club industry in Australia is afforded tax-free status on income derived from members. The favourable income tax treatment is through the principle of mutuality. The mutuality principle provides that, where a number of persons contribute to a common fund that is created and managed as a common interest, any excess earnings that are generated from the use of the fund are not, for the purposes of taxation, to be considered income. This is an excellent system. But it is only excellent where it is not abused—and it is abused.

In essence, private licensed registered clubs are only assessable for taxation that is earned from trading with non-members. The determination of taxable income of non-members is based on what is known as the Waratah principle. That principle is derived from the Waratah's Rugby Union Football Club v. FCT, 1979, 10 ATR 33‐79, which is now probably outmoded.

The question that this raises is the matter of the regulation of sign-in procedures in clubs. The enforcement of membership amongst its customers by a club is of major concern from a tax point of view. It is in the interests of licensed clubs to be less vigilant in the policing of the numbers of non-members in a club and, therefore, this clearly serves as an incentive to distort the level of income that is declared for taxation purposes.

This results in many clubs having an unfair advantage over hotels and other tax paying businesses, including gymnasiums, travel agents, bus operators, hairdressers and butchers. The current situation has a severe effect on the hotel and other associated hospitality and service industries. If left unchecked, it will undoubtedly result in reduced investment in those industries, many of which are small businesses, which will result in being to the detriment of Australia as a whole.
The loopholes need to be tightened up. Government happily tightens the budget and tax screws on ordinary Australians. But clubs which abuse these loopholes are so far escaping the net.

The fact that large clubs do not have to pay income tax on their gaming operations means that other operations of the club can be subsidised, including food and beverages, entertainment and accommodation, along with undertaking further activities and capital expenditure. The major influence of the large clubs appears to be in New South Wales, Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory. The benefits for `members and guests' in accessing cheap subsidised club operations—including dining and bar facilities, gym and entertainment—in these areas are to the detriment of taxpayers in the other states and territories and in the entertainment industry.

Evidence that clubs are using their tax concessions to threaten private enterprise includes the disclosure by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 13 December 1996 that New South Wales clubs have not paid any income tax on more than $138 million derived from the Club Keno electronic lottery game. The club industry apparently faces up to $50 million in back income tax alone on Club Keno.

BREAK.PARA: Documentation shows that 34 clubs have not paid income tax on a combined revenue of $80 million, including $8.9 million and $6.9 million tax-free to the Manly-Warringah and St George rugby league football clubs respectively. Over $1.1 billion is spent annually by New South Wales clubs alone on capital works, plant, refurbishment and new poker machines. That expenditure includes: a proposed $50 million development at the Blacktown Workers Club; a $30 million club hotel at Gosford Leagues Club; and a $100 million development at Canterbury Leagues Club, including a 240-room hotel. Those are very large businesses. They are hardly clubs in the general sense of the word.

Examples of the limited amounts of tax being paid by clubs include the Panthers Rugby League Club, where the club paid only 1.4 per cent income tax on its 1996 profit of $4,482,459. This is despite the fact that Panthers, which had a 1996 revenue of $83 million, received $596,330 in interest in 1996 and has admitted that up to 60 Taiwanese tourists, who cannot possibly be Panthers members, stayed at the club and played the poker machines each night. These are businesses, not clubs and, like many clubs, these are part of the entertainment industry. Panthers are directing some of their profits into a $22 million 16-screen cinema complex which they announced in October 1996. The cinema will compete with private enterprise cinema complexes.

Concern has also been expressed at the fact that the level of community contributions from clubs is not accurately measured. The role of clubs should be to support community projects in sport or welfare. Many do, and the Australian Democrats strongly support the continuation of that community service. But there are many cases in which it can be shown that clubs are paying nothing or a very small percentage of their profit back to the community. This is an unacceptable distortion and manipulation of the tax system.

The Australian Democrats support the proposal whereby the commercial activities of private licensed registered clubs which are operating as a business should be subject to company tax as any other business enterprise. Clubs should also be obliged to pay a mandatory sum to community organisations as part of their charter. Apparent constraints on the Taxation Office and the courts to effectively interpret the current taxation exemption in respect of clubs should be removed by both legislative change and a more vigorous enforcement and evaluation procedure.

One proposal that I am aware of is that section 23(g)(iii) of the taxation laws should give effect to a test that clubs show that the principal activity of that club is in accordance with the original objectives of the club. The effect of this change would be that where clubs have a principal activity relating to social activity, as distinct from sporting or community activities, then there would be definitive guidelines whereby the tax office would be in a position to review those clubs in order to reassess their taxation exemptions.

A further proposal is that a mandatory donation of, say, four per cent of gross turnover be paid by each club to registered charities and community organisations, provided a certain level of profit or surplus is achieved. A conservative estimate of the possible tax revenue arising from such proposals is $84 million annually and a community benefit of $186 million based on the mandatory donation of four per cent of gross turnover.

The Australian Democrats would ask that the government review this situation and believe that this situation must be addressed as a matter of urgency to assist small business competitors that are being unfairly disadvantaged, to provide revenue to assist in reducing the deficit currently facing this government and to contribute to government's budgetary needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unhappily, whenever there is media comment on matters relating to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, particularly in the area that I come from in the north, it often involves stories of conflict and division—all bad news stories fuelled by media reporting of comments by particular parliamentarians. So tonight I want to speak about a good news story about an exciting initiative for Aboriginal and Islander people in a community that I had the privilege of inspecting recently in Townsville.

SPEECH.PARA: The Shalom community development is a totally interactive community offering principally indigenous Australians—and I emphasise principally, because it is not restricted to indigenous Australians—a complete range of services and infrastructure, including: a coeducational college, both primary and secondary; an elders village and nursing home; a construction and training facility; community housing; and sporting and recreational facilities.

A couple of weeks back, I was taken on a tour of the complex by the head of the Shalom community, Reverend Shayne Blackman. I am sure, following my inspection, that the development I saw is one that well could form a model to help improve the unequal position of Australia's Aboriginal and Islanders right around the country.

The project addresses some appalling statistics of Aboriginal and Islander people. Some of those statistics are well known. Fewer than 50 per cent of Aboriginal and Islander children have any preschool experience; 85 per cent of children of compulsory school age participate in primary or secondary education, compared with the national average of 100 per cent; 11 per cent of 15-year-olds have never attended a school; 30 per cent of 16- to 17-year-olds participate in formal training, compared with the national average of some 85 per cent; and, perhaps most damning of all, 33 per cent of working age people are employed compared with the national average of about 66 per cent.

The Shalom development and Shalom community work to improve these statistics by giving indigenous people the option of choosing an educational and lifestyle option in keeping with their traditional cultures and values, while at the same time providing them with access to the sort of support that all Australians expect.

The total development is an activity of the Uniting Aboriginal and Islander Christian Congress, which is the Aboriginal arm of the Uniting Church in Australia. It is managed by a board of directors—who all happen to be indigenous people—and Reverend Blackman is the chairman.

The site is located on 31 hectares, approximately 15 kilometres from the centre of Townsville. It is almost in the middle of the rapidly expanding Thuringowa city, which is one of the twin cities that makes up the Townsville geographical area.

The college and the community were opened in March 1992. It was actually established on some land purchased through the generosity of a retired shearer and mushroom farmer from Victoria, who provided an initial sum of $860,000 to the church for this project's commencement. It has grown from providing for only two classes to now offering an impressive array of facilities. Federal and state governments provide some support for the community. Again, that support is principally the sort of support that is given to any school or any nursing home or any accommodation for elderly people right around the country. The community operates largely through church and business donations and through self-funding.

In the short time available to me, I want to mention the array of facilities at the college. There is the Shalom Christian College which currently has an enrolment of 300 students from preschool and primary school through to year 11, with facilities for extension to year 12 likely to be ready for the next school year. The schooling system is designed to prepare students for later life and does so within the Shalom philosophy of involving the total community and educational processes. For instance, parents and respected elders from within the community give valuable input as and when it is necessary. This unique approach supports the efforts of teachers and children to learn and improve their future prospects.

These educational facilities were complemented by male and female dormitories, which are also located on site. They were opened in January 1994. These allow for boarders from remote areas to live and learn as part of the complete community.

BREAK.PARA: The community area has a construction and training facility, which is integrated within the college. The community's construction company and training facility is a particularly impressive initiative and allows both students and long-term unemployed to gain genuine on-the-job work experience by building many of the facilities which appear in the community. So they gain not only real employment but real skills and real qualifications.

There are currently 39 people from the community involved in the construction company and training program. They are performing competency based training and working towards genuine qualifications through apprenticeships. Once skilled, with real qualifications, these people have the ability to enter the work force with much greater prospects for gaining employment.

Some of the projects that training and building initiative have already completed include the primary school and high school, the two dormitories, the three community houses, the training centre, the first class athletic oval, the elders village, basketball courts, a kitchen and dining room, and laundry facilities. It represents $12.5 million worth of work over a three-year period.

In fact, when I visited the community they were in the throes of constructing more classrooms on the site. Having seen these facilities first-hand, I can assure the Senate that the workmanship is of the very finest quality and is a real credit to the people involved. The construction team starts each project virtually from scratch, working from the initial design of the building right through to its completion.

In addition, there is an elders village, which reflects the special responsibilities and the place that elders hold within indigenous communities. The Shalom community also provides this elders village for aged people to live in during their later years of life. That includes a nursing home. It provides for 24 beds for elderly people and allows the community to take advantage of the wisdom and life experiences of the elders. The elders are made to feel very welcome. They are very valued members of the Shalom community, and they are involved in many aspects of community life. Their leadership gives direction to the youth and is one of the development's key support mechanisms.

For all its impressive achievements to date, the Shalom community is still growing and evolving. By the year 2000, it is anticipated that there will be over 1,000 people living, studying and working at Shalom each day—the majority of whom will be Aboriginal and islander people. Its facilities at that time will be complemented with on-site housing, an indigenous art gallery, staff accommodation, a function and conference room, a convenience store and more recreational facilities.

I was terribly impressed with this facility which is right in the heart of the fastest growing area of the Townsville-Thuringowa community. It is a real credit to the people involved. It provides a very strong rejection of the negative stereotypes of indigenous communities that have been aired recently—and they are fairly uninformed and uneducated comments—by some of those amongst us. I believe this development could be a real role model for pioneering improvements for indigenous people.

I am aware that some of my parliamentary colleagues, including Senator Woodley, have visited this establishment. For those who have not, I would urge them to visit if they are in Townsville and have half an hour to spend—although it really takes more than half an hour. They would then be able to appreciate that very fine development. I am so impressed with the whole development that I do think it forms a magnificent model—one that we could well use in other parts of Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Government Policies: Effect on Small Business

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —It was announced this week by the Electoral Commission that the ACT stands to lose one of its seats in the other place. This calculation is based on a comparative population growth estimate. I have to say that I am not surprised that the outcome of this redistribution is the loss of one seat to the ACT. Of recent times, the state of the ACT economy has been reported on numerous occasions. At this point in time, despite the grandest efforts of many local businesses and of many individuals in the ACT, it is very hard for many of those businesses to survive or to contemplate future growth in the short term.

SPEECH.PARA: The approach of this Liberal government towards small business to date has been one of talking up the situation, claiming that they are the representatives of small business in this country, that they have the policies that will see small business—the growth engines of the future—provide the jobs this country needs. On behalf of small business in this particular region, it seems that there is no depth and no substance to these words at all. In fact, in the ACT it is small business that is feeling the sharp edge of the government's cuts to the public sector. I am of the view that this government has not truly analysed the relationship that exists between the public sector, government departments and small businesses that actually provide services to them.

This situation does not just apply in Canberra or in the region with all the small businesses that feed into Canberra; it applies in every regional centre where there has been significant Commonwealth presence. There is a direct relationship between small business and the public sector. Because of our situation and our industry spread here in Canberra, we are feeling it perhaps more sharply than other places but the principle remains. How can this government say that they are pursuing the interests of those people, when you only need to walk outside of this place to see what is occurring?

The impact of outsourcing is one example of how small business can be affected. But in this case it is not so much a distinction of the impact public sector cuts are having but one of outsourcing policies. The government will be required to consider in the lead-up to the forthcoming budget how it is going to deal with the outsourcing of information technology in government departments.

At this stage there is no strong indication that small business is even going to get a look into these contracts. The nature and structure of the expressions of interest being called indicate that there is no room for our local indigenous information technology industry to even have a hope of being competitive in that process. This presents a double whammy for this particular region, which I define very broadly as being the south-east corner of New South Wales. It impacts greatly because it is one of the few strengths we have in terms of future growth.

That strength in that sector of our industry is something that has been developed, has been nurtured and has grown by virtue of the presence of the Commonwealth government departments here. So not only is this industry being impacted upon in the first instance by the cuts and the reductions in expenditure, but they are being hit again by being excluded from participating in the process in the hope of picking up some of that work that will be effectively outsourced.

Can I say this to the government: if you genuinely represent small business then you need to genuinely represent all of small business. You cannot claim to be their representative on the one hand and then, on the other hand, through your policies, seemingly do everything within your power to ensure that they do not have a future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening in response to comments that were made today by Senator Abetz in respect of long service leave pay-outs in the Australian Workers Union in Queensland. What Senator Abetz said in his brief speech here today was completely off the top of the world, completely wrong and completely unfair to Mr Ludwig and others in the AWU in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at what our friend Senator Abetz said, he started out talking about long service leave, then he got stuck into the superannuation pay-out. He then mentioned superannuation on five separate occasions when in fact the issue was not superannuation but long service leave. But the fact was that the long service leave which was availed by Mr Ludwig and others was well within the limits of the rules of that organisation and well within the law. If Senator Abetz was aware of all the facts on this issue, he would know and would have informed the parliament that the scheme he referred to in his attack on Bill Ludwig and others is quite legitimate and not in breach of any state or federal law.

As confirmed by the Queensland Minister for Industrial Relations recently, elected union officials are not employees and therefore not covered by the safety net provided for in industrial relations laws. As a consequence of this, most unions establish provisions in their rules, via legitimate resolutions of their respective executives, which give their elected officials access to respite for continuous long service to the union and its members. In the AWU, after 20 years of continuous service to members elected officials are given the option to access a lump sum rather than take leave. This provision has existed legitimately since the 1950s. It is not something that has happened recently within the AWU; it has been there for almost half a century.

I am not sure whether Senator Abetz takes four weeks annual leave in his six‐year elected term, but I have it on good authority that Mr Ludwig and others, who are elected for four‐year terms take very little leave at all. I have had that experience myself as a trade union official. Leave is few and far between for the officials.

Perhaps Mr Ludwig takes his job of representing the interests of 60,000 plus Queenslanders far more seriously than Senator Abetz takes his job. Indeed, if Senator Abetz was doing a good job representing Tasmanian electors he would not be doing the dirty work for factions in an interunion power struggle. Given the spurious nature of these allegations, Senator Abetz must be asked why he is involving himself in an interunion smear campaign. In the interests of fairness, he should reveal who sold him this smear line on Mr Ludwig and the AWU.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 23 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to sections of Highway 1 in Tasmania:

(1) Near Bracknell: (a) why was an exit up to Oaks Road near Bracknell not constructed when the new highway was completed: (b) how much did it cost to build the exit; and (c) what caused the government to change its mind about this exit after the road was completed.

(2) At Deloraine: (a) why was the wrong connector built between the old highway and the new highway east of Deloraine; (b) how much did it cost to build; (c) how much did it cost to dismantle; and (d) how much did the new connector cost.

(3) West of Liffey Bridge: (a) why has it been necessary to resurface the road for some kilometres west of Liffey Bridge so soon after it was built; (b) what did the resurfacing cost; and (c) who paid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) When the Illawarra Main Road to Hagley section of the Bass Highway realignment was built in 1992, predicted traffic volumes were insufficient to justify the construction of a full diamond interchange at the junction of the Bass Highway and Oaks Road. Instead a half‐diamond with east facing ramps was considered appropriate until traffic demand rose.

(c) East bound Bass Highway traffic wishing to access Oaks Road, and traffic from Oaks Road wishing to travel west on the Bass Highway increased beyond initial estimates which indicated a very low demand. This was compounded by the faster than estimated growth of the newly established annual 3 day AGFEST show held on Oaks Road just south of the junction with the Bass Highway, causing a demand for access to and from the west earlier than anticipated. In addition unsafe traffic behaviour had begun to develop from drivers (including drivers of commercial and agricultural vehicles) using the east facing ramps to execute `U‐turns' on the Bass Highway in the face of high speed traffic in order to travel west or to gain access to Oaks Road. The erection of traffic signage to control the traffic failed to eliminate this practice.

(2)(a) The 1.3 km connector linking the Deloraine Bypass to the Bass Highway from Bonneys Creek to the Deloraine roundabout east of the town was constructed in 1989 with the knowledge that it would be made redundant when the Deloraine Bypass linked up to the new alignment of the Bass Highway to the north of Exton. Initially this was envisaged to be between 7 to 10 years distant. However the decision in 1990 by the then Federal Minister for Transport to accelerate construction between Launceston and Deloraine, meant that the temporary connector only lasted 6 years until September 1995 when it was `dismantled' in preparation for linking the Bypass to the new alignment between Deloraine and Violet Banks which was completed and opened to traffic in August 1996. It was always envisaged that the connector would be a temporary structure.
(b) As the cost of the connector is subsumed in the original Bypass cost of $19 million, its cost cannot be separately identified.
(c) The cost of `dismantling' of the temporary connector is subsumed in the overall cost of the $21 million work linking Deloraine to Violet Banks west of Westbury.

(d) As for (c). However as the material `sacrificed' by the demolition of the connector was used in the new structure linking the Deloraine Bypass to the new route north of Exton, there was an estimated saving of some $500,000 in the total construction cost in not having to find and transport a quarter of a million cubic metres of material to provide a base for the new flood free road above the Meander River flood plain.

(3)(a) The gravel materials used by the contractor in the road base of the original work met set specifications and tested satisfactorily in laboratory conditions. However performance in situ was less than the desired optimum resulting in pavement surface failures at the site mentioned.

(c) All works on the National Highway System in Tasmania between Hobart and Burnie such as works west of Liffey River are funded by the Federal Government under the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Federal Government is committed to providing generous compensation and assistance to Australia's veteran community, and to continually improving services to veterans.
The 1996/97 Budget provided a guaranteed level of running cost funding over a three-year period. The funding provided allows my Department to meet program and service objectives.

While it is expected that staff numbers will be reduced further in the near future my Department has an excellent record in adapting to change while maintaining high standards of service to the veteran community.
(2) Core business should be seen as those activities through which an organisation can add particular value to its overall objectives. The focus of my Department will increasingly be on:
a) providing an integrated, timely and quality service in the determination of compensation payments and income support pensions;
b) purchasing and monitoring health care services;
c) cost effective facilitation of health and community services;
d) the provision of information on entitlements available to veterans and their widow(er)s;
e) providing convenient and easy access to information and services through the Veterans' Affairs Network and outreach activities; and
f) commemorating those Australian men and women who served in war.

However, core business is not an absolute concept, but one which will evolve over time as a result of operational experience and directional changes in Government policy. Core business should not imply a lesser value on non‐core activities in the effective delivery of services. Rather it should relate to the primary activities of my Department and its staff.
(3) My Department successfully outsourced its mainframe computing facilities in 1992 to Ferntree Pty Ltd.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How are withdrawals from a superannuation fund by a person of pre‐Age Pension age currently treated under the income and assets tests of the department.

(2) Can a number of examples of people in varying circumstances showing how this works in practice be provided; for example, where a 58 year old who has been on Newstart for 3 years withdraws $50,000 from his/her superannuation fund, would this person be precluded from income support for a certain period following that withdrawal.
(3) Will this system be changed following the introduction of the new treatment of superannuation assets in September 1997.
(4) How will the new system operate and can a number of examples be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) When part or all of a superannuation or rollover investment is withdrawn before Age Pension age (and the withdrawn amount is not rolled over into another superannuation or rollover fund or deferred annuity), then the growth component of the withdrawal attributable to a period during which the customer was in receipt of a pension or allowance is treated as income for 12 months from the date of withdrawal for income test purposes. Withdrawals, for the purposes of this assessment, do not include commutations of a superannuation pension (or other income stream) to a lump sum.

Currently, the superannuation or rollover investment is exempt from the means tests while it is held in a fund. This means that the assessment of income on withdrawals from the investment is necessary so that growth received by the customer is taken into account.
If the amount withdrawn before Age Pension age is rolled over into another superannuation or rollover fund or deferred annuity no income is assessed.

Whether the amount withdrawn will be taken into account under the assets test will depend on what the person does with it. For example, if it is used to pay off the mortgage on the principal home, there would be no impact under the assets test, as the person's home is not an assessable asset. However, if the person used the money to purchase a financial investment, the value of the new investment would be taken into account under the assets test.

(2) Whether a withdrawal from a superannuation fund affects a customer's entitlements under the current rules will depend on the amount withdrawn, the period the person has been getting income support payments from DSS (the `assessable period'), and the level of growth of the superannuation investment over the assessable period.
Examples in Attachment A illustrate this.

(3) From 20 September 1997, the assessment of withdrawals from a superannuation fund for income testing purposes will depend on whether or not the pre‐Age Pension age customer has been on income support for a total period of 39 weeks after reaching the age of 55. If the answer is no, then the current assessment rules as indicated in (1) and (2) would apply.

If the answer is yes, the growth component of the amount withdrawn would not be assessed as income. This is because deemed income would be assessed on the investment in the superannuation fund while it was held in the fund, based on the value of the investment. There would be an element of double counting if income was also to be assessed when there was a withdrawal from the superannuation fund.

In itself, the withdrawal would reduce the amount of deemed income assessed for the customer, because it would reduce the total value of the customer's financial investments to which the deeming rates are applied. In itself, the withdrawal would also reduce the customer's assessable assets. This could result in an increase in entitlement.

If the customer reinvests some or all of the amount that is withdrawn, then the new investment will be assessed under the means test rules that apply to it. For example, if the customer reinvests the amount that is withdrawn in another financial investment, the net effect would be that the customer's income and asset assessment would remain unchanged.

(4) As outlined in (3), from 20 September 1997, whether a withdrawal made by a customer whose superannuation assets are assessable affects the customer's entitlement will depend on the use to which the customer puts the funds. Examples in Attachment A illustrate this.
ATTACHMENT A
Basic Assumptions For Examples

PARA.TAB: a single allowee homeowner aged 58 who has been in receipt of Newstart Allowance for 3 years;
the allowee has a superannuation investment of $80,000;
the investment was worth $65,300 at the time the customer started receiving Newstart Allowance (ie the average growth over the 3 years was 7 per cent per annum); and
apart from his home, the customer has no other assets nor any other source of income.

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Before 20 September 1997
Example 1
Before September 1997, the customer gets the maximum rate of Newstart Allowance of $320 per fortnight.
The customer makes a withdrawal of $50,000 from the superannuation fund, and reinvests the proceeds in a financial investment.

PARA.TAB: As the customer withdrew 5/8ths of the superannuation investment, 5/8ths of the growth over the 3 years of income support receipt will be maintained as income for 12 months from the date of withdrawal. In this example, $353 per fortnight income would be maintained.

Because the $50,000 was reinvested into a financial investment, it is assessed under the deeming rules and deemed income of approximately $96 per fortnight is also taken into account under the income test. Therefore, the total income assessed would be $449 per fortnight and the customer would be entitled to about $63 Newstart Allowance per fortnight.

ANSWER.PARA: Example 2
The allowee uses the $50,000 withdrawal to make a lump sum mortgage repayment.

PARA.TAB: In this case there would be no deemed income (as the money has not been reinvested in a financial investment) but the withdrawal income calculated in Example 1 would apply. In this case, $353 per fortnight income would be maintained and the customer would be entitled to about $130 Newstart Allowance per fortnight.

ANSWER.PARA: 2. From 20 September 1997
Example 3

From 20 September 1997, the allowee would have his superannuation investment of $80,000 assessed under the deeming rules. Income assessed under the deeming rules would be approximately $165 per fortnight. This would result in a Newstart entitlement of approximately $262 per fortnight.
The customer makes a withdrawal of $50,000 from the superannuation fund, and reinvests the proceeds in a financial investment.

PARA.TAB: Under the income test, the balance of $30,000 in the superannuation fund and the $50,000 which was reinvested would be added together, and the total value of $80,000 would be assessed under the deeming rules. This would give the same deemed income and allowance entitlement as that assessed prior to the customer making the superannuation fund withdrawal.

ANSWER.PARA: Example 4
The allowee uses the withdrawal of $50,000 from his superannuation fund to make a lump sum mortgage repayment.

PARA.TAB: This course of action would mean there is no income or assets assessed in respect of the use of the withdrawn funds.

Under the income test, the balance of $30,000 in the superannuation fund would be assessed under the deeming rules. Income assessed under the deeming rules would be approximately $50 per fortnight. This would result in a Newstart entitlement of approximately $320 per fortnight.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Was there any hold‐up in issuing 1997 concession cards to any Social Security recipients; if so: (a) what were the reasons for this hold‐up; (b) how many people were affected; (c) what type of payments were these people receiving and how many were there in each payment type; (d) did this delay affect pensioners' ability to receive free rail vouchers provided by State governments; and (e) have all these cards now been issued; if not, when will they be.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. There was a delay of up to three weeks for some Social Security recipients.
(a) The problem arose from errors in data generated by system processing and conversion faults. The data errors have been corrected and the identified faults will be rectified by March.
(b) Approximately 98,000 pensioners were not initially included in the 2.6 million eligible for bulk issue of a 1997 Pensioner Concession Card.

(c) Data on the 98,000 pensioners involved is not available by payment type and would be costly to obtain. However, the likely payment types would be: Age Pension, Widows Pension, Mature Age Allowance, Sole Parent Pension, and Disability Support Pension.

(d) Yes. However, `replacement' PCCs (without valid vouchers) issued on request enabled those affected by the delay to access all concessions, other than the free travel concession provided by State Governments. Those wishing to travel urgently in early January 1997 needed to apply to the relevant State Rail Authority to establish their 1997 entitlement to free travel. Some States grant the free travel on production of a 1997 `replacement' PCC. Others provide concessional (half‐fare) travel only, with the possibility of claiming reimbursement of the half‐fare paid, on eventual production of a set of valid vouchers issued by DSS.
(e) Yes. In the general course of mail, the missing cards and vouchers should have been received by 23 January 1997.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 6 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware whether there are proposed river regulation schemes as follows and, if so, what is the current status of federal funding for the schemes: (a) dam on Black's Creek and St. Helen's Creek; (b) Fitzroy catchment; (c) dams on Comet and Dawson rivers; (d) dams on the Cooper and Paroo rivers; (e) dam site on Kidamen Creek; (f) raising Barron‐Pocket Dam; (g) third stage Hinze Dam, Glendower Dam on Albert and Wyaralong Dam on Teviot; (h) raising of Lenthals Dam for domestic supply of Hervey Bay; (i) Walla Weir at Johnstons crossing on the Burnett River; (j) dam at Elbow Valley on Condamine in south Queensland; and (k) weirs on Condamine near Brigalow and Condamine in south Queensland.
(2) Given that the Federal Government has pledged $1 billion for river regulation schemes in Queensland, what criteria are being used to determine which projects get funding.

(3) What consideration is being given to: (a) assessing the costs and benefits of policies that keep livestock and fertilisers away from water courses; (b) ensuring water is of an appropriate quality for the use proposed, rather than demanding high quality drinking water for all uses; (c) pricing mechanisms and public education on water usage; and (d) developing and setting appropriate performance criteria for urban stormwater and waste treatment.
(4)(a) Does the Minister and Government accept the principle of environmentally‐sustainable development; and (b) does the Government consider dams to be environmentally‐sustainable.

(5) What funding is being provided for alternatives such as: (a) defining criteria for environmental flows; (b) waste water recycling; (c) providing equipment to farmers so that they can carry out more efficient water utilisation of household rainwater tanks; (d) more research into the re‐use of fully treated sewage effluent by pumping back into storage areas; (e) rates rebate incentive scheme for reduction of water use; (f) encourage use of grey water; (g) installation of water efficient facilities; and (h) introduction of carry capacities for human populations.
(6) Why has the Federal Government approved the construction of the Walla Weir despite State department confirmation that the habitat of the lungfish will be destroyed if this is to occur.

(7) With reference to the Council of Australian Governments agreement, signed by the States, which is seeking to achieve realistic costing of water, what mechanism is being used to allocate water rights under this agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth is not involved in any of the proposed river regulation schemes mentioned in the question except for the Walla Weir at Johnstons Crossing on the Burnett River. The Walla Weir Irrigation Project is funded under the Queensland Sugar Industry Infrastructure Program, which is a four year (ending June 1997) program for infrastructure development (transport, irrigation, drainage) in the sugar industry. Commonwealth funding of $4.745 million for the Walla Weir project has been approved conditional on the implementation of environmental and land management conditions recommended by the Commonwealth Minister for the Environment, Senator the Hon. Robert Hill. No funds have been provided to date.

(2) The Federal Government has not pledged $1 billion for river regulation schemes in Queensland. I understand that the Queensland Government announced in August 1996 its intention to outlay $1 billion over fifteen years on the development of new water infrastructure. Criteria for the selection of projects are a matter for the Queensland Government.

(3) The water resource management issues raised in the question are the responsibility of the State and Territory governments and are covered by the strategic water industry reform policy agreed by the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) in 1994. The strategic framework includes; pricing reform based on full economic cost recovery; reduction or elimination of cross‐subsidies; clarification of property rights and enhanced trading arrangements for water entitlements; recognition that the environment is a legitimate user of water; implementation of the National Water Quality Management Strategy; institutional reform and public consultation and participation.

The Commonwealth works with the States and Territories through the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ) to develop integrated and sustainable agricultural land and water management policies. ARMCANZ is responsible to the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) for monitoring the implementation of the COAG Water Industry Reform Framework.

(3a) In 1995 the Department undertook and published a study into the potential scope for economic instruments to assist in reducing nutrient levels in agricultural run‐off. This study highlighted the need for holistic and integrated approaches to natural resource management, which is the central plank to effective landcare practices supported under the National Landcare Program.

The land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation has two research programs of relevance. Under the Management of Nutrients and Eutrophication Research Program work is being undertaken to gain a better understanding of the processes that lead to the development of algal blooms in Australian fresh and estuarine waters. Under the Rehabilitation and Management of Riparian Lands Research Program work is being undertaken to develop guidelines and practices for sound and economic management of riparian lands to maintain and improve the condition and value of streams, wetlands and impoundments.

(3b) In 1996, under the National Water Quality Management Strategy, the National Medical Health and Research Council and the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand jointly prepared Australian Drinking Water Guidelines. The guidelines provide the minimum requirements for drinking water of good quality. In addition, in 1992 the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council released Water Quality Guidelines for Fresh and Marine Waters. These guidelines establish water quality parameters for a range of uses including agricultural and recreational use.
(3c) Water pricing and public education are specifically being addressed by the States and Territories in the implementation of the COAG water industry reform framework.
(3d) Under the National Water Quality Management Strategy guidelines for urban stormwater management and waste treatment are currently being developed.

(4a) The Commonwealth is committed to the 1994 COAG water industry reform framework which requires that any new water resource development projects be both economically viable and environmentally sustainable.

(5a) Research is being undertaken under the National River Health program, which is the responsibility of the Minister for the Environment, into the environmental requirements of Australia's rivers. An important element of this work is the development of a decision support system to allow State and Territory governments, in consultation with community groups, to make informed decisions on environmental flow requirements.

(5b) Under the National Landcare Program, which operates in partnership with State and Territory Governments, funding is available to support activities which include economic and sustainable re‐use options for treated effluent in a catchment management context. A number of projects have been funded for the reuse of effluent from treated sewage for irrigation, primarily as an alternative to the discharge of nutrients to our rivers.
(5c) No funding is being provided through the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio.
(5d) See answer to 5(b).
(5e) No funding is being provided through the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio.
(5f) No funding is currently being provided through the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio.
(5g) No funding is being provided through the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio.
(5h) No funding is being provided through the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio.

(6) An environmental assessment process for the Walla Weir project was conducted over a long period of time to ensure that all parties had every opportunity to provide comments on any contentious issues. All comments received were taken into account during the preparation of reports by the Queensland Department of the Environment (QDE) and Environment Australia. The QDE report concluded that the project could proceed subject to a number of conditions being applied.

These reports, along with an independent report on major issues by Dr Keith Boardman, were then considered by the Commonwealth Minister for the Environment, Senator the Hon. Robert Hill, who subsequently provided me with advice on the environmental implications for the project. Senator Hill recommended that certain conditions, including those identified by QDE, be applied to ensure that the development is ecologically sustainable and operated under best land management practices.

I agreed with Senator Hill's recommendations and therefore approved the release of Commonwealth funds for the project subject to the requirement that the conditions be included as environment and land management requirements in the Implementation Arrangement (IA) for the project. The IA sets out all conditions under which the project will proceed and is to be signed by the project proponents and the Queensland Govern ment. I have asked the Queensland Government to ensure that these conditions are strictly applied.

(7) Implementation of the COAG water industry reform framework is the responsibility of State and Territory governments. The Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ) has endorsed a set of national principles establishing a strategic framework for the implementation of property rights in water. These principles will allow the States and Territories the flexibility to establish systems of water allocations and property rights to suit their specific jurisdictional circumstances.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Government Analytical Laboratory: Staff Reductions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there plans to cut staff numbers at the South Australian operation of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratory (AGAL) from 45 to 3; if so, why.
(2) What services does the Government anticipate will fill the hole created by such a funding cut.

(3) Given that the AGAL is crucial in outbreaks of food contamination, environmental testing for water and air pollution and examining food for export, how can it be argued that public health will be safeguarded if the cuts go ahead.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) AGAL's Adelaide laboratory is currently being downsized from 45 permanent and contract staff, to a shopfront with four permanent laboratory staff and two contractors.
The downsizing of the Adelaide laboratory is a part of the overall restructuring and re‐engineering of AGAL. Similar changes are also being made in Hobart.

(2) Following the restructuring, AGAL will continue to provide its full range of analytical services, including important functions relating to food and environmental testing. In particular, AGAL will maintain a strong national capability to respond to food contamination crises, as a backup and extension to the state systems, through major laboratories in Melbourne and Sydney. Funding for AGAL's public interest activities has been maintained.

All of the services provided in Adelaide are being continued—most being transferred to AGAL's other laboratories. Staff in the Adelaide shopfront will maintain contact with clients and forward locally sourced work to the appropriate AGAL laboratory. Occupational health and safety services, which cannot be readily transferred, will continue to be delivered by the remaining Adelaide staff.
(3) Claims that the restructuring of AGAL threatens public health are simply not true.

Initial investigations of incidents such as food poisoning are the responsibility of state public health laboratories. For example, AGAL was not involved in the initial investigation of the Garibaldi incident—this was handled by the South Australian Government's Institute of Medical and Veterinary Science (IMVS). AGAL nationally has since been involved in investigative work to assist the development of standards and protocols to prevent a repeat of such an incident.

The SA Government's IMVS is in fact the Australian reference laboratory for Salmonella and E‐coli bacteria—the causes of recent major food poisoning outbreaks. Suspected food poisoning cases anywhere in Australia are referred to the IMVS laboratory in Adelaide for confirmation.

AGAL has never provided all services from all laboratories—it is neither practical nor necessary. The Adelaide laboratory has never had a major capability for environmental testing of soil and water samples, and similarly, the Perth and Brisbane laboratories have never had a comprehensive food testing capability. AGAL laboratories regularly send samples interstate to the appropriate specialist AGAL facility, and this arrangement will continue through the Adelaide shopfront.
